title: Warner Bros. Enters Race For Network
description: Joining the race to establish the nation's fifth broadcast television network, Warner Brothers announced yesterday that it was creating WB, to be headed by Jamie Kellner, the former president of the Fox Broadcasting Company.

title: Chief Resigning From Convention Bureau
description: Marshall E. Murdaugh, president and chief executive of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau for the last five years, resigned unexpectedly yesterday, effective Jan. 1. The 52-year-old Mr. Murdaugh has a year remaining on his contract.

title: Books of The Times; When Embroidery Was a Lesson in Femininity
description: Girlhood Embroidery American Samplers and Pictorial Needlework, 1650-1850 By Betty Ring Illustrated. Two volumes. 584 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $125.

title: Dolco Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings in the 1993 and 1992 third quarter and 9 months are after payment of preferred dividends.

title: Packwood Case Steps Onto New Ground
description: The struggle over Senator Bob Packwood's diaries involves disputes over Congressional powers and civil liberties that date to the nation's birth. But it is also a venture onto uncharted ground, since no Senator in modern times has contested a Senate subpoena for his private papers.

title: BEARD BAN RULED UNFAIR TO BLACKS
description: In the latest upset to an employer's prohibition against beards, a Federal appeals court in St. Louis has ruled that Domino's Pizza must waive its ban for black employees who have a common and sometimes painful skin ailment.

title: Food Notes
description: Gourmet Kosher

title: Let's Get Profit and Loss Out of Health Care; Denial of Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Noble Drilling Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, which included losses from discontinued operations of $ 247,000 in the quarter and $ 2,932,000 in the 9 months.

title: Japanese Offer Highest Rate of Low-Skill U.S. Jobs
description: A new Government study of foreign-owned manufacturing companies in the United States has found that they generally provide the same quality jobs as American companies, with one exception: the Japanese employ a higher percentage of low-skilled workers than other companies do.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: COMBINING fruits and seafood is a potentially dangerous undertaking for any cook, for the flavor of the fruit can easily overwhelm the seafood. Fructose, the fruit sugar, is another culprit, capable of ruining seafood if it is allowed to become dominant.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: The Supporters; Viewing a Verdict as Based on Race
description: The defeat of New York's first black Mayor brought cries of anguish from black supporters, who said the verdict was based largely on race.

title: Severo Ochoa, Biochemist, A Nobel Winner, 88, Dies
description: Severo Ochoa, the biochemist who won the Nobel Prize for his discovery of an enzyme that can synthesize RNA, a nucleic acid that is a vital part of the genetic machinery of living cells, died on Monday in Madrid. He was 88.

title: Itel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 36 million from public offering of Antec and $ 8.1 million in charges from early repayment of debt in the quarter, and the 9 months included net income of $ 30.8 million, or 95 cents a share, from continuing operations and loss of $ 1.3 million from discontinued items.c-Net loss and included a loss of $ 7.3 million from continuing operations and a loss of $ 800,000 from discontinued operations in the quarter and the quarter also included a charge of $ 400,000 in the quarter, and the 9 months included $ 21.8 million in restructuring costs. The loss is made up of a loss of $ 30.6 million from continuing operations; a loss of $ 2.1 million from discontinued operations and an $ 18 million charge.

title: Coventry Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Syratech Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marquee Name on Undercard as Hearns Tries Comeback
description: Like a refreshing desert breeze, Thomas Hearns has blown away the hot air generated by the warring heavyweight camps.

title: United Airlines and Unions Are Said to Be at Impasse
description: United Airlines is at an impasse in talks with leaders of its pilots' and machinists' unions over the labor groups' effort to buy a majority stake in the carrier, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

title: Moscow Outlines 'Doctrine' for Its Future Military
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's Security Council approved new guiding principles today for the Russian Army in a long-awaited "military doctrine," which declares that the main source of military danger is no longer any nation or alliance, but small local conflicts.

title: Capital Re reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Man in the News; A Road of Many Turns, an End Triumphant: Rudolph William Giuliani
description: Taking his place as New York City's 107th mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani gains a position of influence and prestige for which he fought feverishly and at times awkwardly since his slender defeat by David N. Dinkins four years ago.

title: Theodore Barash, 79, Advertising Executive
description: Theodore Barash, a former senior vice president with the advertising firm of Wells Rich Greene BDDP Inc., who created advertising campaigns for Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways, died on Oct. 22 at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington. He was 79 and lived in Monkton, Vt.

title: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN ON MISSILE PROJECT
description: On the first stop of an Asia trip intended to address the North Korean nuclear threat, Secretary of Defense Les Aspin urged Japanese officials on Tuesday to take part in a new, American-led missile defense program. But he said the Japanese would not necessarily have to offer commercial technology in return.

title: Review/Music; From When Jazz Was Young
description: Hardly any words are spoken in "Eddie, Bix and Bing," a low-key musical revue at Michael's Pub that re-creates pop-jazz sounds from the decade that immediately preceded the swing era. But the show, which features the jazz guitarist Frank Vignola, the cornetist Peter Ecklund and Eddie Byrd, a polished pop baritone, offers appealing musical sketches of a time when American jazz was young, fresh and uncomplicated.

title: They Still Harvest Wild Rice The Old-Fashioned Way
description: SWISH - THUMP - THUMP. Swish-thump-thump. On a warm, still morning in late August, two Ojibwa Indians glided through the shallow water of Little Tamarac Lake in a canoe, harvesting wild rice in a rhythm that linked them to the world of their ancestors.

title: Supreme Court Eases Restrictions On Use of Tapes of Its Arguments
description: Released from restrictions imposed by the Supreme Court on public access to audiotapes of the Court's arguments, the National Archives said today that beginning immediately members of the public could obtain copies of the tapes for any purpose, including broadcast and commercial reproduction.

title: Let's Get Profit and Loss Out of Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of Italian Mourners File in Homage Past Fellini Bier
description: In the studio where he made his movies and his name, Federico Fellini lay in cinematographic state today, the lights soft, the music no more than a whisper, the tenderness of the thousands who filed by his burnished coffin mingling with the ghosts of his creations.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Penn-Princeton

title: Bridge
description: If both partnerships have close to 20 high-card points and there is no fit to be found, one can expect a small part-score contract producing a small score. But occasionally there is an aberration, as in the diagramed deal played late in February at the Long Island Regional Swiss Team Championship in Smithtown, L.I.

title: Workers at Getty Museum Scramble to Save Artworks
description: With a wall of fire just three miles away and bearing down on the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., fire engines ringed the institution yesterday and staff members were prepared to chop down trees surrounding the building to save it.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Bergen; Sunday-Closing Law Retained in New Jersey County
description: Efforts to repeal the 34-year-old ban on Sunday retailing in Bergen County, one of the country's richest shopping areas, were turned back easily today.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Woman in the News; An Outsider Wins Office: Christine Todd Whitman
description: Today Christine Todd Whitman both fulfilled the political promise she showed three years ago and realized the obligation of public service that was virtually her familial inheritance.

title: General Nutrition Cos. (NMS) reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 16
description: b-After an extraordinary loss from early retirement of debt of $ 1,435,000 and $ 5,004,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-After an extraordinary loss from early retirement of debt of $ 812,000.Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months were after preferred dividends of $ 1,185,000 and $ 3,430,000, respectively.Share earnings for all periods are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Oct. 5, 1993.

title: Prosecutors Pick Up Pace In Trial of Blast Suspects
description: Two more defendants were linked for the first time yesterday to evidence in the World Trade Center bombing trial, as the Government sought to tie one man to chemicals used in the blast and another to a motive of anger over American aid to Israel.

title: Norton Hangs In for Now And Cowboys Go Into Shift
description: When the Dallas Cowboys face the Giants on Sunday, their four-man defensive line will have left end Tony Tolbert over Doug Riesenberg, left tackle Tony Casillas over Bob Kratch, right tackle Russell Maryland over William Roberts and right end Charles Haley over Jumbo Elliott. But when the Cowboys change that standard set, they may line up Brown over Tom.

title: Real Estate; Philip Johnson, the renowned architect, joins the Trump team on the huge Riverside South project.
description: HE is the best-known developer in New York City. The site for his current project has perhaps the greatest potential of any unbuilt parcel in Manhattan. Who else, then, to give form to the project but America's most celebrated living architect?

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Mayor; GIULIANI OUSTS DINKINS BY A THIN MARGIN; WHITMAN IS AN UPSET WINNER OVER FLORIO
description: Rudolph William Giuliani, a tavern owner's son who challenged Wall Street, political corruption and the mob as one of the nation's fiercest prosecutors, edged out David N. Dinkins last night for the right to take on municipal government and become the 107th Mayor of New York City -- the first Republican to lead it in a generation.

title: Bobsledders Stick Together in Germany
description: When some members of the United States bobsled team visited the bank in Altenberg, Germany yesterday, the entire team visited the bank. When one of the sledders went for a run, the entire team went for a run. Meals are eaten in the hotel. If anyone goes out, everyone goes out.

title: Wal-Mart Stores to Buy PACE Warehouse Clubs
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it was abandoning the brutally competitive warehouse club business, selling 91 of its PACE Membership Warehouses stores, all PACE inventory and its membership list to its rival, Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

title: WHITMAN IS AN UPSET WINNER OVER FLORIO; New Jersey Anger Over Taxes Propels Challenger
description: Christine Todd Whitman harnessed lingering anger over taxes and scored an upset victory over Gov. Jim Florio last night to become the first woman to be Governor of New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about a debate between candidates for Nassau County Executive misidentified two of the men shown. The mustached man at the center was Benjamin Zwirn; at the right, facing the camera, was Charles E. Holster 3d. The moderator, Matthew Crosson, was not shown. The caption also misidentified the site of the debate. It was Westbury, L.I., not Southold.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: The Incumbent; Dinkins Ends the Campaign on Note of Gratitude
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins took his defeat for re-election with a warm expression of gratitude for his own place in city history and emphatic pleas to his supporters -- in the face of their own booing to the contrary -- that "we will help Rudy."

title: National Car Rental Narrows Its Review
description: National Car Rental in Minneapolis said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on its estimated $25 million account to five agencies from a dozen. The account was previously at Chiat/Day in New York, which was dismissed in September.

title: Fines Settle Trading Case
description: McVean Trading and Investments Inc. and six of its employees agreed today to pay more than $2 million in fines to settle charges that they had exceeded speculative position limits in futures contracts on live cattle.

title: Kollek Ousted, Resoundingly, In Israeli Vote
description: One of the world's longest and most acclaimed political careers came thunderously crashing down early today when Teddy Kollek was swept from office after 28 years as the indomitable Mayor of Jerusalem.

title: Recipe: Fall Vegetable Stew With Fingerling Potatoes
description: Adapted from David Bouley

title: Zaring Homes Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are pro forma. The company said that the pro forma information reflected the effects on the historical income statement data for each of the periods presented as if the company had not been treated as an S corporation for income tax purposes (assuming a 40 percent combined effective rate). The company completed its initial public offering in May.

title: Drumming (Thump Thump) for the 90's: Much (Thump) More (Thump) Than a Beat
description: BY day, Riva Rothman is a data processing manager at the Consolidated Edison Company in New York. Dressed in silk blouses and conservative suits, she supervises the installation of computer networks for the utility. After hours, though, she drums.

title: Review/Fashion; Bringing New Life (and Bamboo Bra Tops) to the Party
description: NEW YORK'S lineup of young fashion designers is starting to reflect that gorgeous mosaic that is supposed to makes up the general population. And in very recent years the audiences at shows have begun to represent the cross-section of customers who buy clothes.

title: GAF Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $ 2.2 million for an income tax provision due to the change in the federal corporate income tax rate in the quarter and 9 months.c-After an accounting charge from adoption of SFAS 106 of $ 20,800,000.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an obituary of John G. Winant Jr., who was captured by the Germans in World War II while his father was the American Ambassador to Britain, was published in error. It showed Mr. Winant's father, John G. Winant, who died in 1947.

title: Review/Fashion; An Easy Grace By de la Renta
description: OSCAR DE LA RENTA brought a rare quality to the design of his spring collection: moderation. He started his career as flamboyant as the next designer, with prints-too-bold and ruffles-too-many. Now, he is exercising restraint and bringing a glow to the eyes of retailers. Many of the prominent women who wear his clothes braved the crowds yesterday to turn out for his show in a tent in Bryant Park. They were glad they did.

title: OTHER HIGHLIGHTS
description: TERM LIMITS -- Approved, in a Wave of Anti-Incumbency

title: SOROS INVESTMENT SENDS GEOTEK SHARES SOARING
description: Shares of Geotek Industries jumped almost 26 percent yesterday after the company said a partnership that included the financier George Soros would invest $40 million in the company. In addition, Geotek, a company based in Montvale, N.J., that operates specialized mobile radio and wireless communications systems, said it had formed a strategic alliance with the Soros Group to acquire radio licenses and construct digital networks overseas.

title: Borg-Warner Security Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Pro-forma results adjusted to eliminate nonrecurring administrative costs, interest expense, excess purchase price amortization, certain gains of asset sales, and special provisions relating to restructuring efforts.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 268,900,000, which included a write-off of $ 250 million.d-Net income and included an extraordinary gain of $ 17,600,000.Share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma.Borg-Warner Security that final net income for the third quarter was $ 6,900,000, compared with $ 31,600,000 a year-ago.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: WHITMAN WINS NEW JERSEY RACE

title: Performance Food Group (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After a charge of $ 157,000 reflecting the adoption of FASB 109, Accounting for Income Taxes, effective Dec. 29, 1991.Performance Food Group said that the increases in the average number of shares outstanding for the 1993 third quarter and 9 months are due to its initial public offering of 1.9 million common shares in August 1993.

title: Review/Music; Two Ways for Composers to Sound New
description: The American Composers Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon was interesting for, among other reasons, the tensions between its two newest pieces. Michael Daugherty's "Oh Lois!" was one.

title: Box Turtle Versus Lawn Mower
description: Moe, an Eastern box turtle, made his home among the flowers, shrubs and grass of a large Long Island yard. But, like so many Eastern box turtles in New York and its suburbs, he was living on borrowed time amid urban sprawl and the human-generated hazards that come with it.

title: Smith Gets the Cowboys Out of a Hole
description: Most Super Bowl champions featured a signature offensive play that defied logic. Each opponent knew it was coming. Few could consistently stop it.

title: A Borough Gives Notice (Or Hadn't You Noticed?)
description: WITH the residents of Staten Island voting on whether to start down the road to secession, what is the rest of New York thinking?

title: Schultz Sav-O Stores Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
Beria, the Reformer
description: Mention Lavrenti P. Beria to anyone in the former Soviet Union who lived through the Stalin era and the response is revulsion. In the West, too, Beria's memory causes shudders. With good reason. He ranks among the most villainous political figures of the century. But there was another side to this evildoer, a side that has only recently come to light.

title: The Wines For Oysters
description: Which white wines complement the briny, metallic flavor of oysters? This perennial debate was put to the test in the Pacific Northwest last week in a rigorous series of tastings that arrived at 10 winners from a field of 134 regional wines.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON TO BUY GERMAN COMPANY
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Klockner Werke A.G.'s plastics injection-molding machine business for $56 million in cash and assumed debt. The unit being sold, Ferromatik, has 600 employees and annual sales of $100 million. Cincinnati Milacron makes plastics processing equipment, machine tools, computer controls and manufacturing systems.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18 GORBACHEV NOT COUNTED OUT Although his popularity rating is low, Mikhail Gorbachev, in an interview, would not count himself out of politics and was evasive about whether he would run for President. A3 DEFEAT FOR JERUSALEM MAYOR Early returns showed Teddy Kollek swept from office after 28 years as Mayor of Jerusalem. The results were a blow to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin as well, because he had called the election a test of his agreement with the P.L.O. A18

title: Scouts See Nothing Very Spectacular by Islanders
description: Perhaps there are more big trades brewing among the clubs of the National Hockey League. Hours after the Rangers, Hartford and Chicago engineered a multi-player shuffle, there were nine scouts in the Coliseum press box to watch Vancouver's 2-1 victory over the Islanders tonight, enough scouts to start a campfire by rubbing two hockey sticks together.

title: Gorbachev, Energetic, Chatty, but Not Yet Political
description: If he did sense an unquenchable desire to return to active politics, Mikhail S. Gorbachev insists, "I would find a way."

title: CONAGRA ADDS TO STAKE IN AUSTRALIAN MEAT HOLDINGS
description: Conagra Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of the Foster's Brewing Group's interest in Australian Meat Holdings for about $60 million. The purchase, which is subject to regulatory review, would raise Conagra's stake in Australian Meat, a leading Australian beef processor and exporter, to more than 90 percent from its current 50 percent interest. The meat company has annual sales of more than $900 million. Since June 30, Foster's, the Australian brewing giant, has sold nonbrewing assets valued at about $360.1 million. Conagra, a diversified food company based in Omaha, has annual sales of more than $21 billion.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The down-home Hardee's restaurant chain makes a big-city move to Deutsch/Dworin.
description: IT'S not quite as odd a couple as Felix and Oscar. It's not as incongruous a pairing as Julia and Lyle. But when Hardee's Food Systems Inc. said yesterday that Deutsch/ Dworin Inc. would become the national advertising agency on its estimated $75 million Hardee's account, the chain created one of Madison Avenue's most disparate couplings.

title: Rivers Is Prepared to Confront Aches and Pains Anew
description: The National Basketball Association season is about to begin. And with it will come the aches and pains, bumps and bruises and nagging injuries that are part of playing a game meant for young, resilient bodies.

title: Oxford Health Plans Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 3.3 million from a change in accounting principle.Earnings per share have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 27. Before the split, primary earnings per share for the latest periods were 50 cents in the quarter and $ 1.25 for the 9 months, compared to 28 cents a share and $ 1.17 a share, for year-ago periods, respectively.Diluted earnings before the split were 50 cents a share in the latest quarter and 27 cents in year-ago period. Diluted earnings for the latest 9 months before the stock split were $ 1.24 a share, compared to $ 1.14 a share, in year-ago period. Company officials could not immediately supply primary earnings after the split.Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Conrail Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeConrail said that the latest 9 months net income would have been $ 214 million, or $ 2.31 a share, fully diluted basis), a 12.6 percent increase in net income and a 15.5 percent increase in earnings per share, after excluding the nonrecurring items and the one-time charges in the first quarter of $ 74 million after taxes, for adoption of required changes in accounting for income taxes (SFAS 109), and postretirement benefits other than pensions.The estimated loss on disposition of the company's subsidiary, Concord Resources Group Inc., included estimated future operating losses during the phase-out period and disposition costs. Net income for the quarter and 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1993 has been reduced by the loss of $ 80 million less the estimated tax benefits of $ 30 million.The company also said that the 1993 results reflected two nonrecurring items: the estimated loss on the disposition of its Concord Resources Group subsidiary and the retroactive effects of the federal corporate income tax rate increase.Conrail adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions'' and Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109 (SFAS 109), ''Accounting for Income Taxes'' effective Jan. 1, 1993. As a result, during the first quarter of 1993, Conrail recorded cumulative after-tax charges of $ 22 million and $ 52 million, respectively, from the two accounting changes.Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Reviews/Film; East Germany Revisited by the Non-Thriller Route
description: Movies and spy novels have so relentlessly portrayed life under Communism as a paranoid adventure fantasy that a drab little film like Roland Graf's "Tango Player," which is set in East Germany in 1968, stands as revealing corrective to the action-adventure cliche. Set mostly in Leipzig, the movie follows the desultory post-prison odyssey of Dallow (Michael Gwisdek), an assistant professor and part-time pianist who has spent time in jail for being in the wrong place at the wrong time.

title: New Yorkers Approve Limit of 2 Terms for City Officials
description: Joining a national tide of anti-incumbency, New Yorkers voted decisively yesterday to approve a referendum limiting the city's elected officials to two consecutive terms, or eight years in office.

title: New-Home Sales Jump By 20.8%
description: Inspired by mortgage rates under 7 percent, buyers snapped up new homes in September at the fastest pace since 1986, a performance that far surpassed expectations, Government figures showed today. All regions boomed except the Northeast, where sales eased slightly.

title: No Headline
description: "It's just like when everybody flocks to a beach on a Sunday. Guess what happens. You sit in the car and wait and wait and wait." DAVID FARBER, University of Pennsylvania computer scientist, on the information highway's traffic jam. [ D1:4. ]

title: Pittway Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 10,726,000, or 77 cents a share, and after a gain of $ 1,535,000, or 11 cents a share, reflecting the cumulative effect of changes in accounting for income taxes and postretirement benefits.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 21,079,000, or $ 1.52 a share, in the quarter and $ 32,726,000, or $ 2.36 a share, in the 9 months.Pittway said that the 1992 figures are restated for discontinued operations.

title: Eating Well
description: ANYONE who has experienced the symptoms of pregnancy that are commonly referred to as "morning sickness" is unlikely ever to forget it. Unrelenting nausea casts a pall over every waking hour. Vomiting occurs with little or no warning, and the accompanying gastrointestinal distress can range from constipation to diarrhea.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Comptroller; Hevesi Wins Easy Victory In Battle Against Badillo
description: Alan G. Hevesi, the Democrat who was all but dismissed as a serious contender by opponents and pundits alike when he announced his candidacy, defeated Herman Badillo yesterday in the race for New York City comptroller.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: City Council; Incumbents Score Well In Contests For Council
description: The vast majority of Democratic incumbents on the City Council appeared headed toward easy victories last night, assuring that Speaker Peter F. Vallone would retain control of the 51-member Council.

title: COLOMBIA OFFERS CARROT TO CARTEL
description: Colombia's Congress approved legislation today that increases the benefits for drug traffickers and other organized criminals who surrender to the authorities, confess to their crimes and give information that leads to the capture of other criminals.

title: Eating Well
description: ANYONE who has experienced the symptoms of pregnancy that are commonly referred to as "morning sickness" is unlikely ever to forget it. Unrelenting nausea casts a pall over every waking hour. Vomiting occurs with little or no warning, and the accompanying gastrointestinal distress can range from constipation to diarrhea.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Is it politically correct to call yourself politically incorrect? In fact, is it legally correct? The people who run the Comedy Central cable television channel say no, and yesterday they went to court trying to keep JACKIE MASON from calling his new show, what else, "Jackie Mason, Politically Incorrect."

description: In percent

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Staten Island; Secession Is Approved; Next Move Is Albany's
description: Residents of Staten Island yesterday took a step toward severing their ties to New York City by approving a new City Charter that is both a declaration of independence and the political foundation for what could become the state's second largest city.

description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Jerusalem's Mayor Defeated

title: McDowell Of White Sox Is Clear-Cut Young Pick
description: After Jack McDowell lost both of his starts to Toronto in the American League pennant playoff, speculation that the Chicago White Sox would trade their No. 1 pitcher grew. Today, the White Sox general manager quashed that idea, and that was before he knew that McDowell had won the Cy Young award.

title: White House Is Adamant on Balkan War Crimes
description: The Clinton Administration has ruled out granting amnesty to those accused of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia and will press for sanctions against countries that refuse to hand over suspects for trial by the new United Nations war crimes tribunal, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Esco Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big-Spending Tigers Sign Fryman for $25 Million
description: On a day when the Detroit Tigers reached agreement with one of their good young players, Travis Fryman, on a five-year, $25 million contract, the Yankees continued to hold on to their good young prospects. As a result, the Yankees today dropped out of the running for Bryan Harvey, the relief pitcher who saved 70 percent of the Florida Marlins' first-year victories.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Keenan Gets His Men; Patrick and Turcotte Gone
description: Mike Keenan's brand of hockey became further imprinted on the Rangers yesterday when the organization announced that as part of a three-team trade it had swapped defenseman James Patrick and center Darren Turcotte for veteran right wing Steve Larmer and tough-guy Nick Kypreos. The Rangers also acquired a minor league defenseman and a conditional middle-round draft pick.

title:
HORSE RACING;
After Workout, It's Again a Gilded Age
description: When Gilded Time won last year's Breeders' Cup Juvenile, he became the sport's 2-year-old champion and the future book favorite for the 1993 Kentucky Derby.

title: Kaneb Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on issue of units by partnership of $ 15,122,000, or 47 cents a share.c-Net loss and included $ 1.8 million in reserves related to reorganization of its Furmanite subsidiary and a gain of $ 500,000 from sale of some old Kaneb properties in the quarter, and 9 months included income from discontinued operations of $ 996,000, or 3 cents a share, and a gain of $ 742,000, or 2 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Year-ago 9 months' loss from continuing operations of $ 5,227,000 included gain of $ 1.6 million from sale of properties and tax refund.

title: Rogers Cantel Mobile Commun. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a provision for reorganization and goodwill write-off totaling $ 75,345,000 in the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a loss of $ 45,233,000 related to betterments and commissions written off.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: AT WORK WITH: Sean Driscoll; Selling Perfection in an Imperfect World
description: GOD is in the details at Glorious Food, but with Sean Driscoll around He has to fight for space.

title: Book Notes
description: Tale of a Dynasty

title: New York and Fashion Industry Fit Each Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Shiloh Industries
description: Shares of Shiloh Industries, a steel processor based in Mansfield, Ohio, slumped yesterday after the company announced that fourth-quarter earnings would be lower than what some analysts had predicted, largely as a result of one-time charges. The stock had climbed last month after falling sharply in late September.

title: Ex-Linebacker Loses Again in Giants Case
description: A year after being hoist with his own petard in a lawsuit against the Giants, the former linebacker LANCE HAMILTON is getting the bill for pursuing what a judge called a frivolous claim that the team had reneged on a promise to hire him as an assistant coach.

title: Scali Agency Loses Castrol Account
description: Castrol Inc. of Wayne, N.J., said yesterday that it had left Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, its agency since 1976, and moved its national advertising account without a review to Houston, Effler, Hampel & Stefanides Inc. in New York, which is headed by several former Scali employees. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: A Little Bag of (Spice) Tricks
description: THE use of pickling spices is a handy way to add many flavors to a dish. The spices can give tomato sauce a lift quite different from the usual choices, like oregano and basil in an Italian recipe, tarragon in a French dish or ginger and soy sauce in a Chinese version.

title: J. Brenner, 63, Lawyer Who Lobbied for Koch
description: James Brenner, who served as a bureaucrat and a lobbyist when Edward I. Koch was Mayor of New York, died on Saturday at his home in Little River, S.C. He was 63.

title: Personal Health
description: MOST of what children learn about the world they learn through their eyes. Yet the eyes are often sadly neglected, and for lack of proper and well-timed eye exams, correctable visual difficulties present in infants, toddlers or preschoolers are missed until they are well into the elementary grades or beyond.

title: Lincoln National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 96,431,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change for postretirement benefits.Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for June 1993 2-for-1 stock split.Year-ago results are restated for adoption of FAS 109, Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: Israel-P.L.O. Talks Hit Snag Over Repositioning Troops
description: Negotiations between Israel and the P.L.O. ran into their first big obstacle today when the Palestinians suddenly broke off the talks to show their displeasure with Israeli plans for a repositioning of troops in the occupied territories.

title: Emerson Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: In America; The Verdict
description: The verdict yesterday was thumbs down on David Dinkins's stewardship over the last four years. The voters expressed their dissatisfaction, which was certainly their right, but they cannot claim they were the victims of false advertising.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Virginia; Conservative Republican Wins Easily
description: George F. Allen, a conservative former Republican Representative who once was down in the polls by 29 points, won the Virginia Governor's race today, besting former Attorney General Mary Sue Terry, a moderate Democrat.

title: No Loans to Boost Arms Sales
description: As the Pentagon's demand for new weapons declines, America's arms makers, hard pressed to make a buck, or a billion, are trying harder to market their wares abroad. But the global arms market is contracting. Now the arms makers have come up with a new scheme to stimulate foreign demand at taxpayers' expense: get Congress to put up $1 billion in Government loan guarantees, a subsidy to foreigners who buy on credit.

title: A Misleading Health Estimate
description: The Administration's estimate that 40 percent of insured families would pay higher premiums under its health care bill jarred everyone on Capitol Hill last week. When Donna Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, presented the estimate, she gave ammunition to opponents of the President's bill and dismayed supporters.

title: Amtran (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Politicization of Tasseled Loafers
description: To say "tasseled loafer" in Washington is not just to describe a simple shoe, but to utter a political phrase, often part of an epithet.

title: Aon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of about $ 8 million on increased tax rate in the quarter and 9 months.c-After a charge from cumulative effect of change in accounting of $ 79,600,000.Year-ago results are restated to reflect changes in accounting for income taxes and postretirement benefits.Share earnings for both periods included effect of $ 6.1 million and $ 18.3 million of dividends incurred for the third quarter and 9 months, respectively, ended Sept. 30, 1993, on the 8 percent and 6.25 percent preferred stock.

title: Defendant in Beating Case Loses Bid to Lower Bail
description: Calling him "a danger to the community," a judge refused today to lower bail for Damian M. Williams, a black man who was convicted of mayhem in the beating of a white truck driver, Reginald O. Denny, during last year's riots but was acquitted of more serious charges. At the same hearing, Mr. Williams's co-defendant, Henry K. Watson, pleaded guilty to the trial's one deadlocked charge, assault with a deadly weapon.

title: Reviews/Film; 'The War Room': Behind the Scenes of Clinton's Campaign
description: "The War Room" was shown during the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 13. The film opens today at Film Forum 1, 209 West Houston Street, South Village, and is to run until Nov. 16.

title: HAITI IS SUFFERING UNDER OIL EMBARGO
description: Two weeks after an oil embargo was imposed on Haiti, the streets of the capital are increasingly piled with garbage, factories are shut down, power blackouts are occurring more freqently and armed gangs are operating more freely as they rob stores and extort money.

title: WPIX Yank Quest Goes On
description: In the drama to keep the Yankees on free television, WPIX has asked the MSG Network to clarify an offer the cable television network made last week to split production costs and profits or losses for 50 games.

title: Long Bond's Yield Rises in Selloff
description: The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.05 percent yesterday from 6.02 percent on Monday on selling in response to more news that the economy is looking stronger than it did in the first half of the year.

title: Pactel Wins Approval To Sell Wireless Unit
description: The Pacific Telesis Group cleared a major regulatory hurdle today when California regulators approved a much-awaited plan for the regional Bell company to spin off its wireless communications operations from its core local telephone business.

title: Stocks Sluggish Despite Economic Reports
description: Investors yanked stocks through a bumpy session yesterday that illustrated how, these days, good economic news is not always good for the market.

title: Jordan Visits Bulls Practice, Oprah and Larry
description: "Don't make it out to be anything," Jerry Krause was saying yesterday on the telephone from the general manager's office at the Chicago Bulls' training center in Deerfield, Ill., a northwest Chicago suburb. "Michael's not coming back. He was just here to have some fun, screw around, laugh with the guys, give them a little boost.

title: Mixed Fortunes For Impressionists At First Fall Auction
description: Yes, there's still passion in the art market, but only for objects that deserve it. Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculptures last night showed not only that the slow but steady climb out of the last two years' doldrums continues, but also that if a work of art is special enough, collectors from all over the world will fight for it.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Friday, with the continuation of a front-page article about third-quarter gross domestic product, carried outdated figures. Readers wishing corrected copies of the table may write the Business Editor, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: CHRONICLE
description: His name may not be legendary in the annals of charity, but ALBERT HERZSTEIN of Houston has been selected by a panel that includes Jonas Salk, Marian Wright Edelman and Bill Moyers, as the winner of the 1993 American Philanthropy Award of the Columbus Foundation. The foundation is a trust that gives grants in the Columbus, Ohio, area.

title: New Doubts On Merger of Auto Makers
description: Even before the nuptials are completed, the proposed marriage of Renault S.A. of France and Volvo A.B. of Sweden to create the world's sixth-largest automotive group is showing signs of unraveling.

title: Jury Finds Deloitte Was Negligent
description: Deloitte & Touche, the big accounting firm, has been found grossly negligent in a tax case involving a limited partnership that could cost the firm more than $100 million.

title: Executive Changes
description: APPLE BANCORP INC., New York, said Edward J. Brown would retire as president, chief operating officer and director of the company and its Apple Bank for Savings unit on Dec. 1. Alan Shamoon, chief financial officer, will succeed Mr. Brown, who will continue as a consultant. ATLANTIC RECORDING CORP., New York, named Bob Shaw senior vice president for management information systems for Atlantic Records.

title: Video Lottery Tech. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary income equaled to 2 cents a share reflecting a pretax gain of $ 1.78 million from a lawsuit settlement, which was partially offset by a pretax charge of $ 1.3 million for executive severance packages, in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Tech-Sym Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MDU Resources Group Inc.  reports earnings for 12mos Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 5.5 million, or 29 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: 1 Potato, 2 Potato, More, More, More
description: IN the time of culinary innocence, people ordered baked potatoes off restaurant menus and bought baking potatoes at the market. Wasn't life simple? A spud was a spud was a spud.

title: A Simple Test Screens Men for a Sexual Disease
description: IN a study that holds promise for the fight against sexually transmitted disease, researchers have found that simple, relatively inexpensive urine tests make possible the accurate screening off large numbers of young men for the most commonly transmitted urethral infection.

title: Review/Fashion; Not for a Shrinking Violet
description: STEP right up and take your pick: sexy clothes for the club crawlers, innocent baby-doll dresses for the ingenue, or elegant beaded silks for the sophisticate. Next spring's evening offerings from the younger generation of designers is a study in contrasts.

title: Charles Shagass, 73, A Psychiatric Expert On Brain Function
description: Dr. Charles Shagass, a Philadelphia psychiatrist known for his research on brain function and mental disorder, died on Oct. 27 at Temple University Hospital. He was 73 and lived in Wyncote, Pa.

title: Butler International Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,227,000.c-Net lossd-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 148,000 in the quarter and $ 222,000 in the 9 months.

title: California Fire Strikes Malibu; Thousands Flee
description: A fierce and fast-moving wall of fire roared down from the Santa Monica Mountains northwest of here to the Pacific coast today, incinerating canyon ranches, hillside mansions and some of the multimillion-dollar estates of the exclusive oceanside town of Malibu.

title: All Those Problems For Beleaguered Team Just Don't Go Away
description: It has been a busy, mostly unfortunate year of newsmaking for the Nets, and as they prepare to open the new season Friday in Houston they are still dealing with the consequences.

title: DOCTORS ASSAILED IN ANTITRUST MOVE
description: The Federal Trade Commission used antitrust law today for the first time to challenge two joint ventures formed by doctors who sent patients to medical equipment companies in which the doctors had invested.

title: Former New York Hospitals Chief Facing Ethics Inquiry
description: A New York City ethics review agency is investigating whether the former head of New York City's hospital system obtained loans from subordinates in violation of the City Charter, city officials said yesterday.

title: Dolphins' Mitchell Paid His Dues, and It Pays Dividends
description: Two days after Scott Mitchell guided the Miami Dolphins to a 24-14 comeback victory over the Cleveland Browns in his National Football League unveiling in early October, he and his wife, Kim, went on a day trip to Orlando, Fla., with their 9-month-old son, Joshua.

title: Mother Is Charged in Abandoned Baby's Death
description: A 24-year-old woman has been charged with murder in the death of her 2-year-old daughter, who the police said was left alone for almost five days while the mother was in the hospital.

title: DuPont Merck Repackaging Costly
description: Members of Congress and Congressional aides said yesterday that a change in packaging of four drugs that will result in sharply higher prices showed the need for the mandatory drug price restraints in President Clinton's health care program.

title: Market Place; Raising some red flags over those stalwart utility stocks.
description: AS interest rates have fallen, increasing numbers of small investors have shifted their money into utility stocks or mutual funds heavily invested in utilities.

title: Cities Innovate in Hunt for Minority Male Teachers
description: In the hardened neighborhoods of North Philadelphia, Leonard Hill is a rarity: a teacher who is black and male.

title: Review/Pop; 3 Ages of Rod Stewart, Defined by Ages of Women
description: When Rod Stewart was in his 20's, he wrote rueful, self-mocking songs about affairs with older women. In his 30's, he praised a woman who would be his friend when "I grow old." At Madison Square Garden On Monday night, the second night of a sold-out three-night stand, the 48-year-old singer urged his audience to stay "Forever Young" and showed home videos of his 24-year-old wife, Rachel Hunter, and their child. He was a trim, high-kicking advertisement for a baby-boomer vision of extended youth, a little nostalgic (for "old Motown records") but still keeping mortality at bay.

title: O'Rourke Squeezes Ahead of Brodsky for County Executive Spot
description: Leading a Republican sweep of Westchester County's top elected offices, Andrew P. O'Rourke staved off a fierce challenge by a six-term Assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky, and declared victory Tuesday night in his bid to gain four more years as County Executive.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Deciding; Excerpts of Speeches, In Victory and Defeat
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Public Advocate; Green Breezes in Rematch From Primary
description: Mark J. Green, the once-defeated Senate candidate who became a popular consumer affairs commissioner, was an easy winner yesterday against Susan D. Alter in the race for Public Advocate, the city's second-highest office.

title: Give Bhutto Due Credit in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: When a 'Noninvasive' Scan Causes Panic
description: "THERE'S no question that for some people, it's the most horrible medical procedure they've ever had."

title: Masco Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest periods' share earnings included a charge of 4 cents a share related to federal corporate tax increase.

title: For New Lobbyists, It's Now What They Know
description: After years of watching prestigious institutions like Stanford and Harvard snap up billions in Federal research grants, the less glamorous university systems in 18 states came to Washington not long ago to seek their fair share of the pie. After all, they reasoned, if the top educators from a third of the nation couldn't turn bureaucratic heads, then who could?

title: U.S. and China Agree to Expand Defense Links
description: The first high-level military-to-military contact in more than four years has ended here after two days of talks between a Pentagon official and China's top military leaders.

title: For CBX, Figure Skating Is Olympics
description: In the Winter Olympics city of 1994, where Garrison Keillor would find that the men are strong, the women are good-looking and the children are cross-country skiers by age 3, the pressure is building on CBS to equal its highly rated performance in Albertville, France, in 1992.

title: The Vote For Mayor and Comptroller by Assembly District
Hudson Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Accused Olivetti Chief Surrenders and Is Freed Under House Arrest
description: In the latest convolution of Italy's huge bribery scandal, the computer tycoon Carlo De Benedetti, one of the country's richest men, surrendered today to magistrates who had ordered his detention on corruption charges but was freed from jail under house arrest after hours of interrogation.

title: SENATE, BY 94 TO 6, VOTES TO SUBPOENA PACKWOOD DIARIES
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to compel Senator Bob Packwood to turn over 3,000 pages of private diaries for an ethics investigation, ending with ill-concealed disgust an extraordinary political debate over the privacy rights of elected leaders.

title: Let's Get Profit and Loss Out of Health Care; Pharmacy Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Mantra for the Mayor: Deficit, Deficit, Deficit, Deficit
description: Congratulations, Mr. Mayor-elect! But now it's time to unseal that envelope labeled "Do Not Open Until After Election Day." In it is this year's revised budget, with a deficit of about half a billion dollars. In other words, you're already in deep fiscal trouble.

title: Whole Foods Market Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Sept 26
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $ 3.5 million in the latest year and $ 700,000 in 1992 from transaction related expenses and salaries related to former Mrs. Gooch's Natural Foods Supermarkets shareholders terminated upon the effective date of the merger.Whole Foods Market recently completed its merger with Mrs. Gooch's, a chain of seven stores in the Los Angeles area. The transaction was accounted for as a pooling-of-interests, and, accordingly, all transaction related expenses are being expensed in the current year.All historical financial statements have been restated to include the results of operations of the Mrs. Gooch's stores as if that merger had occurred at the beginning of all periods presented. Accordingly, the above figures are pro forma.

title: Walter L. Palmer, 97, an Internist And Expert on Gastrointestinal Ills
description: Dr. Walter L. Palmer, an authority on gastrointestinal cancer, died on Thursday at the Bernard Mitchell Hospital in Chicago. He was 97 and lived in Hyde Park near the campus of the University of Chicago.

title: Reno Dusts Cobwebs Out of Justice Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: French Tricolor Owes a Lot to the Dutch
description: To the Editor:

title: Dressage Will Take the Stage at This Year's National
description: These are the sort of horses unconnected to mankind by way of the trifecta or Pony Express: they don't run, they dance, and their human partners are so charmed by this pas de deux that they routinely ignore $500,000 offers for their mounts.

title: Laidlaw Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included after-tax charges totaling $ 95 million for landfill closure costs and recognition of reduced values for some Canadian hazardous waste facilities.c-Included in write-downs of the company's minority stakes in ADT Ltd. and Attwoods plc of $ 243,760,000 in the quarter and $ 169,950,000 in the year.d-Net income and the year included a charge of $ 6.1 million for the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Molson Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Ho Chi Minh City Journal; The Boat People Fly Back, With Riches to Invest
description: After fleeing Vietnam seven years ago with nothing but the desperate hope to make a better life anywhere else, Minh Le returned this fall with a bottle of perfume, a bottle of champagne and $2,000 in cash.

title: O'Reilly Automotive Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 48,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 51,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 113,000, or 2 cents a share, in the 9 months. the 9 months was also after a charge of $ 163,000 for the adoption of new methods of accounting for income taxes and postretirement benefits.

title: Vote Counting Will Take at Least 10 Days
description: The voting ended in the mayoral race at 9 o'clock last night, but the counting will go on until at least Nov. 12, because of state election laws governing the tallying of outstanding absentee and paper ballots.

title: Jams Already on Data Highway
description: Call it a cautionary tale for the information age: The nation's increasingly popular data highway is beginning to groan under the load of rush-hour traffic.

title: Sports of The Times; Sending A Better Message
description: I'LL be curious to hear what the Knicks have to say this morning.

title: More Than 1,000 Mourners at Funeral for Former Yonkers Mayor
description: Dozens of Westchester County politicians began this Election Day alongside more than 1,000 other mourners at the funeral of Nicholas C. Wasicsko, the former Yonkers mayor who died on Friday from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

title: Competition Draws Banks Into a Price War on Loans
description: Competitive pressures are pushing bankers to reduce interest rates on business loans and abandon some of the more stringent requirements imposed on borrowers a few years ago.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Westchester; Pirro Defeats An Outsider In a Contest Of Squabbles
description: Jeanine Pirro, a tough-talking former county judge, was elected Westchester's first new district attorney in a quarter century tonight, soundly beating back a challenge from Michael Cherkasky, a former Manhattan prosecutor running in his first political race.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Long Island; Gulotta Slips Past Opponent To Remain Nassau Chief
description: Thomas S. Gulotta, the incumbent Nassau County Executive who ran on a platform calling for change, squeaked by his Democratic challenger, Benjamin L. Zwirn, Tuesday night in a contest that was widely seen as a referendum on decades of Republican rule.

title: Letter: On Trade Surveillance; U.S. Monitors High-Tech Exports to Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: On Campus; Baby-Boomer Books Faulted in S.A.T. Drop
description: A Cornell professor contends that the nationwide decline in verbal Scholastic Assessment Test (S.A.T.) scores since 1963 is a result of simplified schoolbooks introduced after World War II.

title: Gold Spring to Miss Sprint
description: The Breeders' Cup Sprint lost one of its top contenders today when Gold Spring was injured while training in Kentucky. Gold Spring won the A Phenomenon Stakes at Saratoga this summer. Gold Spring was not an original nominee to the Breeders' Cup. The initial supplemental fee of $67,000 paid last week by the horse's owner, Ross Harris, to make Gold Spring eligible is nonrefundable.

title: Logistics Steps Onto Retail Battlefield
description: The latest buzz in the retail industry isn't about hemlines or projections of holiday sales. Instead, retail executives are talking about logistics, the science of moving goods from a manufacturer into a customer's hands in the most timely, efficient and cost-effective way.

title: Jets' Jones Takes Calls, But There's No Answer
description: Marvin Jones gets calls from friends each week. They all have the same questions. "Why aren't you playing more? Why aren't you starting?"

title: Wine Talk
description: At a news conference in Canada last year, Nelson Mandela, whom many expect to become South Africa's President in 1994, was asked if any land-distribution programs his Government might undertake would extend to vineyards. Wine farms, Mr. Mandela said, were no different than any other farms.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Voters; In New Jersey, Concern Over Taxes and Trust
description: It was the voters' turn to be heard in New Jersey's governor's race yesterday, and as they left their polling booths in elementary schools and fire houses, in centers for the elderly and libraries, they described their anger about higher taxes and their worries about a poor economy. Above all, they talked of the question that came to dominate the race: whether Gov. Jim Florio deserved another term.

title: Zebra Technologies (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Review/Television; Two New Police Shows, Midwest and Southeast
description: Television detectives, in uniform and out, are getting ensnared in conflicting evidence this season. Gritty urban realism (ABC's "N.Y.P.D. Blue") appears to be connecting with viewers, while offbeat comedy-drama (CBS's "South on Sunset," canceled after just one episode) seems to search desperately for a sympathetic smile. On the other hand, ABC's "Missing Persons," in which the urban realism is pointedly non-gritty, is treading ratings waters nicely, and the same network's comedy-drama "Moon Over Miami" is holding on, albeit tenuously.

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM STAKE SOLD AT REQUEST OF U.S.
description: An investment fund led by Goldman, Sachs & Company sold its 20 percent stake in the National Gypsum Company to a French maker of construction products to avoid Federal antitrust problems, the Justice Department said yesterday. The fund, Water Street Corporate Recovery Fund I L.P., sold about four million National Gypsum shares for about $76 million to Lafarge Coppee S.A., National Gypsum said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMOCO CORP., Chicago, said its Dutch subsidiary had begun production at an offshore North Sea gas complex. BANCO ESPANOL DE CREDITO S.A., Madrid, signed a $60 million joint venture with Israeli and Arab companies to develop business projects in the Gaza and Jericho areas.

title: The Talk of Hollywood; A Studio Tiptoes on Literary Ground
description: It's unusual for a big Hollywood studio like Columbia Pictures to release, in a fairly brief span, two such serious, high-minded movies as "The Age of Innocence" and "The Remains of the Day."

title: Threats End in Two Killings and a Kidnapping
description: After harassing his ex-girlfriend for months, a Bronx man went on a rampage yesterday, killing the woman's mother and sister and then kidnapping her and four small children, the police said.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Mayoral Races; New Faces Moving Into City Halls Around Nation
description: This most Irish of American cities today elected Thomas M. Menino, the grandson of Italian immigrants, its first non-Irish mayor in 63 years, a sign that the pitch of ethnic politics has been muted.

title: Review/Theater: The Treatment; A City So Relentlessly Abusive Its Residents Decide Not to See
description: Being blinded by a fork-wielding assailant isn't necessarily the worst thing that could befall a character in the lurid world of "The Treatment," a pitch-black comic portrait of New York City by the English writer Martin Crimp that opened at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, with nasty appropriateness, on Election Day.

title: INLAND STEEL FILES TO SELL 4 MILLION SHARES
description: Inland Steel Industries filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell four million shares of stock as part of its plan to reduce debt. Based on the company's recent share price, Inland would raise $132 million with the offering. The Chicago steelmaker and iron-ore producer said it would sell 3.2 million shares in the United States and 800,000 internationally. Inland's shares fell 87.5 cents, to $32.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ban on Pregnant Cheerleaders Lifted
description: Facing the threat of a lawsuit by the National Organization for Women, school officials in a small Texas town where four of 15 cheerleaders became pregnant this year said today that they had reversed a decision to bar any pregnant girl from the cheerleader squad.

title: Court Weighs Jury-Selection by Sex
description: After all but eliminating race as a factor in jury selection over the last seven years, the Supreme Court today turned to the question of whether lawyers can remove potential jurors on the basis of their sex.

title: TURNING UP HEAT IN TRADE CAMPAIGN
description: President Clinton placed the reputation of his 10-month-old Administration on the line today, declaring that rejection of the North American Free Trade Agreement would be a "profound setback" to United States foreign policy.

title: END MISSILE ALERT, BIG POWERS URGED
description: An unusual coalition of Russian military experts and conservative former Pentagon officials is urging Moscow and Washington to take most of their nuclear missiles off alert.

title: OLD KENT TO ACQUIRE EDGEMARK FINANCIAL FOR $62 MILLION
description: The Old Kent Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire the Edgemark Financial Corporation for $62 million in stock. Edgemark, a Chicago-based bank-holding company with $534 million in assets, operates five banks and eight offices in Chicago and its suburbs. Old Kent, of Grand Rapids, Mich., has $9.5 billion in assets and owns 18 banks in Michigan and Illinois. Edgemark's shares soared $9.25 yesterday, to $33, in Nasdaq trading, while Old Kent's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $33.

title: WKCR's Annual Music Fair
description: New and used records, compact disks, cassettes, videos and books on music are to be sold on Saturday at the annual fair sponsored by WKCR, the Columbia University radio station. The fair is to be held from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. in Wollman Auditorium of the university's Ferris Booth Hall, at 115th Street and Broadway, Morningside Heights. Admission is $3; proceeds will go to the station.

title: The Young Prove Mortal Again
description: Every generation faces moments when the myth of its own immortality is shattered. Somebody young and beautiful dies, somebody who, like them, was going to live forever.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Legislature; Republicans Keep Their Control of the Senate and Assembly for Life Under Whitman
description: Republicans lost a handful of seats in both houses of the Legislature today but preserved strong working majorities for their party's new Governor, Christine Todd Whitman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS He's No. 2 and Will Have to Try Harder Jim Courier, ranked second in the world and seeded second in the Paris Open to Pete Sampras, bowed out in the second round yesterday when Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden beat him 6-4, 6-3 in 81 minutes. For Courier, who had a bye in the first round, it was only the third time in 22 tournaments that he lost in his opening match. Three-time champion Boris Becker survived a third-set tie breaker to beat Andrei Olhovsky of Russia, 6-7 (6-8), 6-2, 7-6 (7-5). In another second round match and Ivan Lendl was eliminated by David Wheaton, 6-3, 7-5, in a first-round match, marking the 10th time in 25 tournaments this year that Lendl was beaten in his opening round. (AP)

title: Eating Well
description: ANYONE who has experienced the symptoms of pregnancy that are commonly referred to as "morning sickness" is unlikely ever to forget it. Unrelenting nausea casts a pall over every waking hour. Vomiting occurs with little or no warning, and the accompanying gastrointestinal distress can range from constipation to diarrhea.

title: Comeback For Wines Of Austria
description: EIGHT years after a ruinous poisoned-wine scandal, Austrian wines have regained a toehold in America. Importers and retailers say that sales are still spotty, but slowly growing.

title: Telling of Hurled Bucket, Man Reflects on Tragedy
description: Inside the visiting room of a New York City jail, Pedro Gil reflected on how he ruined his own life by ending another's during a night of violence in Washington Heights. Then he broke down and cried.

title: For Tiny British Suspects, Fidgets and Tears
description: They are children, two pudgy 11-year-old boys in neat haircuts, ties and starchy white shirts, the sort of outfits grown-ups think will make a good impression on strangers. Were they not all dressed up to stand trial for murder, they would have been in school today in Liverpool.

title: New Rival Attacks Bell Atlantic as Obstructionist
description: From the moment the Bell Atlantic Corporation announced its $33 billion pact to buy the nation's biggest cable television company, Bell Atlantic officials have argued that the combined entity will bring new competition to local telephone and cable companies around the country.

description: In a day that was part victory lap, part promise and part thank you, Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday frenetically traversed all five boroughs of New York as its newly elected mayor, sharing a message of conciliation and hope.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 26 about the demise of the superconducting supercollider project misspelled the name of the Treasury Secretary. He is Lloyd Bentsen.

title: Essay; 7 More in '94
description: To Tip O'Neill's dictum, "all politics is local," let me append Safire's Corollary: all local politics is now national.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN GETS APPROVAL FOR BRANCH IN MOSCOW
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had received approval from the Russian Government to open a branch in Moscow. The bank has had a representative office in Moscow for 20 years. Tom Swayne, Europe area executive for Chase, said the Moscow branch would focus on existing business with affluent Russians, facilitating cross-border payments and project financing. "We have the capability to bring investors into Russia," he said. Rival Citicorp said earlier this week that it had received approval to open a Moscow branch and plans to open one in St. Petersburg.

title: The sale of Scali may finally be announced today, but Madison Avenue is not holding its breath.
description: YOGI BERRA never worked at an advertising agency. But when he declared that it ain't over till it's over, he must have foreseen the on-again, off-again, not-quite-on-again sale of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: WHITMAN SAYS SHE'S READY TO WORK Christine Todd Whitman, only hours after claiming a narrow victory over Gov. Jim Florio, said she would get to work immediately to redeem a major campaign pledge: cutting income taxes for most residents. A1. The Republicans who lead the New Jersey Legislature begin distancing themselves from Whitman's plan to cut taxes by 30 percent. B7.

Celebrating the Many Lives of Linen
description: AT "Linen," an exhibit at the museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, the ancient fabric is wrapped around a mummified cat, swathed as canopies and pleated into gossamer dresses. It is used as theatrical scrim, to make fire hoses (the wetter it gets, the tighter the weave becomes) and towels (the fiber leaves no lint). The 8,000-year-old fabric, not surprisingly, is being celebrated for its versatility.

The Vote For Mayor and Comptroller by Assembly District
Garden Hose Is a Lifeline For a House
description: I first heard about the wildfires in the Santa Monica Mountains about 11:30 A.M. on Tuesday. By the time I drove from my office toward my home in Topanga Canyon in the fire zone, the smoke and flames had spread and the sun glowed blood-red. I left my car at the bottom of our dead-end road and raced up the last half-mile by foot, determined to save my house.

title: Yes, You Can Go Home Again, Especially If You're Buying It
description: MARRIED six months and already tired of apartment living, Mary Ann Hughes and her husband, Stanley, decided to look for houses in Utica, N.Y., where they both worked at a psychiatric hospital. But when a three-bedroom house in Poland, N.Y., about 15 miles northeast of Utica, came on the market, Mrs. Hughes said they "jumped for it."

title: Giants' Appraisal of Dallas: 'Definitely Beatable'
description: There may be ots of talk around the league that the Dallas Cowboys could win the rest of their games, but don't mention any of it to the Giants. They'll have no part it. They respect the Cowboys, but they are not in awe of them. The Giants even seem to be a little cocky, if you go by some of the comments they made today. And they drew a critical response from Dallas Coach Jimmy Johnson as the two teams turned up the volume in anticipation of their meeting Sunday in Texas.

title: Chinese Issuing What May Be Deng's Final Book
description: China's top Communist Party officials appeared to be preparing for the death of their paramount leader this week by issuing what is likely to be the final volume of Deng Xiaoping's private speeches. The book includes blunt comments about his role in ordering the Tiananmen Square crackdown and his fear that democracy in China could ignite civil war.

title: Theodore Nathan, 82, Executive and Writer
description: Theodore Reade Nathan, a retired New York hotel and advertising executive, died on Monday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Warriors' Webber to Sit Out Two Games
description: Golden State's CHRIS WEBBER, the top pick in the National Basketball Association draft, will probably miss the first two games of the season because of a sprained ankle, the team said yesterday. Webber, who sprained his ankle at practice Monday night, is listed as doubtful for tomorrow's opener at San Antonio and Saturday's game at Dallas.

title: Towns Use Tax Incentives to Lure Companies
description: Years ago this affluent suburb of Hartford was able to rely on a low tax rate, good schools and even an unmistakable New England charm to persuade companies to move here.

title: Music Notes
description: Marilyn Horne has established a foundation to subsidize art song recitals by young singers. In 1994, the board of advisers of the Marilyn Horne Foundation will select a singer to be presented in a New York recital in the 1994-95 season. Eventually, Miss Horne said, the foundation's award winners will be presented in concerts elsewhere in the United States as well.

title: Review/Dance; Keeping Trisler's Vision Alive
description: The Trisler Danscompany was established in large part to keep Joyce Trisler's vision of dance alive. And that vision -- of dance as energy and craft as much as atmosphere -- was well represented by Trisler's invigorating "Four Temperaments," presented by the company on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. But the honors of the evening went to an artist of a rather different kind, Carmen de Lavallade, whose choreography and performing were a highlight of the enjoyably varied program.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Giuliani; Overcoming Early Negative Image To Pull Ahead in Voters' Perceptions
description: For months, the central dilemma of Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign was how to balance the hard-charging prosecutor's image that made his entire political career possible with the cooler-headed, more statesmanlike approach he wanted to project as a potential mayor of a complex city.

title: Granite to Sell Shares
description: The Granite Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell 1.32 million preferred shares at $25 each to help pay for two televisin stations it is buying. The $33 million in proceeds from the stock sale will be used along with bank borrowings to pay for the company's acquisition of two television stations from the Meredith Corporation, announced in June. Granite is paying Meredith $32 million, plus tax considerations. Granite, which was formed in 1988 to buy and manage TV stations, now operates four stations. It is buying WTVH, a CBS affiliate in Syracuse, and KSEE, an NBC affiliate serving Fresno-Visalia, Calif., from Meredith.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: New York City Roundup; Secession in Jeopardy?
description: When Staten Island residents went to the polls on Tuesday, the vast majority voted for two things: to elect Rudolph W. Giuliani the mayor and to secede from New York City. But in doing the first, they may have paradoxically subverted their chances of accomplishing the second.

title: Judge Clears Tighter Auto Emissions
description: A Federal judge in Boston ruled late Tuesday that Massachusetts can adopt California's auto emissions standards, despite arguments by the auto makers that this violates the Clean Air Act.

title: Review/Circus; Commedia dell'Arte in the Little Big Top
description: Strong-jawed, stalwart, sleek of body, the trapeze artist stands at the center of the single ring, bathed in light that gleams against his royal-blue singlet and tights and his golden cape. Overhead, beyond reach, hangs the crossbar of his trapeze, the perilous perch for his coming display of daring.

description: Despite Rudolph W. Giuliani's victory as a Republican-Liberal candidate in the Mayor's race, the vast majority of Democratic incumbents easily waltzed back into office in City Council elections on Tuesday.

title: Three Dubious Political Fixes
description: Exit polls and anecdotal evidence suggest that voters in and around New York City agonized over their choices of candidates yesterday. Which makes it all the more perplexing that these very same voters flocked to simplistic ballot proposals masquerading as cure-alls for America's political ills.

title: Public & Private; Like It Was
description: Covering the first Koch administration was as easy as covering the circus: if you can't get a story out of all those acrobats, high-wire acts and clowns, you might as well pack up your notebook and go into arbitrage.

title: MICHELIN AND UNION TO MEET ON PLANT OPERATIONS
description: Michelin, the French tire maker, will meet today with representatives of the United Rubber Workers union about the possible closing of its Uniroyal Goodrich plant in Fort Wayne, Ind., a company executive said. The plant, which employs 2,050 workers, could be closed unless the union accepted around-the-clock operations seven days a week and work rule changes, Michelin executives said.

title: QVC Is Said to Be in Talks With BellSouth About Bid
description: QVC Network Inc. and the BellSouth Corporation were meeting yesterday to discuss a possible investment by BellSouth in QVC's hostile $9.6 billion bid for Paramount Communications, according to one executive with knowledge of the discussions.
