title: Fire Diverted From Los Angeles After It Ravages the Malibu Area
description: One of the largest firefighting efforts ever undertaken in California succeeded early today in saving thickly populated areas of Los Angeles from a stubborn wildfire, but not before more than 200 homes and 35,000 acres were destroyed in the wealthy beachside enclave of Malibu and nearby canyons.

title: Review/Music; Albanians Find Unity in Diversity
description: The third annual Albanian Festival, which took place on Sunday at Lehman College in the Bronx, was a three-hour variety show, with about 30 acts: dancers, singers, instrumental virtuosos, even a comedian and a poet. It veered between traditional and modern styles and from professional to amateur performances. And it portrayed an extremely diverse musical culture, even as singers drew fervent applause when they invoked Albanian unity. There are Albanian communities in the former Yugoslavia, in Greece and even in Italy; one dance from the Arberesh community in Italy suggested a Balkan tarantella.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Victory
description: The insults flew until the the polls closed, but when the the vote was in, Mayor David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani put aside the bitterness that marked their campaign and behaved with a decency and civility that made New Yorkers proud of both men.

title: House Breaks Impasse on Crime, Passing Limited Measures
description: After two years in which sweeping anticrime legislation has been stalled in Congress, the House of Representatives today approved a series of narrower and less divisive measures that would help state and local governments fight crime with 50,000 new police officers, treatment of drug-abusing prisoners and recreational activities for members of youth gangs.

title: SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nature Has Created a Tinderbox, But Humans Are Striking the Flint
description: Arson is now suspected in nearly half the major fires that have raced across Southern California in the past eight days, prompting much public hand-wringing about whether the police could have deterred the crimes and about the mentality of whoever would set the blazes.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Propositions; Ballot Measures on Term Limits and Crime Draw Wide Support
description: Voters across the country continued to show strong support for term limits, a tougher than ever stand on crime and opposition to gay rights, while indicating they would pay higher taxes if the revenue was used for health care or education.

title: MEM Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grand Casinos (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The company said the current quarterly results included a write-off of 2 cents a share for the costs associated with the pursuit of gaming sites where the company is no longer active.

title: Prosecutors in Blast Case Identify the Defendants
description: The parade of witnesses included a trooper from Texas, a clerk for a car service in New Jersey, three real-estate rental agents and a gray-haired executive secretary at a chemical manufacturing company yesterday as the prosecution in the World Trade Center case worked to establish the addresses and the identities of most of the defendants.

title: S.E.C. Settles Insider Suit
description: Martin Revson, co-founder of the cosmetics company Revlon Inc., has agreed to pay $1.6 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission insider-trading lawsuit, the S.E.C. said today.

title: Global Natural Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net gains on property transactions of $ 1.8 million and a $ 1.3 million liquidating distribution from Investment Properties International.c-Net lossd-Included property transaction gains of $ 1.1 million.

title: Marseilles President Is Expected to Resign
description: BERNARD TAPIE, the embattled president of scandal-plagued Olympique Marseilles, is expected to resign by next week, the French League president, NOEL Le GRAET, said in an interview published yesterday in Toulouse, France. Tapie will probably resign by next Tuesday, Le Graet told the newspaper La Depeche du Midi.

title: Getty Museum's Brush With Disaster Recalls Fate of Its Ancient Model
description: Shortly before dawn this morning, with scorching cinders in the air and the dark sky aflame over the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, John Walsh faced a moment of alarm.

title: A Sad Exit in Jerusalem
description: As Mayor of Jerusalem for 28 years, Teddy Kollek has presided memorably as the blunt-spoken but equitable magistrate of a fractious city. In his prime, he would begin at dawn by walking through Jerusalem, paying its diverse inhabitants the courtesy of listening. Parks and museums filled what had been battlegrounds; a once-divided city was united by efficient municipal services. Even more impressive was the grudging respect accorded Mr. Kollek by the resentful Arab third of Jerusalem's 550,000 inhabitants.

title: JERUSALEM VICTOR REASSURES CRITICS
description: On his first day as Jerusalem's Mayor-elect, Ehud Olmert found himself deflecting worries today that his stunning victory over the long-governing Teddy Kollek would increase tensions between Arabs and Jews and between Orthodox and secular Jews in a city of easily frayed nerves.

title: A Model of Consistency, Maddux Gets His 2d Young
description: Greg Maddux changed teams this year, but not much else changed. Maddux, in fact, displayed remarkable consistency. He was a 20-game winner for the second successive season, he led the National League in innings pitched for the third straight year and today he won the league's Cy Young award for the second straight time.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: City Hall; Sea of Democrats Awaits Republican Mayor-Elect
description: For months Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared on the steps of City Hall as he campaigned for mayor. Yesterday, the day after he was elected, he finally got to go inside, and the Republican-Liberal discovered that it was full of Democrats.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sampras Advances Easily Top-ranked Pete Sampras expects a tougher match from Marc Rosset than he had while advancing to the third round of the Paris Open with a 6-4, 6-2 victory yesterday over a fellow American, David Wheaton. Wheaton had two double faults in the first game of the second set to give Sampras a 1-0 lead. Sampras breezed from there. He has clinched the No. 1 spot heading into the ATP Tour world championships finals starting Nov. 16 in Frankfurt. Jim Courier, trailing Sampras in the rankings, lost to Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, 6-4, 6-3, late Tuesday night. Among other winners yesterday was ninth-seeded Goran Ivanisevic of Croatia, who held off a match point in the third set to advance over Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-3). Ivanisevic's next opponent, Michael Chang, seeded seventh, beat a countryman, MaliVai Washington, 6-7 (1-7), 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Davenport Rallies: Fourth-seeded Lindsay Davenport was shut out in a first-set tie breaker but came back to defeat Ginger Helgeson yesterday in the Bank of the West Classic in Oakland, Calif. Davenport, 17, triumphed by 6-7 (0-7), 6-2, 6-3. In another second-round match, Iva Majoli of Croatia, seeded eighth, set herself up for a quarterfinal meeting with top-seed Martina Navratilova with a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Amy Frazier. Navratilova was taken into a second-set tie breaker Tuesday night before outlasting Marianne Werdel, 6-4, 7-6 (8-6). (AP)

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Reaction; Black Leaders Look Hard At Creating a New Party
description: A day after the defeat of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a Democratic mayor in a Democratic town, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and several black elected officials said yesterday that they are exploring with renewed vigor the possibility of starting a new party under the banner of Mr. Jackson's Rainbow Coaliion.

title: In the Village, Dedicated to the Holidays
description: HUDSON STREET HOLIDAYS, a store that sells only holiday tree ornaments, candles, wrapping papers and ribbons, is an ephemeral place. It opened last week at 555 Hudson Street (Perry Street) in Greenwich Village, and will close Dec. 31.

title: They Who Do (Sit) or Even Teach (Sit!)
description: STROLLING a country lane with a beautiful dog in tow might not sound like work. But to Joan Edwards, the owner of Executive Pet Sitting in Centerbrook, Conn., the morning constitutional is part of a daily job that also calls for feeding the dog, an Akita, a hot lunch of chopped sirloin and rice.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Suburbs; Region's Incumbents Are Shaken Winners
description: While incumbents were toppling almost everywhere, the Republican leaders of Nassau and Suffolk Counties managed to survive election night in one piece, but they suffered a fright they will not soon forget.

title: Dinkins Is Out, but U.S.T.A. Isn't Done
description: Officials of the United States Tennis Association said yesterday that they do not expect the departure of Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS, a tennis fan and a yearly fixture at the United States Open, to affect the planned $180 million expansion of the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. The project could be completed by the 1996 Open if construction begins on target next March. City Council approved it on Sept. 23, but the U.S.T.A. still has no signed lease with the city for use of the parkland.

title: Sports of The Times; Shula's Backup QB Success
description: AS soon as Don Shula saw Dan Marino hobbling toward him on the sideline, the Dolphin coach turned to Scott Mitchell. "Get warmed up," Shula barked. "You're going in."

title: Inbrand Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: The company said the increase in shares reflects a public offering of 2.1 million shares on Sept. 3.First-quarter pro-forma figures, assuming the additional shares had been outstanding during each period, were 22 cents a share, compared with 16 cents a year ago.

title: Dublin Journal; Nemesis of I.R.A., and No Friend to Protestants
description: In his hometown of Londonderry, there is an old joke about John Hume, the most respected and influential Roman Catholic leader in Northern Ireland: What is the difference between John Hume and God? The answer: "God doesn't think he's John Hume."

title: 'Jack London, Hemingway and the Constitution'
description: The unusual combination of subjects that the novelist E. L. Doctorow treats in this arresting collection of essays is apparent in its title, "Jack London, Hemingway and the Constitution."

title:
HORSE RACING;
Breeders' Cup Crowded With Previous Winners
description: Six previous winners, including Lure, the defending Mile champion, joined Horse of the Year candidates Bertrando and Best Pal when 82 horses were entered today for the seven races that make up Saturday's 10th Breeders' Cup at Santa Anita.

title: 'Undecideds' Decided for Whitman
description: New Jersey's voters remained true on Tuesday to their reputation as an independent and volatile electorate by moving in the last weeks away from an incumbent Governor campaigning as a front-runner and handing a come-from-behind victory to Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Arrhythmia Research Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RS Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: The Grand Ballroom of the Plaza may well have been one of the few places in town on Tuesday night where people were not talking about the election, not glued to television screens, awaiting the returns.

title: Moynihan Asks Big Tax Increase On Ammunition
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that he would insist that President Clinton's health-care plan include a huge increase in Federal taxes on handgun ammunition that would make some especially destructive bullets unaffordable.

title: Review/Rock; Altered States of Sound
description: For music as obscure and cloudy as David Sylvian and Robert Fripp played at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night, its presentation was surprisingly straightforward. Everything about the music suggested otherworldly experiences, dream states.

description: In a collision between clean air in New York and foreign policy in Latin America, the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington is considering a request to let Venezuela ship gasoline to the Northeast that contains more of a smog-producing chemical than American refiners will be allowed to market.

title: Economic Scene; However the N.F.L. handles expansion, challenges are likely.
description: Oct. 22. A jury in Boston decides that the National Football League had violated the antitrust laws by restricting William Sullivan's sale of a minority interest in the New England Patriots.

title: HEICO TO COMPLETE NUTRI-SYSTEM PURCHASE
description: Heico Acquisitions Inc. said yesterday that it expected to buy Nutri-System Inc., the bankrupt chain of weight-loss clinics, within days after Regal Communication Inc. ended its rival bid.

title: Knicks Give Students Reasons to Believe
description: Doc Rivers, the starting point guard, delivered a big assist yesterday at Wadleigh High School in West Harlem, where he and his teammates Patrick Ewing, David Cain and Herb Williams stressed to almost 300 students the importance of staying in school, staying off drugs and believing in their dreams.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: MUCH of childhood is marked by experimentation, including the search for altered states of consciousness. A 5-year-old spins until dizzy. An 8-year-old sits transfixed in front of a video game. By the time they reach early adolescence, that normal experimentation can take a dangerous turn.

description: Arts and Crafts American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535.

Shifting Back to Communist Era, Ukraine Bars Hard Currency Sale
description: President Leonid M. Kravchuk decreed strict currency controls today, shutting down the Kiev Interbank Currency Exchange auction and other money exchange points throughout the country.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Voices; For Blacks, Loss by Dinkins Undermines Hopes of Change
description: The defeat of David N. Dinkins, the first black mayor of the nation's largest city, triggered painful soul searching yesterday among black supporters who saw it as a revealing commentary on the state of race relations in New York. Many predicted that Mr. Dinkins's loss will translate into a tougher, smarter battle for the empowerment of people of color in New York, where whites, despite being in the minority, now hold all three citywide elective offices.

title: U.S. DELAY URGED ON KOREA SANCTION
description: Japan and South Korea have urged Defense Secretary Les Aspin to avoid imposing sanctions against North Korea as long as possible, warning that action to force the North to open its nuclear sites to inspection could touch off terrorist campaigns or military attack if the North's Government feels cornered.

title: A Quarterback Understudy To Entertain Off Off Broadway
description: The Jets are 0-2 against backup quarterbacks this season, so they're in no position to take Miami's Scott Mitchell for granted. Not that they would anyway, considering that Mitchell has been doing a pretty good impression of Dan Marino for the last three weeks.

title: Panel Examining Death of Officer Faces Delays
description: A grand jury decision was delayed again yesterday in the case of the man who threw a bucket off a Washington Heights roof and killed a police officer, as a judge dismissed a defense complaint about a court interpreter.

title: Ithaca Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossIthaca Bancorp said that in the latest third quarter, the bank had gains of $ 987,000 on the sale of prepayment-sensitive mortgage-backed securities. In addition, Ithaca said the bank had a $ 980,000 write-down against purchased mortgage servicing rights.

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: NEARLY everyone has a favorite neighborhood shoe-repair shop for simple tasks like getting lifts replaced or shoes resoled. But occasionally, nearly everyone needs more elaborate work, like having pumps dyed to match bridesmaids' dresses or loafers altered to make the wearer taller.

title: Datapoint Names a Returnee Its President
description: The Datapoint Corporation today named Doris D. Bencsik, a 35-year veteran of the computer industry, its president and chief operating officer.

description: A jury began deliberating today in the case of a woman who first confessed to the murder of her track-star daughter and then recanted.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Loud? Flamboyant? It's Oldham's Way
description: GETTING into a Todd Oldham show is as frenetic as getting into a rock concert. Before Tuesday night's spring show in Bryant Park, the line of ticket holders stretched nearly to Fifth Avenue, and the line of ticketless hopefuls went all the way to the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Sales for Brooks Brothers Jump 10% in 6-Month Period
description: Marks & Spencer, the crack British retailer, reported its half-year results yesterday, showing solid improvements at its Brooks Brothers subsidiary, where sales climbed 10 percent, to $169.5 million.

title: Mrs. Whitman's Work Won't Be Easy
description: There are campaign promises that are easily forgotten and campaign promises writ large, like Christine Todd Whitman's pledge to cut the income tax 30 percent if New Jersey voters elected her Governor. Well, they did. And now concerned residents can only hope her moderate political heritage will guide her spending cuts, to protect the state's troubled cities and their poor against uncaring budget-slashers from Republican suburbs.

title: A. Louis Carafiello; Ad Agency President, 64
description: A. Louis Carrafiello, president of Carrafiello Diehl & Associates, an advertising agency in Irvington, N.Y., died on Monday at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 64 and lived in Ossining.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: News Analysis; The Tide Turns on Voter Turnout
description: For all the predictions of epochal changes that Rudolph W. Giuliani's election will mean at City Hall, his historic victory resulted much less from an overwhelming change in voters' attitudes and more from tiny shifts in the voting blocs that he and David N. Dinkins assembled in 1989.

title: Surging Rangers Give Vancouver an Unexpected Detour
description: Mike Richter knows that a big trade can often bring a team a rush of adrenaline, an influx of enthusiasm that carries over onto the ice.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: An Electorate in Revolt; Voting Nationwide Was Less an Embrace Of G.O.P. Than a Warning to Incumbents
description: The three major Republican victories on Tuesday were less a partisan triumph than a warning that the revolt against established politicians that helped send President Clinton to the White House may imperil incumbents next year and ultimately threaten Mr. Clinton himself.

title: Sports Products Deal For Shaquille O'Neal
description: Shaquille O'Neal, the Orlando Magic basketball star, added another product to his lengthening endorsement roster yesterday, signing an agreement with Score Board Inc. of Cherry Hill, N.J., a marketer and distributor of sports and entertainment products like trading cards and memorabilia. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The athlete's other product agreements include Pepsi-Cola and Reebok.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced for sale to the public $700 million of floating-rate notes due in 1998 through Lehman Brothers. Underwriters said they priced the issue at 100 to float 19 basis points more than the three-month Treasury bill, with the interest rate adjusted after each weekly bill auction. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. The notes are callable in a year.

title: Woody Allen Fails to Beat A Prosecutor
description: A criminal-justice panel in Connecticut voted unanimously yesterday to dismiss a complaint by Woody Allen against a prosecutor who had said there was "probable cause" to believe Mr. Allen had molested his 7-year-old daughter, but then declined to file charges.

title: American Power Conversion Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 24, 1993.

description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $ 462,000 in the quarter and $ 846,000 in the 9 months.c-Included extraordinary income of $ 3,763,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Polls; New Jersey Voting Experts Try to Figure Out Where They Went Wrong
description: Was it a case of enormous changes at the last minute, or were the polls simply wrong?

title: THE 1993 ELECTION: Chronology; Tracking the Race for Mayor Since the Primary
description: Sept. 14: Dinkins easily wins three-way primary against Roy Innis and Eric Ruano-Melendez. Sept. 17: Giuliani proposes drastically curtailing services for some of New York City's homeless, setting a stringent 90-day limit on many shelter stays. Dinkins later accuses him of being heartless and punishing children.

title: Elite Image, Red Ink Disappear
description: Three years ago, the National Horse Show was in the throes of an identity crisis following a cost-effective move from Madison Square Garden to the Meadowlands after a century of renown as one of the most glittering autumn events on the Manhattan social calendar.

title: Gibson Greetings Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and reflected one-time pretax expenses of $ 28.8 million associated with the bankruptcy of Phar-Mor, which was the company's largest customer, and restructuring costs in both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a charge of $ 1,449,000 from an accounting adjustment.Gibson Greetings said that increases in revenues for the latest quarter and nine months were generated by certain domestic and international greeting card operations and Paper Factor of Wisconsin Inc., which was acquired July 1.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Suburbs; Narrow Victory in Nassau
description: In Nassau County, both Democrats and Republicans claimed victory after Thomas S. Gulotta was returned to office with the narrowest victory of his 18-year political career.

title: AT WORK WITH: Chief Wilma Mankiller; The Name's the Most and Least of Her
description: When she was 10 years old, says Wilma Pearl Mankiller, the principal chief of the Cherokee Nation, "I set out on what I call my own little Trail of Tears."

description: OVER the years, some pieces of furniture quite literally have had their ups and downs.

title: Review/Film; Behind the Scenes At a Chinese Restaurant
description: "Combination Platter" was shown as part of the 1993 New Directors/ New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 27. The film opened this week.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS

Redeemable in five years, the notes are rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and B- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Dean Witter, Discover & Co. is selling $250 million of 6 1/2 percent notes due in 2005 at 100 through Dean Witter Reynolds. The noncallable notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.& P. and yield about 87 basis points more than a Treasury security with a comparable maturity.

description: Right wing ALEKSANDR MOGILNY, who shared last season's N.H.L. goal-scoring title with TEEMU SELANNE of Winnipeg, signed a multiyear contract with the Buffalo Sabres, the team announced yesterday. Terms were not disclosed, but the contract reportedly will pay an average base salary of $2.7 million for the next four years.

title: Benefit for Bosnian Writers
description: "An Evening for Sarajevo: A Benefit for Bosnian Writers," a public reading presented by the PEN American Center on Nov. 30, is to feature Joseph Brodsky, Mary Gordon, Jamaica Kincaid, Tony Kushner, Arthur Miller, Susan Sontag, Derek Walcott, Wendy Wasserstein and several other writers. A special guest at the reading, to be held at 7:30 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, will be Zlatko Dizdarevic, a writer from Sarajevo. The trumpet player Wynton Marsalis has composed a work for the occasion. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 864-5400.

title: Au Bon Pain Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: Au Bon Pain said that third quarter results included Warburton's bakery cafes which were acquired in July 1992.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: New York City Roundup; Vallone Says Term Limits Issue Is 'Not Dead'
description: A day after New Yorkers voted to impose term limits on the city's elected officials, the Speaker of the City Council said the issue was "not dead," suggesting that he and other opponents of the limits might press for another referendum or challenge the limits in court.

title: MNX Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2

The company said these items increased net income per share in the latest quarter by 27 cents.

title: T.W.A. EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. officially emerged yesterday from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The airline is now owned by its employees and creditors and is operating under airline industry veterans, headed by the former chairman of Piedmont Airlines, William Howard.

description: b-Net loss

title: Envoy in Somalia Voices Both Hope and Fear
description: At the end of a three-day visit in which he tried to restart political negotiations in the Somali capital, Robert B. Oakley, the United States special envoy here, said he was "moderately encouraged for the near term." But he also warned that the ultimate responsibility for peace lay with the Somalis and that the consequences would be "monstrous" if they did not cooperate.

description: The New Jersey Devils continued to cool tonight, losing for the third time in four games due to a roadblock by Kings' goalie Kelly Hrudey.

title: Egypt Hangs Three Muslims In a Crackdown on Militants
description: Three Muslim militants were hanged in a Cairo prison today for conspiring to overthrow the Government, the military prosecutor's office said.

title: Bomb Figure May Testify, Lawyers Infer
description: A bombing case defendant charged with plotting to kill President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was abruptly moved out of his jail quarters on Monday amid signs that he has agreed to become a witness for the Government against Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and other former co-defendants, defense lawyers said last night.

title: Relatively Few Taxpayers Are Jolted by the Nanny Scandal
description: THE Zoe Baird nanny scandal was expected to teach American taxpayers, be they rich or middle class, a lesson: you can't get away with employing illegal immigrants or failing to pay Social Security and Medicare taxes for legal domestic workers. Come clean or pay the price.

title: Nets to Open With Options, Not Answers
description: Expect Dwayne Schintzius, who totaled 142 minutes of playing time for the 1992-93 season, to have some difficulty opening the regular season as the Nets' starting center. He will be opposing Hakeem Olajuwon of the Rockets on Friday in Houston and David Robinson of the Spurs on Sunday in San Antonio. So Coach Chuck Daly has been carefully considering his options.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Mayoral Elections; Results Hint at Secondary Role for Race
description: Six weeks after President Clinton, campaigning in New York, described some opponents of Mayor David N. Dinkins as unwilling to vote for "people who are different than we are," a notable feature of mayoral elections around the country was how secondary a role race and ethnicity played.

title: Northern Telecom Joins Data Network Plan
description: Northern Telecom Inc. has joined an alliance of I.B.M., MCI Communications and nine universities in developing technology to improve the performance of the national data highway.

description: Burr-Brown said that a large part of its 1992 sales included military products, which the company has since discontinued.

description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell the appliance division of its Clairol subsidiary to the Remington Products Company.

title: McGeehan Ready to Lead Quakers Against the Tigers
description: A crowd of some 40,000 is expected to turn out for the game between Penn and Princeton, both unbeaten, at Franklin Field in Philadelphia on Saturday. Many more will be there to watch the Tigers' star running back, Keith Elias, than Penn's quarterback, Jimmy McGeehan.

For its latest 9 months, Reliance reported gains of $ 113 million, compared with $ 37.1 million, in the year-ago period.

title: Stocks Plunge In Japan
description: Stock prices fell sharply here today, on selloffs in afternoon trading triggered by poor corporate half-year earnings, traders said. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 431.45 points, or 2.23 percent, to 18,949.79.

title: CHRONICLE
description: This could be called a banner week for TONY CURTIS. Today, he will be the guest of honor at a party in SoHo given by Ambassador Galleries, which is exhibiting his art. On Tuesday, William Morrow published his book "Tony Curtis: The Autobiography." And on Sunday, he is scheduled to speak at the 92d Street Y.

title: HAITIAN TALKS END ON A HOPEFUL NOTE
description: A group of diplomats, Haitian lawmakers and Government officials met today and said afterward they were optimistic that they could salvage a United Nations-sponsored agreement that called for the return of the nation's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHASE SECURITIES INC., New York, a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan Corp., named Barry Berkeley managing director of its new mortgage-backed securities unit. INTERNATIONAL SPECIALTY PRODUCTS INC., Wayne, N.J., named Richard B. Olsen senior vice president and chief financial officer. The chemical maker also appointed James P. Rogers senior vice president for finance.

title: Russia Drops Pledge of No First Use of Atom Arms
description: The Russian Defense Ministry confirmed today that the Russian military doctrine adopted on Tuesday abandoned the old Soviet pledge not to use nuclear weapons first.

title: Article 087393 -- No Title
description: Steadily, the market for Impressionist and modern art is crawling back to life. But as Sotheby's sale last night showed, the climb is slow and at times downright tedious.

title: Many Tiny Ripples Create a Sea Change
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani's victory resulted less from seismic changes in voters' attitudes than from tiny shifts in the voting blocs that he and Mayor David N. Dinkins assembled four years ago, the first time they ran against each other.

THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Governor; Whitman Triumphantly Pledges Income-Tax Cut by 1994 Budget
description: Christine Todd Whitman made a triumphant entry into the State House today only hours after claiming a narrow victory over Gov. Jim Florio. Appearing before a crowd of legislative leaders and cheering supporters, she said she would get to work immediately to redeem a major campaign pledge: cutting income taxes for most residents, beginning with the 1994 budget.

title: Reviews/Fashion; A First Look at Lauren as Just Plain Ralph
description: RALPH LAUREN was not quite sure how he should introduce his secondary collection of casual clothes, called Ralph. His competitors Donna Karan and Calvin Klein had staged separate fashion shows for their similar collections.

title: E. Dwight Salmon, 98, A Professor at Amherst
description: Prof. E. Dwight Salmon, who taught history at Amherst College for 37 years until he retired in 1963, died on Sunday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Oak Bluffs, Mass. He was 98 and lived in nearby Chilmark on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Missing Cabdriver Found Slain, The 36th Such Victim This Year
description: A taxidriver reported missing three days ago was found dead yesterday, slumped in the front seat of his yellow cab on a Bronx street with a single gunshot to the back of his head, the police said.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Dinkins; Mayor Is Gracious in Defeat as He Calls for New Yorkers to 'Move Forward'
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins continued his virtuoso lesson in loser's politesse yesterday, beaming graciously on the steps of City Hall at the man who defeated him and cherishing the durability of the city and its people.

title: Scholastic
description: Shares of the Scholastic Corporation, the publisher and distributor of children's books and magazines, dropped sharply yesterday after the New York-based company said that its revenue growth was slowing. An analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company later downgraded the stock to "underperformer" from "performer."

title: Cortines Plan Gives Districts Repair Power
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines yesterday said that he would reorganize the way the New York City's Board of Education handles minor repairs of its school buildings, turning decisions about what gets fixed and when over to local school districts.

title: Mets and the Indians: Talks but No Trade
description: Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' general manager, wasn't getting anywhere in hotel rooms, so he figured he would try the golf course. McIlvaine and his assistant, Ed Lynch, played 18 holes today with John Hart, the Cleveland Indians' general manager, but the best they could do was keep their scores in the 80's.

title: Officials Watch Clock on Strike Deadline
description: The National Hockey League offered its on-ice officials a 10 percent pay increase yesterday and then left the bargaining table to study a counterproposal. The league's response is expected today, less than two weeks before the Nov. 15 strike deadline.

title: Islanders Shake Up Roster
description: Stung by a 3-8-1 start and worried about empty seats at the Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders shook up their roster yesterday, leaving two healthy regulars at home and calling up three minor leaguers before they traveled to Chicago for tonight's game with the Blackhawks.

title: Times to Offer Resume Service
description: The New York Times Company announced this week that it would offer a new interactive system for employers to advertise jobs and for prospective employees to send resumes.

title: Review/Theater: The Lights; Crime, Drugs, Trash, the Homeless: Urban Reality at Its Grimmest
description: The bleak urbanscape that brought New York City a new Mayor this week can be found live onstage at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Howard Korder's play "The Lights" is set in an unnamed "large city" of "the modern era" that would have been right at home in Rudolph Giuliani's campaign commercials. Crime, drugs and garbage are rampant. The homeless are always underfoot. Civic corruption is ubiquitous. The good old immigrant values that once built the town are in rout.

title: Larmer Knows Keenan's Method
description: Steve Larmer was a smoker when Mike Keenan took over as the head coach of the Chicago Blackhawks in June of 1988. He had heard about Keenan's tough-guy reputation, his disciplined practices and emphasis on physical fitness. What Larmer quickly learned, though, is that Keenan is uncompromising when it comes to some off-ice behavior, particularly the smoking of cigarettes.

description: Pepsico Wines and Spirits International and Monsieur Henri Wines said yesterday that they had narrowed the review on four major liquor brands to four agencies from eight semifinalists, eliminating Calet, Hirsch & Ferrell of New York, which had handled the account for more than a decade.

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: New Jersey Legislature; Cut Taxes 30 Percent? Whitman's Top Statehouse Allies Say Not So Fast
description: Within an hour of hearing Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman repeat her pledge to reduce the New Jersey income tax by 30 percent over the next three years, the leaders of the State Legislature began distancing themselves from their fellow Republican's plan.

description: Despite the opposition of Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines, the New York City Board of Education voted yesterday to move a community garden onto the schoolyard of Louis D. Brandeis High School to make room for a 35-unit public housing project.

title: Pachinko: A Game Or an Obsession?
description: PACHINKO is a pinball machine, complete with flashing lights and beeps, but made vertical and small ( 3 feet high by 20 inches wide). In Japan, where the game has been played for prizes in commercial parlors since the 1940's, half of the adult population has played pachinko, according to the Japanese Cultural Exchange, a New York nonprofit organization.

title: Capitol Hill Memo; Ascendancy of Scandal To High Political Drama
description: Of the many extraordinary aspects of Senator Bob Packwood's two-day, nationally broadcast struggle to limit a humiliating investigation of his conduct in office, this one stands out: In the modern Congress, such spectacular bloodlettings are no longer extraordinary.

title: Ecuadorean Indians Suing Texaco
description: Maria Sanchez, who lives in the rain forest of Ecuador, said she cannot bathe in the river and lagoons near her house. She and her son are reluctant to walk on the road because oil stains her feet and clothing, she said tearfully at a news conference yesterday in New York, and she is also allergic to the gasoline used to clean off the oil.

title: Medisys Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: "Yesterday our city's votes may have been divided. But today our city will be reunited. I expect nothing less and hope for even more." -- DAVID N. DINKINS. [ B3:1. ]

title: Reviews/Fashion; Color It With Silver and Spice
description: MINIMALISM'S onetime wallflowers are standing out from the pale plaster. Who could fade into the background wearing silver go-go boots like those at Ghost, or the shimmery, shiny cognac-colored skirts at Liza Bruce? Antifashion, even when accompanied by music bemoaning a world of drug addiction, garbage and blood on car seats, is looking mighty fashionable these days.

title: If Trade Pact Fails, Doubt On Japan Role in Mexico
description: Contradicting what has become a central argument for the North American Free Trade Agreement, businessmen, diplomats and trade experts say Japan and Europe are unlikely to flood Mexico with new investment and trade if the pact is not approved.

title: Burlington Industries Equity Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After an extraordinary net charge of $ 34,103,000, which included charge of $ 29.2 million chiefly related to a write-off of unamortized financing costs of the 1992 recapitalization plan, and charge of $ 4.9 million related to use of net operating loss carryforwards in the quarter, and the 9 months included an extraordinary gain of $ 7,969,000, or 12 cents a share, which included charge of $ 29.4 million for early extinguishment of debt and gain of $ 37.4 million related to net operating loss carryforwards, and the 9 months also included a charge of $ 4,482,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net income and after an extraordinary loss from retirement of debt of $ 3,902,000.d-Net loss, which included an extraordinary charge for retirement of debt of $ 93,559,000.Latest quarter and 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 9,040,000, or 13 cents a share, and $ 81,579,000, or $ 1.19 a share, respectively, both included a restructuring provision of $ 11.9 million, which included a charge for the knitted fabrics division and a provision for further costs associated with the restructuring of the carpet division.The company said the previous year's net loss also included a pretax restructuring provision of $ 29.6 million. Share earnings in the previous year follow accrued preferred stock dividiends and accretion of preferred stock.

title: Books of The Times; A Medley of the Literary and Political
description: Jack London, Hemingway and the Constitution Selected Essays, 1977-1992 By E. L. Doctorow 206 pages. Random House. $20.

title: 37 Are Arrested In Document Sales
description: A team of Federal, state and local law-enforcement officials arrested 37 people today, including Federal and state employees, on charges that they sold or conspired to sell fraudulent driver's licenses, Social Security cards, "green" cards, passports and other documents used for personal identification.

title: Bridge
description: Almost 60 years ago, a brilliant group of players, with an average age of about 35, became the first life masters based on their playing performances. They were: David Burnstine (later Bruce); Oswald Jacoby; Howard Schenken; Waldemar von Zedtwitz; P. Hal Sims; B. Jay Becker; Theodore Lightner; Richard Frey; Michael Gottlieb, and Sam Fry Jr. All played much of their bridge in New York City, although Becker was from Philadelphia and Jacoby migrated to Dallas. Most lived to be octogenarians, but all are now dead.

title: Smart & Final Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
description: b-After a charge of $ 12.9 million from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net incomeShare earnings and shares outstanding were restated for 3-for-2 stock split Feb. 5.

title: Packwood Case Shows Women Speaking Up
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Virginia; A G.O.P. Stride Could Pick Up Speed
description: George F. Allen did more than win the Virginia governor's race on Tuesday.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Banc One To Purchase Liberty Bank
description: The Banc One Corporation, continuing as one of the banking industry's most prolific buyers, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Liberty National Bancorp of Louisville, Ky., in a stock swap valued at $842 million.

title: Saga Communications Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 126,000 loss on asset sales.c-Net lossYear-ago periods were after payment of preferred dividends of $ 158,000 in the quarter and $ 408,000 in the 9 months.

title: Celtics Are Not Singing the Blues, Yet
description: All the scars have not healed. The tremendous void has not been filled.

title: Review/Film; Inner Voices, This Time From Dogs
description: Like an over-dressed Christmas tree, "Look Who's Talking Now" is a movie so eager to shine that it arrives draped in several layers of sentimental tinsel and cutesy-pie decorations. The third film in the series that began four years ago with the surprise blockbuster "Look Who's Talking" continues the gimmick of observing an all-American family through the eyes of creatures who don't speak. But in Part 3, the perspective has shifted from the human to the canine. And the sound of stars mouthing the inner thoughts of dogs is somehow funnier than that of grownup actors doing wisecracking voice-overs for gurgling infants.

title: In New Tajikistan, Islam Can Be a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard Decker, 89, Judge Who Upheld Nazi Right to March
description: Bernard Martin Decker, a retired Federal judge in Chicago who upheld an Illinois town's right to ban pistols and a neo-Nazi band's right to march in the suburban village of Skokie, died on Tuesday in a Lake Forest nursing home. A longtime resident of Waukegan, Ill., he was 89.

title: Art in Review
description: Chuck Close Pace Gallery 142 Greene Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through Nov. 27

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 TOKYO AUTO MAKERS PINCHED The yen's rise comes at a bad time for Japanese auto makers, who are seeing car prices pushed up in the United States while sales in Japan are hurting. A1 AIDS ANXIETY GROWS IN EUROPE Charges that a German company distributed AIDS-infected blood to hospitals is spreading anxiety in Germany. The scandal has now erupted in other European countries where hospitals bought blood from the firm. A1

title: Market Place; Just looking for opportunities in beer can kill an investor's gusto.
description: LIGHT beer. Dark beer. Dry beer. Steam beer. Ice beer. Wheat beer. Pilsner. Porter. Stout. When it comes to beer, drinkers have an incredible number of choices. But investors will find far fewer ways to sample the beer market. And right now, none of them seems very attractive.

title: Canyon Resources (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Duff & Phelps Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from loss on early extinguishment of debt of $ 5,932,000.

title: Whitman Names 2 for Staff Of New Governor's Office
description: Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman began shaping her administration today, choosing as her first two staff members a former member of Governor Thomas H. Kean's administration and a prominent young leader in the state Republican Party.

title: No Headline
description: "The only sure thing about luck is that it will change." -- GOV. JIM FLORIO, quoting a fortune cookie that he said he got at lunch yesterday. [ B1:4. ]

title: Franklin B. Lincoln, Aide in Transition Of Nixon, Dies at 85
description: Franklin Benjamin Lincoln Jr., a lawyer who represented President-elect Richard M. Nixon in dealings with the staff of President Lyndon B. Johnson during the transition in 1968, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 85 and lived in Short Hills.

title: Christopher Spells Out New Priorities
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher redefined priorities for America's foreign policy today, but restoring democracy to Haiti, ending the war in Bosnia and reconciling warring parties in Somalia were not on his list.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Even the noblesse are obliged to face a publicity juggernaut when they write a book. Take, for example, VISCOUNT LINLEY, Princess Margaret's furniture-making son, who is about to embark on a grueling tour to promote his new book, "Classical Furniture," which is being published by Harry N. Abrams.

title: Giuliani's Most Trusted Aide Juggles Demands of Success
description: In a cluttered office at the campaign headquarters of Rudolph W. Giuliani, which is now papered with hastily prepared signs reading, "Office of the Mayor-elect," Peter J. Powers reflected on the abrupt transition from campaign manager to builder of a new administration.

title: Key P.L.O. Official Accused of Spying for Israel
description: A key official at the P.L.O.'s Tunis headquarters has been arrested by the Tunisian authorities on charges of spying for Israel, the Palestine Liberation Organization has announced.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR IN TECHNOLOGY DEAL WITH NEC
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a technology partnership agreement with the NEC Corporation of Tokyo aimed at building a market in Japan for Ethernet-based computer networking. Ethernet, developed by the Xerox Corporation, is the dominant technology in the United States for connecting personal computers to networks, but it has been slow to take hold in Japan.

title: American Re Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 17,800,000, or 36 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.c-Net lossd-Included a gain of $ 37,000,000, or 75 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Latest 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 81,400,000, or $ 1.65 a share, included after-tax realized capital gains of $ 1.4 million, or 3 cents a share.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 26,500,000, or 54 cents a share, included after-tax realized capital gains of $ 300,000, or 1 cent a share.American Re said that all figures except the latest third quarter are pro forma. Comparisons to dates and periods prior to Oct. 1, 1992, are pro forma since the company did not purchase American Re-Insurance Co. until Sept. 30, 1992.Pro forma data reflects adjustments necessary to give effect to capital enhancement program transactions entered into in connection with the initial public offering of Jan. 29, 1993, and the subsequent pay-down of $ 100 million in bank debt on Feb. 23, 1993, as if the transactions had taken place on Jan. 1 of the respective year.

title: Trade-Pact Battle Lines: Wheat vs. Corn
description: When the talk at Ralph and Cleo Thompson's farmhouse social shifted from the cold, wet weather to the North American Free Trade Agreement, it quickly became apparent that here in the rural Midwest, where you stand on the agreement depends on what you grow.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "SOPHISTRY," Playwrights Horizons Studio, 416 West 42d Street, Clinton. Jonathan Marc Sherman's drama about a college professor who is charged with sexual harassment, directed by Nicholas Martin. Through Sunday. Performances: Today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $30. All performances are sold out, but returned tickets are sometimes available; those interested may put their names on a waiting list one hour before the performance. Information: (212) 279-4200. "SNOWING AT DELPHI," WPA Theater, 519 West 23d Street, Manhattan. A comedy about six friends who meet at an upstate farmhouse during the holidays by Catherine Butterfield; directed by Pamela Berlin. Through Sunday. Performances: today and tomorrow at 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $22. Information: (212) 206-0523.

title: Corrections
description: A table of Long Island election results yesterday misstated the party affiliation of Mark Morgenstern, a candidate for Nassau County district attorney. He ran on the Liberal Party line, not Right to Life.

title: For Cuomo, Elections Seeded Many Clouds and Few Linings
description: For Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the victory of Republican mayoral candidates in New York City and two upstate cities on Tuesday have created new political hurdles that will complicate his efforts to win re-election to a fourth term next year.

title: Review/Film; A Family That Overcomes (Music, Please)
description: "A Home of Our Own" is a shamelessly heart-warming family memoir that, with a good, crafty performance by Kathy Bates and with soundtrack music that tells you when to sob, often succeeds.

title: Hadson Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 3 million accrual for severance and transaction costs relating to the company's proposed merger into Apache Corp.c-Net income

title: Gap
description: Shares of Gap Inc. dropped yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after the company was one of several specialty retailers to report lower sales for October. The stock price had risen 40 percent from early September, apparently because several analysts raised their investment ratings on the San Francisco-based company.

title: Meridian Insurance Group Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 526,000, or 9 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-After a charge of $ 651,000 from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago periods were restated to conform with the Financial Accounting Standards Board's announcement on how financial statements of property and casualty insurance companies must accrue certain liabilities related to funded catastrophe cover arrangements with reinsurers.

title: Judge May Sever Some Charges in Case Involving a Plot to Bomb Landmarks
description: A Federal judge yesterday told lawyers defending the 15 men charged with sedition in a conspiracy to blow up New York City landmarks that he might be ready to sever the 1990 killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane from the case as well as charges involving what prosecutors say was a plot to assassinate the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak.

title:
Subsidized Housing;
Old Favorite, The 2-Family, In Comeback
description: Many developers of affordable housing are borrowing a page from the past and turning to construction of an old staple -- the two-family home.

title: Hollywood Entertainment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Results are pro forma and included tax adjustment to reflect company as a C corporation. The S corporation status was changed upon completion of its initial public offering on July 19, 1993.

title: Columbia Healthcare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge which represents retroactive increase in federal income tax rates of $ 5,000,000 in the quarter and 9 months; an extraordinary net charge of $ 168,000,000 which included restructing charges of $ 98 million and loss on early extinguishment of long-term debt of $ 70 million.Restructuring charges in the quarter and 9 months are related primarily to costs incurred in connection with the Galen Health merger, a write-down of assets associated with the restructuring of the combined entity's operations, and a provision for loss on the planned sale of certain assets in the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $ 16,000,000, or 10 cents a share.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 132,000,000 and $ 131,000,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively and an extraordinary restructuring charge resulting primarily from the spinoff of Galen by Humana Inc. of $ 86,000,000 in the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a gain of $ 51,000,000, or 36 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.The company said since the merger with Galen Health Care Inc. on Sept. 1, 1993 was accounted for as a pooling of interests, operating results for all periods have been restated to include Columbia and Galen on a combined basis.

title: Taylor to Play Limited Role
description: On Sunday you may see Lawrence Taylor as you've never seen him before: as a part-time role player.

title: Bias Found Against Bright Minority Students
description: In a ruling that would expand the liability of schools in desegregation cases, a Federal magistrate yesterday found that the Rockford, Ill., Public Schools had discriminated against bright minority students by failing to include them in classes for high achievers.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a noncash charge of $ 11,429,000 to adjust deferred tax balances to reflect the higher federal corporate income tax rate. In addition, current year taxes increased by $ 1,603,000 due to the tax rate change being retroactive to Jan. 1 for the quarter and 9 months.c-Included earnings of $ 17,422,000, or 19 cents a share, from deferred tax benefits reflecting adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 109 on Jan. 1, 1993.d-Included $ 7,267,000, or 8 cents a share, of deferred tax benefits recognized under the previously applicable accounting standard.Revenue represented total operating revenues.

title: Review/Art; From the 19th Century, Works by Americans Not Often Encountered
description: With much attention being paid to the reopening of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's 19th-Century European art collection, it is easy to overlook the less grandly packaged group shows of American work from the same period on view in Manhattan. In addition to "Dreams and Shadows" at the National Academy of Design (review on page C31), there are several group shows, large and small, all of which offer seldom-encountered work.

title: At the Bar; Catering to a feminist superstar, judges find themselves tangled in a free-speech debate
description: Though Catherine A. MacKinnon's views on pornography and censorship are highly debatable, one thing she has regularly refused to do is debate them -- at least, some assert, with women who hold opposing opinions.

title: Murder Indictment Given In Bucket-Tossing Case
description: Citing "circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life," a grand jury handed up an indictment of second-degree murder yesterday against the man who threw a bucket from a Washington Heights rooftop that killed a police officer in the street below.

title: Review/Art; Mike Kelley's Messages: Mixed and Mystical
description: One of the more striking works in Mike Kelley's often disturbing, sometimes beautiful and always demanding exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art is a big colorful banner made of pieces of felt. It depicts a cheery and motherly cookie jar and is emblazoned with the words "Let's Talk About Disobeying."

title: Beene: If Ever a Wiz There Was
description: Geoffrey Beene is a designer of singular accomplishments. He celebrated his 30th anniversary as the head of his own company with a book, a half-hour film and a display of 65 styles from his spring collection. There was no fashion show.

title: Playboy Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time restructuring charge of $ 2.5 million, and after a benefit of $ 7.5 million, or 38 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.c-Net loss, and included $ 500,000 in one-time items and nonrecurring expenses, primarily related to office relocations.

title: Let's Tighten Reins On Credit Reports

Halifax Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Halifax said that the improved second-quarter earnings were due in part to the acquisition of EAI Services in June.

title: Consultant to Head Foote, Cone Office
description: Foote, Cone & Belding said yesterday that it had appointed Joel Hochberg to head its Los Angeles office as executive vice president and general manager, effective on Monday.

title: Jurors Convict Mother in Death Of a Track Star
description: After deliberating only four hours, a jury today convicted a 43-year-old woman of murdering her teen-age daughter, who was one of the nation's most promising young female track stars.

title: Sports of The Times; There Are Many Ways To Be Missed
description: A LIFE-SIZE poster of Reggie Lewis greeted a visitor to Jack Grinold's office on the campus of Northeastern University yesterday, but Grinold said it was one of those days when the realization that Lewis is gone hit home just a little harder than usual.

title: Editorial Notebook; Confronting Slaughter in the Streets
description: My cousin Paul was shot to death at the age of 16. My brother Blake, a dealer of cocaine, was murdered at 22. My boyhood friend Stephen, number 14 on our football team, was shot four times in the head while conducting his heroin business. A second Stephen, in what sounded like a crack-induced frenzy, murdered three people, one of whom I also knew, then hanged himself in jail. I'd list more, except that space forbids it.

title: United Water Res.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain from an intercompany real estate transfer. The company declined to disclose the amount of the gain.

title: Islanders Extend Free Fall on Skates
description: This Islander defeat had a rare and enhanced level of frustration. When they lost by 4-2 to the Chicago Blackhawks tonight, two of Chicago's goals came on deflections off New York sticks, and two came after Islander players broke their sticks and skated with nothing in their hands.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, excerpts from Rudolph W. Giuliani's victory speech in some copies on Wednesday rendered a passage incorrectly. It should have read: "As we look to the future we must proceed with one thing in mind. Whatever adversity we face, we will face it together, and whatever the benefits, they will be distributed evenly and fairly." (The correct word was "adversity," not "diversity.")

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
HORSE RACING;
'Riding to a Different Level' Fills Smith's Cup Card
description: The first time Mike Smith rode in southern California, his horse made an abrupt right-hand turn in midstretch and left him with nothing but the hard track below. All he got that day was hot and dirty.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about rising sales at Brooks Brothers misstated the pretax profits of the store's British parent company, Marks & Spencer, when converted from British pounds to dollars. For the six months that ended March 31, Marks & Spencer earned the equivalent of $464.8 million, not $209 million.

title: Tuesday's Tea Leaves
description: The pundits have stretched their analytical powers to the limit to find meaning in Tuesday's elections. Their judgments range from the minimalist (nothing much happened) to the apocalyptic (the Democrats are headed for disaster in 1994). One point on which most agree is that this is a terrible time to be an incumbent.

title: Restaurants
description: "Have you tried the cheese yet?" asks the man in the little cap, strolling up to the table. "The cheese man here is the best."

title: France Growth Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income represented net investment income.As of Sept. 30, total net assets in the latest period was $ 141,741,575, or $ 12.32 a share, compared with $ 135,878,157, or $ 11.81 a share, in the year-ago period.

title: International Murex Technologies Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included restructuring costs of $ 3,286,000 in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Grieg Sesquicentennial
description: To celebrate the 150th birthday of the Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg, the Edvard Grieg Society of New York is to present a concert on Sunday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Per Brevig is to conduct the Orchestra of St. Luke's, with the soprano Torgun Birkeland performing songs by Greig and the piano duo Bradshaw and Buono playing the premiere of Johan Kvandal's Concerto for Two Pianos. Also on the program are Grieg's Norwegian Dances and Incidental Music to "Sigurd Jorsalfar." Tickets are $15 to $50. Information: (212) 875-5050.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; So the stock market didn't crash in October, after all. But what was that noise on Madison Avenue?
description: OCTOBER is often a tumultuous month on Wall Street. This time, it was quiet. But on another street -- Madison Avenue -- it was another story altogether.

title: Norcen Energy Res.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mary Shea Giordano; Philanthropic Leader, 90
description: Mary Shea Giordano, for many years a leader of Roman Catholic philanthropic groups in New York, died on Tuesday at St. Patrick's Home for the Aged in the Bronx. She was 90.

title: Elbit Ltd. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 835,000.

title: CONFLICT IS SEEN BETWEEN REGIONS IN HEALTH PLAN
description: While President Clinton's sweeping proposals would extend health care equally to all Americans, consumers and businesses in and around older urban areas like New York City are likely to find themselves paying substantially higher premiums for coverage than their counterparts elsewhere, and in many cases even higher than today.

title: Athlete Is Butcher's Ticket to Press Pass
description: DUST off a seat in the press box, boys. Sid Frenkel's back in business.

title: Boots Make a Statement: Is It Fashion or Politics?
description: The idea was to rid the high school of what officials said were emblems of violence and hate, thick-soled storm trooper boots, Los Angeles Raiders jackets and other attire favored by skinheads and gangs.

title: Art in Review
description: Ashley Bickerton Sonnabend Gallery 420 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Giants Decide Two Backs Are Better Than One
description: When Rodney Hampton thinks about the games earlier this season, when he was carrying the football 30 and 40 times a game, his legs begin to ache. He never complained about carrying the ball so much, but he was like those horses in Central Park that take tourists on carriage rides. Steady, dependable, but seriously overworked.

title: Bids Allowed By Contractor In Plea Accord
description: Last year, a New York City school construction contractor suspected of evading Federal taxes made a bid for leniency, the authorities say. Seeking a softer sentence, he offered to help expose a bid-rigging scheme in the school construction and repair programs.

title: Robert Hellendale, 76; Ran a Paper Company
description: Robert Hellendale, a retired chief executive in the paper manufacturing industry, died on Saturday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 76 and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: Sega Selects McCann-Erickson
description: Sega of America in Redwood City, Calif., said yesterday that it had selected McCann-Erickson San Francisco to handle an $8 million to $10 million campaign for a new toy division aimed at younger children and their parents.

title: 2 Police Officers Arrested In Theft of a Victim's Gun
description: Two police officers assigned to the 34th Precinct in Washington Heights were arrested late Wednesday night on charges that they stole a gun from a dying man who was shot during a gun battle between rival drug gangs last July, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Camden Property Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossLatest results are the actual results which included historical results of Camden Property Trust from July 29, 1993, through Sept. 30, 1993, plus historical results of Camden Predecessors from the beginning of the period through July 28, 1993.Latest quarter results do not reflect effect of initial public offering of 8,544,500 shares from the beginning of the period through July 28, 1993. Earnings adjusted for the effect of the initial public offering, pro forma third quarter earnings were $ 2,293,000, or 25 cents a share, on revenues of $ 10,921,000, and 9 months' earnings were $ 6,374,000, or 70 cents a share, on revenues of $ 29,889,000.

title: Bio-Dental Technologies (NSC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN SHIP SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The American Ship Building Company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday, a week after losing an appeal to keep a $176 million Navy contract. The loss of that contract to build two Navy oil tankers left the company with just one $63 million contract to build a Navy surveillance vessel and no commercial work. On Tuesday, the Navy put the company on notice that it would cancel the remaining contract unless the company showed it had the financial means to finish the ship. American Ship, based in Tampa, Fla., had already laid off 1,100 people, leaving an administrative crew of about 50 people. The acting chairman of the company is George M. Steinbrenner, the majority shareholder of the New York Yankees baseball team. His family started the company more than 100 years ago.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TV Weekend; 'Zelda': From Madcap to Madness
description: Like the political Kennedys, the literary Fitzgeralds -- F. Scott and Zelda -- have become almost obsessive national myths, their lives generating innumerable books and films with claims to assorted revelatory truths. With the 30th anniversary this month of the John F. Kennedy assassination, television will be presenting a slew of movies and documentaries over the next few weeks, exploring President Kennedy and his family from every conceivable angle. Meanwhile, TNT has decided to poke once more into the lives of the Fitzgeralds. Graced with one memorable performance, "Zelda" can be seen on Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight.

title: Administration Offers New Math To Bolster Health Plan's Appeal
description: Struggling to convince Americans that its health care plan would save most people money, the Clinton Administration today produced its third set of predictions of how many Americans would pay more, or less, for health insurance.

title: Home Video
description: The movie business acknowledges that if a film is altered for television or videocassette, the public should be told. But told what?

title: American Medical Response Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Pro-forma. Company went public in August 1992.The company noted that it received about $ 46.4 million in net proceeds from a public offering of 3.25 million common shares in September and October.

title: All 88 Picassos Sell In Auction at Sotheby's
description: Sotheby's has always been a company known for taking risks, and its sale of 88 Picassos from the Stanley J. Seeger collection last night was a risk well taken. Every lot sold, with some works bringing double their estimates. One drawing brought five times as much as expected.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;
description: The issuance of new corporate debt is running at a record pace, according to Stephen W. Carter, an analyst with MCM/Corporatewatch. He said yesterday that the total of debt sold to date is about $250 billion compared with $207 billion for all of last year.

title: N.C.A.A. Selects Arizonan As Director
description: Cedric Dempsey, the athletic director at the University of Arizona, has been picked to become the third executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Medical Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Shocking Crime?
description: Last month was National Domestic Violence Awareness Month, but it's November that will really put the issue of violence against women on the map. On Monday, John Wayne Bobbitt is scheduled to go on trial, accused of sexually assaulting his wife, Lorena Bobbitt; on Nov. 29, it will be her day in court. On June 23, as everyone must know by now, she cut off his penis with a kitchen knife.

title: Lowe Group Buys Scali, McCabe
description: The long expected sale of Scali, McCabe, Sloves by the WPP Group P.L.C. to the Lowe Group, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies' three agency networks, finally took place yesterday after more than two years of on-again, off-again talks.

title: Gaylord Container Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 2.1 million pretax charge for the consolidation of certain facilities in the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary gain of $ 201,500,000, or $ 4.40 a share, from restructuring of subordinated debt and a charge of $ 1,300,000 from adoption of SFAS 106.c-Net lossd-Included an asset write-down of $ 32.9 million and a $ 9 million pretax charge for costs associated with the acquisition of certain joint venture interests in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Why Not Mandatory Liability Insurance for Handgun Owners?
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Turkey Kurdish Separatists Blamed for Attacks Across Europe
description: Kurdish separatists attacked Turkish embassies and offices across Europe today, killing one person, wounding at least 23 others and inflicting serious property damage. It was the second time this year that Turkish targets in Europe have been attacked in coordinated assaults.

title: MOBIL PLANS TO CLOSE ITS SOLAR ENERGY PROGRAM
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would close its 19-year-old solar energy program because it did not expect the technology to produce a reasonable return until well into the next century. As a result, 164 workers at the Mobil Solar Energy Corporation's demonstration plant in Billerica, Mass., will be laid off and production operations there will cease. Mobil declined to say how much money it had invested in the solar program.

title: Cox in Cable Merger Talks
description: Cox Enterprises Inc. and the Southwestern Bell Corporation are close to an agreement to pool their cable holdings and spin off the combined business in a publicly held company, investment bankers close to the talks said today.

title: Sun Sportswear Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Computer Language Research (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-Included a gain of $ 5,694,000, or 41 cents a share, for cumulative effect of accounting change for adoption of FASB 109.

title: Fila Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are in American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS equals 5 ordinary shares.Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Boeing Studies Production Of a Versatile Jet Fighter
description: The Boeing Company said today that it was studying production of a new military jet that could serve the Air Force, fly from carriers for the Navy and lift off vertically for the Marines.

title: Business Travel Takes a Pay Cut
description: The luxurious business trip has not yet gone the way of the three-martini lunch, and corporations are not requiring executives to pack a bedroll for out-of-town travel. But so intent are companies on holding down costs that they are increasingly requiring employees to fly in economy class and to stay in hotels to match.

title: As Liberia's Factions Talk, Strife and Fear Drag On
description: For the last three months, Liberia's political factions have engaged in something rare for this war-battered country: peaceful negotiations to resolve the bitter differences that have led Liberia from dictatorship to anarchy.

title: Arthur J. Klein; Entertainment Lawyer, 61
description: Arthur J. Klein, a New York lawyer for 35 years who often represented actors and other people in entertainment, died on Tuesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 61.

title: RLI Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 1,665,000, or 29 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.RLI said that the decrease in earnings is primarily due to Midwestern flood claims, which are now estimated to cost $ 3.3 million.

title: Consumers Water (NMS) reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 5,179,000 which included a noncash charge of $ 4.2 million to establish a reserve for disposition of a company.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 217,000, or 3 cents a share.Latest 12 months' income from continuing operations of $ 9,559,000, or $ 1.32 a share, included gain of $ 841,000 from sale of properties.Year-ago 12 months' income from continuing operations of $ 6,942,000, or 99 cents a share, included $ 206,000 from sales of properties.

title: Plains Resources Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Plan for a TV Screen in Grand Central Draws Criticism
description: Eager to increase revenues, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will erect a high-definition television screen at Grand Central Terminal later this month in a test of an advertising, news and entertainment program that officials say could raise $1 million a year.

title: Nu-Kote Holdings (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included a charge of $ 1 million for its secondary offering in May.Year-ago results are pro forma figures to reflect the company's initial public offering, the acquisition of Future Graphics and an increase of 4 cents a share in the quarter and 9 cents a share in the 6 months for the normalization of taxes to current rates.

title: Rebuilding Dreams in Wire and Wax
description: Raven Chanticleer may have the most famous roommates in New York. There are Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr., Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Josephine Baker and Fannie Lou Hamer.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about shifts in voting patterns in the New York City mayoral election misstated the party affiliation of Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

title: Accounts
description: * Midas International Corp., Chicago, to the Evans Group, Seattle and Pheonix, to handle its local advertising in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Oregon, Washington and parts of Montana, previously handled by Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, which continues handling Midas's national account. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

title: The Spoken Word
description: TONY CURTIS, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The actor, who made his acting debut 50 years ago at the Y, will speak with Charlie Rose. Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $16. Information: (212) 996-1100. OPERA LECTURE, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, Kaplan Penthouse, 10th Floor. A discussion of Mozart's "Die Zauberflote" by Bridget Paolucci, a lecturer and music correspondent for National Public Radio. Tomorrow at 11:45 A.M. Sponsored by the Metropolitan Guild. Admission: $8. Information: (212) 769-7021.

title: Cisco Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split which was effective March 5, 1993.

title: Public Schools Are Failing Brightest Students, a Federal Study Says
description: The nation is failing its smartest students, who sit bored and unchallenged in classrooms and ultimately learn less than their counterparts around the world, according to the most comprehensive Federal study in two decades on the status of education for the gifted and talented.

title: Landauer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Where There's Smoke There May Be Dunston
description: The Mets, continuing their urgent push to acquire a shortstop, spoke with the Chicago Cubs late Wednesday night, apparently about trading for Shawon Dunston.

The 9 months also included a charge of $ 11,900,000 from cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.c-Net lossd-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,000,000, or 6 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 12,500,000, or 25 cents a share, in the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a charge of $ 14,500,000 from cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.Kemper said that its third-quarter 1993 results included a charge of $ 184.7 million after taxes for the company's provision for real estate-related losses due to declining valuations in the real estate portfolio, and a $ 3.3 million tax gain due to the change in the corporate tax rate.

title: FHP International Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
