Roslyn Heights $350,000 54 Glenwood Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 117-year-old Victorian; dining room, parlor, 3 fireplaces, 1 acre; taxes $4,300, listed at $500,000, 10 weeks on market (Broker: Coldwell Banker Sammis). Smithtown $106,000 175 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 55-year-old Cape Cod; basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,600, listed at $129,900, 6 weeks on market (Broker: Straub Resales). Syosset $417,000 149 Split Rock Road 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 74-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, 1 acre, garage w/ one-bedroom guest apartment; taxes $8,000, listed at $525,000, 32 weeks on market (Broker: Daniel Gale Associates).

title: Clinton Plan Rewards Big Insurers; Tops in Bureaucracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Snuffing Out Secondhand Smoke
description: Only 10 years ago, the Smoke-Free Environment Act of 1993, introduced last week by Senator Frank Lautenberg and Representative Henry Waxman, would have seemed unthinkable. Now, as evidence about the health risks involved in inhaling somebody else's cigarette continues to mount, it just seems common-sensical.

title: Stephanie Miller, James F. Laborde
description: Stephanie Alicia Miller, the editor in the information products group of Fitch Investors Service Inc., was married yesterday to James Ferrier Laborde, an account executive at Katz Independent Television, a media representative. Both work in New York. The Rev. James P. Walsh performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Peace Church in New York.

title: How the Unemployed Are Facing Changes in the Workplace
description: ECONOMISTS would say Eugene J. Cribbin and Catherine Devito are "meeting the challenge of change." Mr. Cribbin and Mrs. Devito, unemployed as a result of company staff reductions, say, however, that they are enrolled in the occupational-training center run by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services in Yorktown Heights because they need jobs.

title: Angelic Verses for Rushdie
description: Arab and Muslim intellectuals were strangely silent in 1989 when Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a "fatwa" -- or death sentence -- against Salman Rushdie for offending Islam in his book "The Satanic Verses." More than four years later, however, growing attacks on independent Muslim writers and thinkers -- most dramatically in Algeria -- appear to have convinced them that freedom of expression is an absolute value and that a death sentence on one writer is a way of trying to silence all writers.

title: Who Will Fix Tomorrow's Cars?
description: IN the not too distant future, every new car sold in this country will have a computer chip at its nerve center. The chip will make the car run more efficiently. It will also make repairs to the car's engine as easy as reprogramming the chip at the push of a button.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Why the pianist Krystian Zimerman wouldn't even think of stepping onstage ahead of Ricard de La Rosa. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 The flower business is getting rough, and George Prevezanos is worried. PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 14 Remembering Yugoslavia in TriBeCa, Puerto Rico in Mott Haven and Scotland on the Upper West Side. MOVIE CLOCK 16 What's showing at the local movie houses, today through Thursday. GOOD EATING 21 The very middle of midtown: reshmi kebab or mulligatawny at Darbar, sturdy mushroom barley at La Bonne Soupe. SOAPBOX 23 Newer, fewer, less reliable: the bus as stepchild of New York City transit. Plus, letters and "Eye of the Beholder."

title: A Veteran's Legacy: Garden of Heroes
description: THE small room is kept cool, so the crystalline wax of the sculptures stored here will not melt. Against one wall, a life-size alcoholic with a bottle in his hand comforts a young prostitute carrying a toy bunny. Nearby, a homeless man's frightened eyes peek out from a cardboard-box shelter. A Rodin-like figure in cape and hat huddles against the cold, while across the room, a fierce-looking man sticks out his tongue at the passing world.

title: Breathing Room
description: No real-estate ad would ever waste words on GRT HALL alongside such obvious assets as RVR VUS, WBFPL and HRWDFLRS. And yet, these neither-here-nor-there connectors are truly indispensable in making a home livable. They are an urban dweller's passage to sanity.

title: Tiny Wineries With a Big Impact
description: SEAN THACKREY is the curator of a small art gallery, Bob Lamborn is a semiretired private investigator and Dick Stark is a former Silicon Valley marketing executive. But all three would insist they share a single vocation: winemaker.

title: The First Antecedent
description: To the Editor:

title: Mad, Mad World of Hitting the Wall
description: Let's get this much straight. They are only tears of joy at the finish line because the madness is over. The body gets the rest of the day off. No more blisters, for the time being. No more cramps. No more dizziness, nausea, lightheadedness, diarrhea, vomiting, chills, headaches, numbness and/or those pained expressions that make you very unattractive.

title: Making Our Schools Safer
description: LIKE MOST parents and grandparents, I am shocked by the violence that has occurred in and around schools this fall. In Atlanta, a ninth-grade student died after being shot in a lunchroom. In Dallas, a 15-year-old was gunned down by a fellow student in a hallway. In Washington, a 4-year-old was shot while watching a football game on a school playground. Unfortunately, this is the reality of school life in many cities, but it is not just a city problem. It is a national problem.

title: Thrift Shop Backlash
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Woods
description: Carved out of a stand of soaring pines and elms just inland from the Atlantic coast, nestled in an industrial park complete with shimmering ponds on which plump ducks glide like lazy clouds, the world headquarters of the Timberland Company befits its image as one of the most successful producers of rugged outdoor wear on the planet.

title: Lobster Catches Drop in Key Months
description: LAST summer was a very bad season for Connecticut lobstermen. But according to recently compiled state fishery statistics, this summer's lobster catch was worse. And drastically falling lobster catches may be the wave of the immediate future along Connecticut's shoreline.

title: Self-Rule Pact Is Major Challenge To Islamic Militant Group in Gaza
description: On the day Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat shook hands in Washington to seal their peace pact, Atef Adwan sat bound and blindfolded in an Israeli Army detention center here as celebrations erupted in the streets.

title: Is 'Rusalka' A Fairy Tale? Yes. And No.
description: Be honest now. You hear that a piece that can be billed as Beloved National Opera is coming to town. Does your pulse quicken? Are you immediately impelled to storm the box office?

title: In Zimbabwe, Imperiled Rhinoceroses
description: A LARCHMONT resident is trying to raise money to help save rhinoceroses in Zimbabwe in southern Africa.

title: Excuse Me; I Must Have Missed Part of the Movie
description: SOMETIMES cultural events conspire. First there was the "60 Minutes" expose of the contemporary art world, unleashing a flood of rabid debate over what is art and what is hokum, what is criticism and what is willful idiocy. Then, last week, Federico Fellini died, unleashing a flood of paeans, eulogies and fawning obituaries. In the, pardon the expression, wake of these events, it occurs to me that there are two kinds of Philistines in the world, and that most of us are one kind or the other.

title: GIULIANI PROMISES NEW TACK ON DRUGS AND CITY SPENDING
description: Sending a signal about some early priorities of his administration, Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would issue two executive orders soon after taking office to enforce budget discipline among his department heads and to make clear to police officers that they can make street arrests of drug dealers.

title: BOSNIANS DISBAND SARAJEVO CROATS
description: The Muslim-led Bosnian Army mounted a raid before dawn today to disband the Croatian militia force that had helped defend Sarajevo, Bosnia's besieged capital, from Serbian attacks for the last 19 months.

title: 'Such a Bunch Of Losers'
description: To the Editor:

title: Car-Rental Companies Raise Their Rates
description: Car-rental companies are raising their rates in major cities throughout the United States and for every category. The average rise is 12 to 15 percent, but it varies by city. The companies instituted a price rise a year ago, but pulled back in most places when business slackened this year. This time the rises appear to be sticking. First announced for 28 cities by Hertz, the biggest company, at the beginning of October, the increases are in effect by now in 100 cities, and other companies are following suit.

title: Token Art
description: SURROUNDED by the bleeps and blasts of his childhood, Mark Oliver strolled down memory lane.

title: Television As Teacher's Assistant
description: JUDY Tretiak, a kindergarten teacher in Westfield, N.J., was having trouble explaining volcanoes to her students. She couldn't find an appropriate book, and a field trip to Hawaii did not seem imminent. So Ms. Tretiak turned on the television set in her classroom at Franklin Elementary School and popped in a videotape on volcanic activity.

title: Congratulations Are in Order
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Police at Kennedy Is Reassigned
description: The head of the police force at Kennedy International Airport is being reassigned after he sent two officers to check on his boss at the hospital and then authorized overtime for them, a Port Authority spokesman said yesterday.

title: OCT. 31-NOV. 5: The Packwood Papers; Senate Demands a Look At the Diaries
description: "I do not want to go to court," Senator Bob Packwood told the Senate last week. "I do not want to have to pay several hundred thousand dollars or a million to test this in the courts. I would like this to be over with."

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FREEDOM AND EXTREMISTS

title: Play 'Misty' (Again and Again) for Me
description: HERE is the equipment that David Sudnow uses to turn 120 beginners into competent cocktail pianists: one room in Steinway Hall, the elegant showroom on West 57th Street, three hours on a Saturday, three on a Sunday; 120 folding chairs; a headset microphone; one piano.

title: Celebrity Goulash
description: Stars cooked at Gourmet Gala for March of Dimes, Nov. 1.

title: Sicily Pensione
description: To the Editor: In April 1992, you ran an article by Mary Taylor Simeti, "In an Ancient Monastery, Family Fare," on the Tornabene family's remarkable monastery restaurant in Sicily's Madonie mountain town of Gangivecchio. Now the enterprising Tornabenes have opened a delightful nine-room pensione where we spent an evening recently. The Tenuta Gangivecchio, which is in the province of Palermo, costs 85,000 lire per person, including bed, breakfast, dinner and locally produced red wine. The food is superb.

title: Susan Brody, Stephen Thomas
description: Susan Elizabeth Brody, a reporter for Sports Illustrated magazine, and Stephen Vail Thomas, a reporter for Sports Illustrated for Kids magazine, both in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel in South Orange, N.J.

title: Alisa Pines, Ronald Emanuel
description: Alisa Pines, a daughter of Doreen and Ira Pines of Glen Cove, L.I., was married last evening to Ronald Bruce Emanuel, a son of Carole Goldstein and Barry Emanuel, both of New York. Rabbi Laurence Kotok officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Searingtown, L.I.

title: Bank Agrees to Remodel in Basic Brick
description: Republic National Bank's plans for a $40 million tower and a $2.6 million restoration of its landmark Knox Building at Fifth Avenue and 40th Street have been approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, after slight modification.

title: OCT. 31-NOV. 5: AIDS Scare; Infected Blood Supplies Distributed in Germany
description: Germans were urged not to panic last week after officials confirmed that a company had distributed blood products tainted with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Barbara Barsa, James Jamison
description: Barbara Anne Barsa, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert S. Barsa of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Kennedy Jamison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rushton M. Jamison of Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Rev. Vance Polley performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: County Buys New Vans To Carry the Disabled
description: NEARLY one million passenger trips have been made on the county's Paratransit system for the disabled since service began on Oct. 24, 1983.

title: LITTLE BIG PEOPLE
description: These parents should be commended for raising forthright and honest children, as my own parents did. With our precociousness comes a thirst for knowledge and a disdain for mediocrity. Leaving children in "dreamlike states" is precisely the type of mumbo jumbo that is keeping America behind in this competitive world. SUJATHA MURALI Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Do Drunken Drivers Get Railroaded?
description: DEFENSE lawyers, legal scholars and some municipal court judges are beginning to say that the well-intentioned attempts by lawmakers and judges to rid the state's roads of drunken drivers are undermining the constitutional rights of many defendants in such cases.

title: Purple Cows and Literacy
description: CORWIN Jacobs, a Cornell University senior, has discovered that a purple cow may be the ideal companion for a teen-ager who is learning to read.

title: Noisily Nurturing the Grass Roots
description: UNDER a radiant sun, Solomon Goodrich swung past screechy traffic into Roy Wilkins Park, a bold gesture of urban rehabilitation in southeastern Queens. He studied several men swatting golf balls with mixed precision, then fetching them from their far-flung landings. "They are here every day, whatever the weather," he said. "They would be lost without this park."

title: Curious Behavior Of the Dog, Watson
description: IF the shade of Harold Sterling Vanderbilt could return to view the American bridge scene almost six decades after the famous cruise through the Panama Canal on which he presented his "new" game of contract, he would find that his rubber-bridge code had virtually disappeared. In the 50's, the rubber game started to lose ground to Chicago, or four-deal bridge, and is now a rarity in in North America.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CHILDREN'S THEATER

title: 'Emmitt': A Name That Won't Go Away
description: In every corner of the Giant locker room this week there were conversations about Emmitt. That was what people were calling him: Emmitt. The Giants thought they were on a first-name basis with the Dallas Cowboy running back, since they had seen him so much on television and game film. But they were fortunate; others have seen him in person -- from behind.

title: The New Inner Circle: A Small, Trusted Group
description: Christine Todd Whitman has thrown a wide net in her search for people to serve in her new administration, but the final staffing and policy decisions will probably be made in the Governor-elect's living room with just her immediate family on hand.

title: An 'Oh, Well' For Wesleyan
description: For Wesleyan, the setting was perfect: The team was unbeaten through six games with two to play, it was homecoming day at Andrus Field before a crowd of 5,500 -- big by Wesleyan standards -- and a victory over Williams would have given the Cardinals their first outright Little Three championship since 1970.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 17 about the New Jersey Coastal Heritage Trail misstated the location of the trail's northern welcome center. The center, at the entrance to Cheesequake State Park, is in Old Bridge Township, in Middlesex County, not in Matawan, in Monmouth County.

title: Debra Richman, Bruce Schoenfeld
description: Debra Sue Richman, the daughter of Donald and Pearl Richman of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Bruce David Schoenfeld, a son of Fred Schoenfeld of New York, and the late Judith Lieber. Rabbi Robert Orkland officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: In the Wings
description: A chicken glaze requires slightly less time to make than a beef glaze, but it offers a similar challenge. The cook must remain vigilant and unobtrusive throughout the simmering, only to become resourceful and imaginative when using the resulting elixir.

title: Joanne Kim, Henry Kolowrat
description: Joanne Kim, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kyo A. Kim of Greenville, Del., was married yesterday to Henry Francis Kolowrat, the son of Henry Kolowrat of Philadelphia and Elizabeth S. Kolowrat of Swarthmore, Pa. The Rev. John Walton officiated at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del.

title:
Your Own Account;
Sharing a Family Business, Tax Free
description: AT the end of the year, many taxpayers consider making gifts to younger family members with the intention of shrinking their estates and ultimately, any estate taxes.

title: Key West
description: To the Editor: I read with interest "What's Doing in Key West." However, I must take issue with the author's statement that "Very little remains of the salvaging industry that was Key West's economic lifeblood in the 1800's," as our Wrecker's Museum/ Oldest House, at 322 Duval Street, exhibits old documents, ship models, undersea and maritime artifacts and paintings and prints that tell the story of the early wreckers (salvagers) in the Florida Keys. The museum is open daily from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and is staffed entirely by volunteers. SAM MAXWELL President, Old Island Restoration Foundation Key West, Fla.

title:
MUSIC;
Unusual Path to a New Work
description: ANONYMOUS selection by number may be a new idea in commissioning composers, but that process has produced a new work by Aaron Kernis, chosen recently in an informal competition. Not only was the process of selection unusual, but also Mr. Kernis's work is the first piece composed as a result of a direct commission for a radio broadcast, said Mary Lee, producer of the public radio program that will broadcast the work.

title: Japan's Old Guard Flails At the Talking Heads
description: WHEN the revolution finally arrived in the Japanese political world last summer, the country's commercial television networks led the charge, and clearly enjoyed their newly discovered power to stir the electorate. Now the losers are out for revenge, trying to put the genie back in the television tube.

title: In Twist, Protectionism Is Used to Sell Trade Pact
description: Increasingly desperate to win support in Congress for the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Clinton Administration has resorted to the odd tactic of selling a free-trade pact by highlighting its protectionist provisions.

title: Stiff Premium To Travel Alone
description: DIANA L. DIAMOND of Palo Alto, Calif., a hospital administrator, signed up with Globus Tours for a trip to India last summer. The price of the 19-day trip, with air fare and land arrangements, was $3,530. This, as is typical of tour operators' offerings, was the price for one person based on the traveler's sharing a room with a companion. For Ms. Diamond to make the trip by herself, she would have to pay $1,026 additional as a "single supplement."

title: Cheerleader Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Hail the Instant Coursepack!
description: SOMEWHERE on the academic continuum between lugging thick tomes to class and using a notebook computer to tap into electronic library collections, a new era of textbooks has taken hold: the coursepack.

title: The Adventures of Tony Richardson
description: THE LONG-DISTANCE RUNNERAn Autobiography.By Tony Richardson.Illustrated. 368 pp. New York:William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: Does Industrial Policy Work? Lessons From Sematech
description: THE world has changed for Sematech, the Government-subsidized consortium of semiconductor manufacturers formed amid much criticism in 1987 to rescue an industry faltering against Japan.

title: SUNDAY, November 7, 1993; A MILLION DOLAR BABY, BUT NO FIVE-AND-TEN-CENT STORE
description: It has to have cosmic significance that Tiffany Trump was born on the same day Woolworth's announced its intention to close almost 1,000 stores and put 13,000 people out of work.

title: Fashion Forward
description: Council of Fashion Designers honors the press, Nov. 1.

title: After a Suit, Moving to a New Life
description: ONCE she navigates past the smoke-scarred lobby downstairs, the litter in the hallways and the three dead-bolt locks at her front door, Carol Giddins finally enters a private oasis -- her tidy two-bedroom, plant-filled apartment that belies the squalor below.

title: Islanders Win Ugly Over Nonwinning Whalers
description: The Islanders proved tonight that they are at least slightly better than the Hartford Whalers by outlasting them, 5-3, at the Coliseum. The Islanders came into the game ranked 23d in the 26-team National Hockey League; the Whalers were 25th.

title: A Raucous Assessment Hearing
description: IT was billed as a town meeting. Less than a week before election day, Alfred Del Vecchio, Mayor of White Plains, convened a panel to discuss reassessment in the city. In front of an audience of about 250 people and with live cable coverage, Mr. Del Vecchio, who lost re-election last week to the office he held for 18 years, told residents that if the state forced the city to reassess, their taxes would likely double.

title: Anger Over a Proposal to Aid Former Prostitutes
description: On West 12th Street between Eighth and Greenwich Avenues, trees shade the walks, and some town house values approach $1 million. But the usually placid street has been stirred up by Dr. Joyce I. Wallace's proposal to convert her neat four-story brick home and office at No. 266 into New York City's first shelter for former prostitutes.

title: THE CORONATION OF KING RONNIE
description: As a Kenyan, I found the tone of Alex Shoumatoff's article "The Coronation of King Ronnie" (Oct. 17) offensive. I doubt that he would have described the coronation of a European monarch, even of the beleaguered House of Windsor, in such belittling tones.

title: Forget Designer Dogs; Mutts Are the Best Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD: Playing Dominoes in Central Asia; Why All Eyes Are on a Place Called Tajikistan
description: SMALL, mountainous and with no oil or nuclear weapons, Tajikistan, one of the new Central Asian nations formed from the old Soviet Union, wouldn't seem to be of much interest to the outside world. But Russia has 20,000 troops engaged in almost daily combat in the impoverished backwater of five million people, and the United States has an active embassy; diplomats from Turkey, Iran, China and Germany are also here.

title: LITTLE BIG PEOPLE
description: The sophisticated children's quotations cited by Lucinda Franks are in keeping with the updated words I hear elementary schoolchildren putting to such classics as "A tisket, a tasket, my green and yellow basket." Today, they sing, "A tisket, a tasket, a condom or a casket." ANTHONY M. DEIULIO Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Deborah Miller, Adam Landis
description: Deborah Lynn Miller, a postdoctoral research fellow in psycho-oncology at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and Adam Gilbert Landis, an associate at the law firm of Schulte Roth & Zabel, were married yesterday in Wilmington, Del. The couple work in New York. Rabbi Julie Greenberg and the Rev. Dr. Joseph Ruane of the Federation of Christian Ministries officiated at Brantwyn Mansion.

title:
Commercial Property/Atlantic City;
A New Face to Reflect the Glory Days of Old
description: IT is not much to look at now, this dreary wedge of Atlantic City punctuated by littered lots and small businesses, stretching 20 blocks to a wall of flashy casinos. But that may change soon.

title: SUNDAY, November 7, 1993; DOWNSIZING
description: Miniature golf may finally be getting some respect. This summer the Clintons played while they were on vacation. And an exhibit called "Putt-Modernism," mounted by the Artists Space gallery to raise funds, is now on display at the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan as part of a nationwide tour.

title: Knicks Get a Lesson Without Paying for It
description: Victories on the road are precious, even when they are precarious.

title: Climber Likes His Mountains High and Clean
description: It is safe to say that climbing Mount Everest alone and without supplemental oxygen is beyond the reach of most mortals. But for Reinhold Messner, a legendary mountaineer, it is part of being normal.

title: LITTLE BIG PEOPLE
description: Spoiled kids are nothing new. So why limit the exploration of this New Wave brattiness to Manhattan apartment buildings with doormen. Any of us, from any social background, can recall friends with a flair for beating adults at their own game. Even I, as a shy and obedient boy of 10, would parrot my father's serious stock phrase -- "This is totally unacceptable!" -- when offered food I didn't want.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-21 SOVIET ATOMIC TEST ON TROOPS A film of a Soviet nuclear test in 1954 that exposed 45,000 Red Army troops and thousands of civilians as part of a military exercise sheds new light on the use of people as guinea pigs during the cold war. 1 CHINA FACES WATER SHORTAGES At a time when China's 1.1 billion people are relatively prosperous, a growing number of scientists fear that the country's water resources will not be able to keep up with its ever more robust expansion. 1 YELTSIN STEPS BACK FROM VOTE Backing off from a promise to hold early presidential elections next June, President Yeltsin of Russia said he would stay in office until his term expires in 1996. 3 BOSNIA DISBANDS CROATIAN FORCE The Muslim-led Bosnian Army disbanded the Croatian militia force that had helped defend Sarajevo from Serbian attacks. The crackdown followed months of bitter fighting between Croatian and Muslim forces elsewhere in Bosnia. 7 ITALY RE-EXAMINES MORO SLAYING Fifteen years after terrorists killed Aldo Moro in postwar Italy's most enduring national trauma, investigators have been confronted with new evidence suggesting that the wrong man was convicted. 13 SCANDAL HITS JAPAN REFORMER The top strategist of Japan's new reform-minded Government has been implicated in a bribery scandal, casting a shadow over Prime Minister Hosokawa's coalition. 16 UKRAINE CULT FACES CRACKDOWN Ukrainian officials have begun a crackdown against members of a religious cult whose leader has pledged to stage her own crucifixion and resurrection. 21 For comedians and satirists in Poland, things are looking up. 6 National 22-36 DOCTORS' PAY MAY DROP After years of surging incomes that made many millionaires, the nation's doctors now face the prospect of stable or shrinking pay. 1 HOPE SUBSIDES FOR NEW DRUG Just a year ago, taxol, a new cancer drug, was hailed as a breakthrough and and expectations ran high among doctors and patients. But the enthusiasm has tempered. 1 NEW TACK ON FREE TRADE As the President intensifies his campaign to win approval for the North American Free Trade Agreement, he has begun to argue that failure to pass the accord will undermine American foreign policy. 1 The trade pact is being sold with its protectionist aspects. 26 GOING AFTER DEADLY BULLETS In his proposal this week to levy high taxes on destructive ammunition, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan focused the gun-control debate on physics, terminal-wound ballistics and penetration factors. 22 PENNSYLVANIA JUSTICE ASSAILED A grand jury found no credible evidence to substantiate criminal accusations Justice Rolf Larsen made against two colleagues. The grand jury also recommended Justice Larsen's removal. 22 MILITARY BUDGET APPROVED Congressional negotiators approved a $261 billion military budget for the 1994 fiscal year, making few big changes in the Administration's first Pentagon spending plan. 25 MIXED MESSAGE FOR G.O.P. Political Memo: The Republican sweep in elections this week will no doubt boost morale. But many Republicans said the victories did little to crystallize the vision of a party still reeling from losing the White House. 24 LINK FOR PSYCHOSOMATIC ILLNESS Researchers said a large statistical study of Chinese-Americans in California had found evidence that psychosomatic beliefs can shorten a person's life. 27 Metro 37-44 GIULIANI TO ISSUE 2 ORDERS Rudolph W. Giuliani pledged that his administration would quickly require department heads to prove every three months that they are within budget and to make clear to police officers that they can make street arrests of drug dealers. 1 BALLOONING MAINTENANCE COSTS Reconstruction of New York City's oldest high school has become the latest symbol of the Board of Education's troubled maintenance operations, with costs ballooning to $78 million from $22 million. 37 2 CAMPAIGN MODELS The first head-to-head clash between two respected political consultants, Ed Rollins and James Carville, produced two campaign models that will likely influence how campaigns are run straight through to the 1996 Presidential elections. 37 A POLITICIAN'S DEATH Nick Wasicsko was laid to rest on Election Day, his casket surrounded by dozens of Westchester County politicians and hundreds of his former constituents. The general election was to be the first in almost a decade in which his name would not appear on the Yonkers ballot. 37 ASSESSING WHAT WENT WRONG Shaken by Mayor David N. Dinkins's defeat, more than 100 black politicians and community leaders met in a Harlem high school to assess what went wrong and plan how to resurrect the political power that came with the election of the city's first black mayor. 40 Obituaries 46 Jeffrey Schmalz, reporter and editor at The Times.

title: INTO THE PIT
description: From the outside, it looks like a riot, a street fight, a battle in a war we didn't even know was going on. Several hundred scruffy teen-agers, dressed in a weird hybrid of Pacific Coast Lumberjack and Early Heroin Addict, are crushed together in a fleshy, roiling mass in front of a stage. They are attending a concert; they are also, it seems, trying to kill one another. Granted, they're doing it gracefully, without Uzis or broken bottles. It's strictly skin on skin: torsos slam into one another, chests collide, heads recoil, noses bleed; clothing is ripped off, trampled underfoot, forgotten; bodies fall and disappear, sucked into the sweaty undertow. Occasionally a warrior is tossed above the crush and passed along from hand to hand. It's unspeakably hot, often painful, certainly claustrophobic -- all in all, just another night in the mosh pit.

title:
PRO FOOTBALL;
Still Winning After All These Years
description: Watching from close up the gathering apotheosis of Don Shula can be a fairly suffocating thing. To begin with, there are all those Shula signature items crowding the senses: a Shula hotel, a Shula expressway (said to be straight as an arrow), a foundation, an "all-star cafe," etc., etc.

title: Getting Licenses for Selling, Storing, Moving
description: PERHAPS you have decided that it is high time you opened a bingo parlor. You've got the boards, you've ferreted out those little chips, you've even lined up an expert caller.

title: Waistlines Rediscovered
description: A few women are giving their fall jackets and coats a new look by buckling a narrow leather belt around them. It's been years since fashion highlighted the belted waistline. Could this be an early signal that the reconstruction of fashion has begun after decades of loose layers and the recent deconstruction of dressing?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SUBURBAN GOTHIC ELECT MR. ROBINSONFOR A BETTER WORLD By Donald Antrim.Viking, $20.

title: Boulez Relaxes His Grip -- a Bit
description: Pierre Boulez began his career as a wild man of the avant-garde, a composer who clung to the Serialist faith and lashed out at his enemies without mercy. Many of those enemies were in France, and during the 1950's and 60's Mr. Boulez spent most of his time in West Germany, where he actually lived for a while.

title: Dispute Arises on 'Historic' Designation
description: IF he were around today to saunter down South Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge's main street, Elias Boudinot, the president of the Continental Congress, would encounter a scene quite different from the one he knew in his early days here.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Down by the Riverside
description: J. M. W. Turner is perhaps best known for his alchemical fusings of fire and water, sky and sea, in spectacular atmospheric images in which solid forms, be they ships or castles, seem nearly to dissolve in light and color. To different critics at different times, his monumental canvases have prefigured a range of later styles, from Impressionism to Abstract Expressionism. But it is not the more familiar, grand pictures -- of Parliament on fire or Trafalgar battleships -- that are the main subject of this small and charming book, TURNER ON THE THAMES: River Journeys in the Year 1805 (Yale University, $45). Instead, David Hill, an art historian at the University of Leeds, takes the reader on an intimate excursion into a small domain within Turner's work -- the many beautiful, serene sketches he made of the Thames in his first years at Syon Ferry House, which had a view of the river. During that time, Turner escaped from the entangled politics of London's art world, where the Royal Academy was marooned in petty disputes, to paint alfresco on the riverbanks. From his boat, he made oil paintings as well as watercolors; his lustrous oils are delightfully sensuous, with brush marks in thin paint following the grain of the mahogany boards. With an imagination primed with verses by Virgil and Dante (Turner had also been trying to write poetry), the painter transformed many of England's plain and rustic spots into classic idylls, as in "Isis" (1806). Painted at Weymouth, the canvas depicts an elegiac vista of arching trees silhouetted against a golden Italianate sky, with a silvery thread of water winding past. But the reader is not forever lost in Turner's ennobling vision; Mr. Hill's animated and meticulous descriptions of Turner's working methods, often including a contemporary photo of the landscape pictured, provide the perfect counterpoint to the artist's dreamy impressions of a great river on its seaward journey.SIRI HUNTOON

title: Skiers' Strolling Fingers
description: Looking for a masseuse in Killington or a snowboard shop in Whistler, British Columbia? Listings that cover these and other whims -- along with hotels, restaurants and, naturally, ski resorts -- are contained in the Yellow Pages of Skiing, published by Activity Directories International. The book costs $14.95 plus $2.50 postage; to order, call (800) 864-2754.

title: Wall Street; Is Paramount Really Worth That Price?
description: IT'S the sort of rationale every mother uses when buying the hopelessly oversized winter coat for her kid: He'll grow into it.

title:
THEATER;
How a Lone Producer Gambled on an Epic
description: "The Kentucky Cycle" by Robert Schenkkan is an anomaly on Broadway. It won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1992 yet had never played New York. At $2.5 million, it is the most expensive serious play ever mounted on Broadway. One hundred dollars buys a ticket to the six-hour production; you cannot purchase either half separately. Stacy Keach is the only household name in the 21-member acting ensemble that performs 73 roles. The director, Warner Shook, has never worked on Broadway before, nor has the producer, David Richenthal.

title: From Smoky Saigon Bars To Stateside Concerts
description: When the folk singers who perform in the In Country Revue talk about unfriendly theaters, take their word for it. They mean downright deadly.

title: Forever '21'
description: '21' CLUB ** (212) 582-7200; 21 West 52d Street; $$$$; all major cards

title: A Law Firm Open to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Head Injuries: the Long Road Back
description: FROM her wheelchair Jessica Bogin, 17, spoke about the accident two years ago that left her paralyzed from the waist down. She told about piling eight people into a car, sitting on a friend's lap and being thrown when the car was broadsided.

title: For Its Bicentennial, Louvre Gets a New Look
description: THE newest and most ambitious chapter in the Louvre's modern history is about to begin. On Nov. 18, France's grand museum will wrap itself in pomp and glitter to celebrate its bicentennial and announce that it has become the largest cultural complex in the world. In one fell swoop, it will double its exhibition space to a bit more than 70,000 square yards (almost 15 acres) by opening a mammoth new wing flanking the Rue de Rivoli, occupied for close to a century by the Finance Ministry.

title: Bulls Bid Adieu To Lord Of Rings
description: One last time, the countdown to Michael Jordan began, as it had for nine memorable years.

title: Holyfield Wins Title in Bout Marked by the Bizarre
description: Evander Holyfield survived history, a younger, bigger opponent, and a bizarre delay after a parachutist landed in the ropes in a fight he was dominating, to regain his heavyweight title tonight from Riddick Bowe.

title: M. J. Wildrick, James C. Thomas
description: Margaret Jeanne Wildrick, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Kenyon J. Wildrick of Millington, N.J., was married yesterday to James Conrad Thomas, the son of Mrs. James Rodney Crombie of New York and Conrad Thomas of Ventura, Calif. The bride's father, a Congregational minister, officiated at Morrow Memorial Methodist Church in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Softening A Move's Tax Bite
description: ANYONE moving from a more expensive home to a less expensive one is probably aware that such a move could trigger a capital gains tax. That is why most people go out of their way to make sure they are buying a home that costs as much as or more than the one they are selling.

title: The Very Middle Of Midtown
description: AQUAVIT ** (212) 307-7311; 13 West 54th Street; $$$$; all major credit cards

title:
DINING OUT;
Festive Spirit at Mamaroneck Landmark
description: IN all seasons, strings of jolly holiday lights mark the entrance to this neighborhood dining spot situated in a charming, rickety 1792 landmark, for a time the home of the writer James Fenimore Cooper. Inside, beyond the bar and leaded-glass transom, more of those tiny lights festoon a dim, cozy dining room brightened further by pink tablecloths under glass and by glittery hurricane sconces.

title: Alice Kornfeld, Gordon Osinoff
description: Alice D. Kornfeld, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe W. Kornfeld of Scarsdale, N.Y. was married last evening to Gordon Osinoff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Osinoff, also of Scarsdale. Rabbi Steven Klein officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Columbia's Best Efforts Doomed by Dartmouth's Fiedler
description: Entering yesterday's fourth quarter at Baker Field's Wien Stadium, Columbia found itself in a thoroughly unfamiliar position: holding the lead.

title: Fordham Tops Colgate To End 10-Game Slide
description: Fordham 17, Colgate 13

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: We live in an age that has time to criticize when something goes wrong, but rarely recognizes good deeds.

title: SUNDAY, November 7, 1993; VEGGING OUT
description: Pity the fan who wanted a disk by Smashing Pumpkins but forgot the name and bought one by Screaming Trees (it was just awful). No wonder. Other new botanical bands are Blind Melon, Lemonheads, Cypress Hill, Gin Blossoms and the Cranberries.

title: After a Small Respite, Murders Soar in the 75th
description: On a recent chilly morning, Allan Bouser was keeping warm in his red Toyota Corolla parked at a curb near Alabama and Cozine Avenues when six gunshots rang out. Two bullets shattered the car's rear window and tore through Mr. Bouser's back and left arm. He died a couple of hours later. The motive is unknown, according to the police.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate

title: A Journalist's Torch Lies Fallen
description: On a small plot of trees and shrubs at the border of Jackson Heights and Elmhurst in Queens, seven neighborhood residents were scattered recently on benches in Manuel de Dios Unanue Triangle.

title: Morris Hamburg, Professor, 80
description: Morris Hamburg, a retired professor of educational administration at Brooklyn College, died on Wednesday at his home in San Diego. He was 80. The cause of death was a brain tumor, according to his wife, Marian Hamburg.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FOOTBALL 3RD DOWN AND FOREVER Joe Don Looney and the Rise and Fall of an American Hero. By J. Brent Clark. St. Martin's, $21.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PERSIAN POETRY

title: Pennsylvania Grand Jury Urges Ouster of Justice
description: A special state grand jury has found "no credible evidence" to substantiate accusations made by Justice Rolf Larsen that a colleague on the Pennsylvania Supreme Court took kickbacks and another tried to run him down with a car.

title: What's the Problem? He Won't Say.
description: In "The Remains of the Day," the Merchant-Ivory film that opened on Friday, Anthony Hopkins plays the butler at a stately English manor. Emma Thompson is the housekeeper. They have worked together and lived under the same roof for years. He is truly, madly, deeply in love with her, and she with him. But he has never told her. They have never exchanged more than the most proper pleasantries. In a climactic scene, she (not for the first time) tries to back him into an emotional corner by telling him she has agreed to marry another man. His only response is to inform her of some dusting that needs to be done upstairs and to bid her goodnight.

title: One Person Made a Difference
description: NEVER STOP RUNNING Allard Lowenstein and the Struggle to Save American Liberalism. By William H. Chafe. Illustrated. 556 pp. New York: Basic Books. $28.

title: Taxi Panel Sets Hearing On Possible Fare Increase
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission is planning to hold a hearing this month on whether to impose a fare increase by early next year, a commission official said yesterday.

title: Yearning for the Familiar, From Far Away
description: AS anyone who has suffered from it knows, there are two strains of homesickness: the first half-comic and easily cured, the second much more virulent and harder to shake. I speak with some authority, since at various times in my traveling career I have suffered from both versions, to the point where, at worst, I've cut trips short and hightailed it home, and where, at best, this oddly nostalgic, bittersweet longing for things familiar has furrowed even the happiest of my travels with some deep sloughs of despond.

title: Deborah Novick, Todd Goldberg
description: Deborah Ruth Novick, the daughter of Susan and Jeffrey Novick of Syosset, L.I., was married last evening to Todd Alan Goldberg, a son of Phyllis and Marshall Goldberg of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report on Oct. 24 giving crime statistics for the 68th Precinct, and a corrected version last Sunday, referred incorrectly to the section of Brooklyn covered by the precinct. The section, Bay Ridge, is in southern Brooklyn; South Brooklyn is generally considered to encompass Cobble Hill, Red Hook and Carroll Gardens.

title: Administration Settles on a New Rights Nominee
description: Senior Administration officials say President Clinton will soon nominate John Payton, a Washington lawyer, to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, despite sharp reservations from some members of the Congressional Black Caucus.

title: Figured It Out, Have You, Mr. Hawkins?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Sunshine, Mr. Hirsch
description: Deborah Lynn Sunshine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Sunshine of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening to David Lawrence Hirsch, a son of Patricia Hirsch of White Plains. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: Topics of The Times; Hating New York -- and Loving It
description: New Yorkers complained loudly about their city during the recent mayoral campaign -- and they found plenty to be unhappy about in responding to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll. Sixty-five percent viewed the economy as bad; 59 percent found the city less safe than four years ago; 67 percent said race relations were poor; 70 percent didn't like the schools.

title: Unfair to Stoneham And O'Malley
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Promotion For Mr. Chips
description: "ANYBODY who believes that all you have to do to be a good teacher is to love to teach also has to believe that all you have to do to be a good surgeon is to love to cut."

title: Resurrecting A Rail Yard: A New Hitch
description: For decades, the Harlem River Rail Yard has been abandoned, a forlorn stretch of rickety tracks in Port Morris that once teemed with freight cars transporting coal, lumber and other cargo. A proposal to resurrect the yard would create jobs and revitalize the sagging neighborhood, supporters say. Critics of the plan say it doesn't go far enough to reduce dependence on trucks.

title: Propelled by the Power of Arms, Wheels and Will
description: When Bob Neumayer lines up for his eighth New York City Marathon next Sunday, it will be symbolic not only of how far he has come but of how far wheelchair racing has advanced as well.

title: New York's Black Political Leaders Waste No Time in Going Back to Drawing Board
description: Deeply shaken by last week's defeat of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a group of more than 100 black politicians and community leaders met in a Harlem high school yesterday to assess what went wrong and plan how to resurrect the political power that came with the election of the city's first black mayor.

title: A Playwright Shoots a Film (In Its Heart)
description: The theater and the cinema are not necessarily mortal enemies, but you wouldn't know it if you listen to playwrights on the subject of movie making. Playwrights can get pretty riled up when they write about Hollywood -- land of the ruthless, the craven, the pea-brained, the face-lifted.

title: THE RELUCTANT STAR
description: In "The Reluctant Star" (Oct. 17), Janet Maslin focuses on the aspect of Jeff Bridges's acting that I admire the most -- his chameleonlike ability to disappear into his roles. It is a rare talent and the hallmark of a true actor. One goes from asking "Who was that guy?" to saying, "That must have been Jeff Bridges because I couldn't tell who it was." CAROL S. LINDQUIST Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Yeltsin Backs Away From Early Presidential Election
description: Backing off a promise to hold an early presidential election next June, President Boris N. Yeltsin told a group of Russian newspaper editors today that he wanted to stay in office until his term expires in 1996.

title: 1 Evening, 2 Plays, 2 Languages
description: THE Pregones Theater, which offers bilingual performances in the Bronx, begins its 15th season this week with a two-play presentation.

title: 'Sheer Boredom': Questions of Existence
description: HOW do three men, trapped in humdrum jobs that sentence them to lifetime membership in the fraternity of unnoticed people, turn mere subsistence into meaningful existence?

title: Two for Time
description: Two ultra-thin, beautifully designed travel clocks from the Museum of Modern Art gift shop will take up little space in luggage or briefcase.

title: Beirut Airport Gets Facelift, Tighter Security
description: Much of the violent recent history of Lebanon was played out at or near Beirut International Airport.

title: Paula L. Lockamy, Craig F. Stout
description: Paula Lyn Lockamy, the daughter of Mrs. Nubron D. Whitley of Tarboro, N.C., and Dr. Thomas B. Lockamy Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va., was married yesterday to Craig Fitzhugh Stout, a son of Julie J. Stout and Anthony C. Stout, both of Washington. The Rev. Mark H. Mullin officiated at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Chester's Many Gifts Of History
description: THE city of Chester, in northern England, is an enormous gift box, overflowing with nearly 2,000 years of history. Holding it all together is its wall, unique in Britain and two miles in length, which encircles the city like a ribbon. A leisurely stroll of an hour or two will take you around the top of the wall, but several days are necessary to explore the city.

title: The 'Miracle' at St. Malachy's
description: One of Broadway's oldest institutions, St. Malachy's, known as the Actors' Chapel, is celebrating its revival today with the completion of a $2 million restoration. The dark, decrepit neo-Gothic church, built in 1903, has been transformed into a bright and welcoming sanctuary.

title: Public & Private; Dumb About Smarts
description: Mirian Acosta-Sing has a problem. She's the principal of a New York City public school, a school whose students are almost entirely black and Latino, with income levels low enough to qualify for free lunches, in a neighborhood in which fifth and sixth graders are importuned by dealers to take lucrative work as drug runners.

title: Kennedy Museum Reopens in Boston
description: The museum at the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston reopened on Oct. 30 after a year-long renovation, with new multimedia exhibits designed to give visitors an immediate experience of the Kennedy era.

title: New London's Larger World in a School
description: THE school on Bulkeley Place, near New London's business district, is made of granite blocks and vaulted towers, a reminder of a time when public buildings were constructed with style and not simply as rectangular boxes.

title: Arts Center Stirs Newark's Hopes
description: THE groundbreakers at a special ceremony do not generally number 39 honored guests, but the groundbreaking here for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center was an event at which symbolism was important. Political, business and arts leaders, and children from every county in the state, participated in the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SOCIAL HISTORY LAND OF DESIRE Merchants, Power, and the Rise of a New American Culture. By William Leach. Pantheon, $30.

title: The Peace Deficit
description: The prospect of peace in the Middle East has everyone giddy. So many promises, so many dreams, so many inevitable editorial references to walls "tumblin' down" in Jericho. There are those who have sworn to undermine the agreement between Israel and the P.L.O., but even these extremists seem to cling to a utopian vision of their own -- namely, that the other side will just sort of cheerfully go away, much as future Serbian textbooks will no doubt portray Bosnia's Muslims as having done.

title: Deng and His Little Red Book
description: For many Chinese, it must have been shocking to hear China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping arguing that instability is good.

title: Candida in Polyester
description: LOST IN JERSEY CITYBy Paula Sharp.358 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $20.

title: LITTLE BIG PEOPLE
description: I am 13, in the eighth grade, and I agree with your article that children are being forced to grow up too fast. I watch my peers trying to regress, in a sense, to the childhood they "missed." They consider it cool to carry a Barney lunch box or to know the words to the "Sesame Street" theme song. I see my friends acting "less mature" than third-graders. I don't think they know that people are saying they missed their childhood, but they seem to be having a lot of fun trying to regain it. LINDSAY RICHARDSON Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Clinton Plan Rewards Big Insurers
description: To the Editor:

title: Arithmetic of the Avenues
description: Hunting for an address on an avenue in Manhattan without knowing the cross street does not have to be difficult. Just drop the last figure, divide by 2 and add or subtract as indicated below. The answer is the nearest numbered cross street. This key does not apply to Broadway below Eighth Street because of the many street with names rather than numbers.

title: Health Plan Is Toughest On Doctors Making Most
description: After a quarter century of surging incomes that made many of them millionaires, the nation's doctors now face the prospect of stable or shrinking pay.

title: THE DOUBLE-BED PRINCIPLE
description: As I read E. J. Graff's Hers column "The Double-Bed Principle" (Oct. 17), I wavered between empathy and wanting to say to her: "Just live your life, lady! Get over it!"

title: Carolina Crafts
description: To the Editor: I read Suzanne Carmichael's article "An Appalachian Trail for Carolina Crafts Seekers" (Oct. 17) and thought that your readers might also like to know that an exhibition called "North Carolina in New York," displaying the works of over 100 North Carolina fine arts and crafts artists, will be on view at the National Arts Club on Gramercy Park in New York through Nov. 23. KRISTEN L. MORAN New York, N.Y.

title: It's Only the Game
description: IT was an odd procession of two decidedly different groups of young men that met outside Rye High School here on the morning before last Saturday's Rye-Harrison football game.

title: Profile: Laura S. Scher; She Took One Look At the Age of Greed And Made a Quick Left
description: LAURA S. SCHER graduated from Harvard Business School near the top of her class in 1985, smack in the middle of the Decade of Greed.

title: Fellini's World Was So Real It Was Bizarre
description: In a section of New York where an old Italian neighborhood intersected art galleries and chi-chi restaurants, I once turned a corner and walked into the middle of a religious procession. Altar boys in red-and-white costumes were heading toward me carrying large candles; behind them men carried a large statue of the Blessed Virgin on their shoulders; on this gentrified street people were singing in Latin. The one word that came to mind was Felliniesque.

title: Professionals Sent Back to Class
description: IN EDUCATION circles, what's sauce for the goose is sauce for an increasingly old and wise gander. Like secondary-school teachers who must submit to periodic competency testing, a wide variety of professionals, from dentists to financial planners, are being pressed to recertify their skills.

title: Karen Porush, Thomas Trowbridge
description: Karen Hope Porush, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome G. Porush of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas Allen Trowbridge, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Trowbridge of Chicago. Cantor David Benedict and the Rev. John Gillham, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Color Relationships in Valhalla, Family Ties in White Plains
description: WITH its prettily landscaped campus, Westchester Community College here is an exhibition in itself. This was especially true last week when trees like blazing beacons were busy upstaging "Color Options," the show on view in the college's Fine Arts Gallery.

title: A Narrow Road to the Old Arabia
description: YEMEN's lure is its Spartan and pristine settings, not unlike those of such other out-of-the-way places as Bhutan, Madagascar, Patagonia or Macedonia. The monochromatic skyscrapers and nouveau Arabian architecture, which characterize most of the Gulf of Aden, have yet to ruin Yemen. And not only are the mud-walled dwellings, framed by graceful whitewashed lines, intact, but the Government issues few permits for new buildings over five stories and insures that the ancient architectural style is respected, if not copied.

title: LITTLE BIG PEOPLE
description: As a historian, I study 15th-century Milan and cannot help noticing the age at which people in that culture take on responsible positions in society. Young men of 17 or 18 sit on the duke's advisory council; people marry at 15 and shoulder family responsibilities; wisdom is exhibited, in those who have it, in late adolescence. Mathematics and music, in other words, are not the only areas in which precocity can play a role.

title: For Night People in Need
description: NEW YORK has many services to meet the nocturnal needs of the sick and harried. Here are a few. Key: B (will go to Brooklyn); Q (to Queens); Bx (to the Bronx). DENTISTS All City Emergency Services (B,Q,Bx) . . . (212) 286-0716 Dentist Referral (B,Q,Bx) . . . (212) 679-3966 Preventative Dental Associates . . .
