title: Pact Has Few Votes From New York Region
description: As evidence of the steep hill President Clinton must climb if he is to win Congressional approval next week of the North American Free Trade Agreement, no Democrat in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations in the House of Representatives is committed to voting for it.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Ruling on Sexual Harassment in Workplace
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today on sexual harassment in the workplace. The Court ruled unamimously that workers suing their employers for sexual harassment need not show that they suffered psychological injury. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the opinion, Harris v. Forklift systems. While joining the opinion, Justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg also filed separate concurring opinions. BY JUSTICE O'CONNOR, For the Court

title: At Haiti-Dominican Border: Barrier or Loophole?
description: More a creek than a river, the Rio Artibonito forms the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic, and for as long as the two countries have existed people on both sides have often just waded across at points like this whenever they wanted to trade with each other.

title: American Consumer Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
TRADING IS HALTED IN AMERICAN SHIP BUILDING SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange halted trading yesterday in the common stock of the American Ship Building Company because the company no longer met the criteria for listing, the exchange said. The value of the company's publicly traded shares fell below the exchange's minimum of $5 million, the stock exchange said. American Ship, whose chairman is George M. Steinbrenner, the owner of the New York Yankees, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last Thursday. After the suspension, an application will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to delist American Ship.

title: Studies Suggest Estrogen Lowers Alzheimer's Risk
description: Women who take estrogen after menopause appear to reduce their risk of getting Alzheimer's disease and, if they do get it, to have milder symptoms, scientists reported today.

title: Spicy Food for the Bean Wary
description: LEGUMES, with their delightful texture and robust flavor, are a near-perfect source of nutrition. As new ethnic foods and assertive seasonings are incorporated into mainstream cuisine in this country, dishes like black beans from Cuba, curried lentils from India and fava-bean fritters from the Middle East are becoming more visible.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Benefits column of Styles of The Times on Sunday about a fund-raiser to be held tomorrow at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, honoring Ted Turner and journalists from five countries who have demonstrated a commitment to freedom of the press, misidentified the sponsoring organization. It is the Committee to Protect Journalists (not "Society").

title: No Headline
description: "There is a mood here that if someone came to the floor and said we should barbwire the ankles of anyone who jaywalks, I think it would pass." SENATOR JOSEPH R. BIDEN, of Delaware. [ A1:2. ]

title: Grand Central Television
description: On Manhattan's East 42d Street, there's an enormous room with Tennessee marble floors, an extraordinary staircase, 75-foot windows and a sky-blue ceiling, 10 or so stories high, that's soon to be twinkling once more with golden stars. Doesn't sound like the kind of place to which a 60-square-foot television screen would add much, does it? But it's about to get one just the same.

title: Sports of The Times; Bradley's Eloquent Teacher
description: IT may be surprising to learn that Moses Malone is only 38 years old, not even the elder statesman of the National Basketball Association. He seems to have been around, if not since the beginning of time, then at least before the creation of the 24-second clock.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18 CHINA WEIGHS VISITS TO PRISONERS China said it was considering allowing the Red Cross to visit political prisoners, a signal of what would be a major shift on human rights. A1 Russia will provide military technology to China. A15

title: Restoring Marsala's Reputation
description: IN kitchen lore, Marsala means a splash in the pan -- a cheap fortified Sicilian cooking wine in screw-cap bottles, often found next to the vinegar on grocery shelves.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Volkswagen and G.M. Seeking Settlement
description: At the urging of a German court, Volkswagen A.G. and the General Motors Corporation agreed today to make an attempt at an out-of-court settlement of the civil dispute stemming from the defection in March of seven G.M. managers who followed Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua to Volkswagen.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL AGREES TO BUY STATE FIRST FINANCIAL
description: The First Commercial Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to buy the closely held State First Financial Corporation of Texarkana, Tex., in a stock swap valued at $110 million. The acquisition of State First, which has assets of $713 million, will double First Commercial's presence in the banking market in southwest Arkansas and northeast Texas. Under the agreement, State First's shares will be exchanged for 3.37 million shares of First Commercial. The ratio of the exchange was not disclosed. Shares of First Commercial rose 50 cents, to $32.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Quantum Restaurant Group Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Include 6 cents a share charge related to settlement of lawsuit.c-Included extraordinary income of $ 347,000, or 6 cents a share, from the early extinguishment of debt in the quarter, and the 9 months was after an extraordinary charge of $ 3,699,000, which included gain of $ 272,000, or 6 cents a share, from net operating loss carryforward, offset by a charge of $ 3,971,000 from early retirement of debt.d-Net loss

title: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Increase in shares outstanding from the year-ago periods reflects the company's two public stock offerings in October 1992 and September 1993.

title: Chairman to Retire From Bowes, Dentsu
description: Murray R. Bowes, the chairman and chief executive of Bowes, Dentsu & Partners in Los Angeles, unexpectedly announced yesterday that he would retire on June 30 from the direct-response agency he founded six years ago.

title: Livery Driver Shot
description: A livery driver was shot and killed by a passenger in the Bronx yesterday, and the police said he was the 38th cabby to die on the job this year. The victim, a 44-year-old man who was not immediately identified, was shot while he drove down West 188th Street around 8:20 P.M., said Sgt. Frances Haimeck, a police spokeswoman. The driver, who was struck in the upper chest, was taken to North Central Bronx Hospital, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The gunman fled.

title: Chad Therapeutics (ECM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 162,500, or 2 cents a share, and $ 311,500, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 123,300, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 202,700, or 3 cents a share, in the 6 months.Share earnings and comparisons for the quarter and 6 months reflect a restatement to include the 3 percent stock dividend paid in April to shareholders of record on March 31, 1993, and the 2-for-1 stock split distributed on Oct. 15, 1993, to shareholders of record on Oct. 1, 1993.

title: U.S. Should Preach Less to the World
description: To the Editor:

title: The Food, You Can Be Proud to Say, Is in the Mail
description: CHEESECAKES and chocolate cakes, ice creams and butter creams, goat cheese and sheep cheese. In hot pursuit of the best food available by mail, somewhere in the neighborhood of 8,000 samples (well, make it 16,000) have passed my lips over the last dozen years.

title: Wine Talk
description: FRENCH wine drinkers are a tradition-bound lot. They may flirt with all kinds of wines, but sooner or later they return to that basic trinity of French wines, Champagne, red Bordeaux and white Burgundy.

title: Mistakes Are Islanders' Only Consistency
description: Tonight's 5-2 loss to the Winnipeg Jets was an embarrassment to the Islanders. Although Aleksei Zhamnov scored a hat trick for the Jets, the winning goal was scored by Tie Domi, a gnome-like brawler who used to pester the Islanders when he was a Ranger enforcer.

title: Primadonna Resorts Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 4.8 million charge for reinstating deferred income taxes in connection with the company's June 1993 initial public offering and the termination of its S Corporation status. The period also included a $ 141,000 loss on a tax adjustment due to the increase in income taxes.c-Pro forma. Assumed the firm was a public company for all reporting periods, and therefore excluded the impact of reinstating deferred income taxes.d-Included a charge of $ 677,000 for interest costs associated with a distribution of accumulated previously taxed earnings in the form subordinated notes that were outstanding from May 1 to June 29.

title: Maxwell Advisers Seen As Winners in Breakup
description: Regardless of the outcome of today's auction of Macmillan Inc., some clear winners in the deal will be the advisers to Maxwell Communication, the parent company of Macmillan.

title: PS GROUP PLANS TO SELL ITS TRAVEL-MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: PS Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its largest unit, a travel-management business, for about $46 million to the Pritzker family of Chicago, by the end of the year. The Pritzkers, who own several closely held businesses, including the Hyatt Corporation hotel chain and the cruise-ship operator Regency Cruises Inc., are to buy an 85 percent stake in the unit, USTravel Systems. The remaining 15 percent is owned by the shareholders of the unit. PS Group, an aircraft leasing and fuel-distribution company, said it expected to record a pretax profit from the sale of $27 million to $29 million and planned to use the proceeds to retire bank debt. PS Group's stock jumped $2.25, to $13.875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, where its 19 percent gain was the best of the day.

title: Clearing a Path as a Restaurateur From Busboy to Empire Builder
description: ARMED with emphatic opinions, a talent for shaping trends, and a volatile temper, Pino Luongo has been cutting a swath of style and controversy through New York's restaurant scene. Even his detractors concede he has excellent taste.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FEW foods are as all-American as chili, whether it is rich Texas-style chili con carne, fiery Arizona style or the myriad variations in between. In France we had all sorts of meat pies and ground meat dishes, but nothing approximating chili.

title: Personal Health
description: FOR many years, American women thought they were relatively immune to heart disease, long the leading killer of American men. But now a tide of information intended to dispel this myth has many thinking that heart disease is the newest epidemic to afflict women.

title: Yeltsin Promotes a Charter That Is Very Much His
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin went on national television tonight to open his campaign for a new constitution that he promised would help restore "law and order" to a country that has seen little of either in the last two years.

title: Judge Says Health Panel Erred by Withholding Data
description: A Federal district judge said today that the White House was improperly withholding records of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform from doctors and consumer groups that wanted to scrutinize the panel's work.

title: Trimark Holdings (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Satisfactory Marriage; Many Economists See Boon to Competition In Merger of Cable and Phone Companies
description: The proposed $32 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications may turn out to be not only the biggest deal yet, but also one of the most scrutinized.

title: Questar Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 1,110,000 in the quarter and $ 2,772,000 in the 9 months.c-Included a loss of $ 633,000 in the quarter and income of $ 7,366,000, or 18 cents a share, in the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.Questar said that during this year's third quarter, the federal income tax rate increased to 35 percent, retroactive to the beginning of the year. The new rate decreased this year's third quarter net by $ 800,000.

title: Dr. Mark Straus, 84, Adviser for Fur Trade
description: Dr. Mark Straus, a medical consultant in the New York fur trade who had fought with the Loyalists in the Spanish Civil War, died on Oct. 27 at his home in the Bronx. He was 84.

title:
Office Relocation;
Connecticut Helps to Lure A Business
description: In the continuing regional battle for jobs, Connecticut has coaxed a direct-marketing services company that had been in Armonk, N.Y., for 37 years to move its 175 employees to a vacant office building in Greenwich.

title: Germans Sigh As One Nov. 9 Passes Easily
description: On the German calendar, this date is eerier and more disturbing than any other, a date that has marked four of the country's most dramatic turning points in this century.

title: Shearson Name May Disappear
description: Smith Barney Shearson, created three months ago in the merger of two Wall Street brokerage firms, may drop the Shearson from its title, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: D. Martin Carter, 57, Dermatology Expert
description: Dr. D. Martin Carter, a research dermatologist and cell biologist at Rockefeller University, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57.

title: Mostar's Old Bridge Battered to Death
description: Croatian gunners destroyed the renowned Old Bridge in the Bosnian city of Mostar today, sending one of the most graceful examples of Ottoman architecture crashing into the Neretva River.

title: Randers Group (ECM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Span-America Medical Systems Inc. coei>(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a charge of $ 958,328 from the retirement of its former chairman and chief executive.c-After a gain of $ 81,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Two Challenges for the House Campaign Finance Reform, Redux
description: As we expected, the Democratic campaign finance legislation finally moving in the House is not as strong as it ought to be. Indeed, the weaker points in this legislation are not accidental creations. They stand as monuments to months of purposeful procrastination by House Speaker Thomas Foley. Mr. Foley, on behalf of the careerist Democrats sheltering behind him, refused all pleas to put the legislation on a fast-track spring or summer agenda. He knew his history. Delay is the career pol's strongest weapon against the reform fevers that rage right after a national election.

title: Atkinson (Guy F.) Co. of California (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4,974,000, or 57 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment and an after-tax gain of $ 7.2 million from the sale of the company's headquarters property.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 250,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months.Guy F. Atkinson Co. said that it had a pretax loss of $ 596,000 in its latest third quarter, but said a provision for recovery of income taxes offset the loss and resulted in net income of $ 83,000.

title: Utility Venture Is Expected
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable television system operator in the United States, is set to announce soon that it has reached an agreement with an electric utility company that ultimately will tie in a home's heating, appliances and wiring with cable television and telephone services.

title: Paris Journal; France's Homeless Get Help! Read All About It!
description: After a chilly night huddled in blankets outside the Musee d'Orsay, Georges was up with the sun and ready for a morning's work selling Macadam Journal at an open-air market near the Seine in Paris's elegant 16th arrondissement. By noon, he had earned enough for a good lunch.

title: Thermo Fibertek reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Evans Environ. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
France Arrests 88 Suspected Islamic Militants
description: Apparently in reprisal for the kidnapping of three French citizens by Islamic militants in Algeria last month, the French police today arrested 88 suspected members or sympathizers of the Islamic Salvation Front who are living in France.

title: Adage Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-Net incomeAdage said that the acquisition of the Bendix/King land mobile radio product line in September had little effect on third quarter results.

title: Life Can Continue After Kidney Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: A.L. Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from results of the Human Nutrition business sold in September 1992 of $ 4,035,000, or 23 cents a share, and $ 4,809,000, or 28 cents share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Year-ago results for the 9 months are restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS 109, which increased net income to $ 1,013,000, or 5 cents a diluted share.

title: Landeta Cut; Ex-Bronco Takes Over
description: After nine seasons as the Giants' punter, Sean Landeta was abruptly cut yesterday and replaced by Mike Horan, a nine-year veteran who played for seven seasons under Giants Coach Dan Reeves at Denver and is known for his accuracy.

title: Intuit Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Open-and-Shut Encounter for Knicks at Garden
description: A scintillating home opener it was not.

title: Hanger Orthopedic Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary noncash nonrecurring charge of $ 39,000 in the quarter and 9 months.c-Net lossHanger Orthopedic Group said that the revenues reported for the latest 9 months included less than one month of operating results of the Precision Fit Brace, which was acquired on Sept. 1.The company also said the quarter did not include any of the operating results from the acquisition of Billing Comfort Shoes on Oct. 4, or the Institute for the Advancement of Prosthetics, a prosthetic patient care business acquired on Oct. 19.Net income in the latest third quarter was reduced by about $ 200,000 from the manufacturing labor and corporate infrastructure expenses incurred to help facilitate expected growth in 1994.

title: Bridge
description: It is always irritating to reach an excellent contract, devise a careful plan of play and fail. The irritation is compounded when the post-mortem reveals that a pedestrian course of action would have succeeded.

title: Bonds Gets Another M.V.P. Award
description: He still hasn't reached the World Series, but Barry Bonds yesterday attained a distinction no player ever had achieved: Bonds was named the National League most valuable player for the third time in four seasons.

title: Daly, Breaking His Silence, Denies Drinking Again
description: Speaking publicly for the first time since he was suspended from the PGA Tour on Sunday, a contrite John Daly apologized yesterday for his conduct and said he would not appeal the suspension imposed by Commissioner Deane Beman.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC. (N)
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the country's largest retailer, reported another quarter of strong sales and earnings yesterday, continuing to prosper in spite of the stock market's concern that the company's string of successes is almost over.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It may be nine years since Senator JOHN GLENN ran for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but the memories linger on, or at least the campaign debts do. So the four-term Ohio Senator and former astronaut has found himself on what might be called a retrospective fund-raising party trail in hopes of erasing those debts. He is coming to New York for a party on Monday at the studio of the artist PETER MAX, on West 65th Street. Vice President Al Gore has said he will attend, and the organizers hope it will raise $400,000.

title: H & R Block Spinoff
description: H & R Block Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off its temporary personnel business through an initial public offering. The sale of the unit, Interim Services Inc., would raise up to $195 million for H & R Block, which operates a chain of more than 9,500 tax preparation offices in the United States and overseas. The 10 million shares, which represent H & R Block's entire stake in Interim Services, will be sold for $17.50 to $19.50 each, according to a registration statement filed last Friday. Interim Services, based in Leawood, Kan., is the fourth-largest provider of temporary employees and the second-largest provider of temporary health care personnel in North America, according to the S.E.C. filing.

title: Cortines Calls For Standards In Teaching
description: Arguing that New York City's schools need more rigorous classroom guidelines, the city's Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday that he has ordered the preparation of a core curriculum that would set citywide standards for what to teach and when to teach it.

title: News Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After abnormal items of $ 10.9 million in the latest first quarter and $ 16.3 million in year-ago period, primarily due to unrealized foreign exchange losses on U.S. dollar borrowings at Ansett.Share earnings and shares outstanding are in American Depositary Receipt (ADR).Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Ben Feldman, 81, Dies; Was Premier Salesman
description: Ben Feldman, whom industry experts called the greatest life-insurance salesman of all time, died on Sunday in West Penn Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 81 and lived in East Liverpool, Ohio.

title: 47 New Death Penalties. Big Deal.
description: In the 1993 crime bill working its way through Congress, the proposals to put more police officers on the beat nationwide and to construct new high-security prisons are sound. Little else deserves support. The bill lacks a coherent national anticrime strategy. It is a potpourri of programs that offers something to everyone -- except perhaps those who live in fear of violent crime.

title: Algoma Central reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Safeguard Health Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * California Pollution Control Financing Authority is selling $200 million of tax-exempt pollution control revenue bonds for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The 5.85 percent bonds are priced at about 99.299 to yield 5.90 percent, and for some investors these securities may be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax. Underwriters expect the issue to be rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corp. * Casino America Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., is selling $105 million of 11.5 percent first mortgage notes due in 2001 at a price of 100 through Salomon Brothers. Nonredeemable for four years, the notes are rated B-1 by Moody's and B by S.& P. The financing includes warrants to purchase 3 percent of the company.

title: Blessings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 406,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: Ag-Bag International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Jordanian Vote Endorses Peace Effort
description: Jordanians have given a strong endorsement to the Middle East peace effort by spurning Islamic militants whose principal platform was opposition to any peace talks with Israel.

title: 17 States in Vanguard of War on Smoking
description: WHILE most funerals are somber events, in Portland, Me., residents cheered last Friday as a local funeral director laid to rest a life-size model of Joe Camel, the advertising symbol for Camel cigarettes. The event and others like it around the country marked the start of the largest, most comprehensive effort ever undertaken against smoking.

title: Not Much New for Prodigy
description: Although the opening screen is noticeably improved, the "new" Prodigy on-line service looks much the same as it did before the Prodigy Services Company, the struggling joint venture of I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck & Company, ballyhooed the change in a multimillion-dollar publicity campaign that began this week.

title: Theater in Review
description: Promises, Promises Goodspeed Opera House East Haddam, Conn. Through Dec. 19 Book by Neil Simon, based on the screenplay "The Apartment" by Billy Wilder and I. A. L. Diamond; music by Burt Bacharach; lyrics by Hal David; directed and choreographed by Ted Pappas; musical direction, Michael O'Flaherty; scenery by James Noone; costumes by Deborah Newhall; lighting by Kirk Bookman; orchestrations by Keith Levenson and Andrew Wilder; stage manager, Donna Cooper Hilton; produced by Michael P. Price. Presented by Goodspeed Opera House. WITH: Jim Athens, P. J. Benjamin; Linda Bloom, Paul A. Brown, Michael Cone, John Deyle, Cynthia Khoury, Juliet Lambert, Joe Palmieri, Evan Pappas, Marilyn Pasekoff, Steve Pudenz, Robert Roznowski, Avery Saltzman, Laurie Sheppard, Elizabeth S. Steers, Suzanne Van Johns, Mary P. Wanamaker, Rob Woronoff and Kayoko Yoshioka.

title: Ann Taylor Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 10,496,000 which reflects after-tax charge from refinancing.

title: Hallwood Energy Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax $ 11.2 million gain on lawsuit settlement.The company said share earnings are available to limited partners.Share earnings are in units.

title: Venture Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After an accounting gain of $ 10,323,000, or 61 cents a share, from the adoption of FAS 109.c-Included an extraordinary cost of $ 2,188,000 in the quarter and 9 months of terminating credit agreement.

title: Coca-Cola Reassigns 3 Beverage Brands
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had further widened its agency roster by realigning responsiblities for three of its brands.

title: Dow Drops 7.83 Points After a Run-Up Fizzles
description: The stock market has been yearning for more good news on the economy, but when the Government issued a surprisingly reassuring report on inflation yesterday, many investors seemed to evince only one reaction: ho-hum.

title: Producer Prices Fell In October
description: Prices received by American producers declined two-tenths of 1 percent in October, surprisingly strong reassurance that a pickup in the economy is not reviving inflation, Labor Department figures showed today.

title: N.H.L. Offers a Deal to Officials
description: The National Hockey League Officials Association, whose agreement with the league ends on Monday, received a proposal yesterday from Commissioner GARY BETTMAN. The four-year deal would increase the base salaries for first-year referees from $50,000 to $65,000 in the first year of the contract and to $80,000 by the fourth year. A referee with 10 years' experience would receive an increase from $80,000 to $125,000. The most senior referees would nearly double their salaries from $90,000 to $175,000. "This offer puts the N.H.L. referees well ahead of our counterparts in major league baseball or the N.B.A.," said Bettman.

title: Florio and Whitman Meet, And Some Advice Is Passed
description: For the first time since Election Day, Gov. Jim Florio and Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman met yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about exchanging coins at the Federal Reserve Bank's office in Manhattan misidentified an employee at the counter. She was Sandra Williams, not Joanna Grever. The article also misspelled the surname of the chief of the Government Bond Department. She is Grace Jaiman, not Taiman.

title: Overseas Shipholding Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included provision of $ 2.9 million for additional deferred taxes resulting from the increase in the federal statutory tax rate.c-Included gain of $ 8 million, or 24 cents a share, from the disposal of vessels.d-After a gain of $ 16 million, or 49 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Stoked by Ethnic Conflict, Refugee Numbers Swell
description: The spread of ethnic conflict since the end of the cold war has pushed the number of refugees to 44 million people, or more than one in every 130 inhabitants of the globe, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reported today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about a study of three drugs used to treat heart attacks overstated the findings. As the article stated, two drugs, magnesium and nitrates like nitroglycerin, showed little or no benefit; the third, captopril, showed a small benefit.

title: Enterra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fresenius USA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Fresenius USA said that the increase in net income for the latest quarter and 9 months resulted from an increase in net sales, as well as certain economies of scale which the company was able to achieve as a result of increased production volumes.In addition, the company said it received additional revenues of about $ 3.5 million from bloodline sales during the latest quarter. The increased sales resulted from actions taken by the Food & Drug Administration, which temporarily banned the importation of bloodlines by one of the company's competitors.

title: Plaintiffs' Lawyers Applaud Decision
description: Lawyers said the Supreme Court's ruling yesterday on sexual harassment in the workplace meant that their clients would not have to show that the incidents drove them crazy in order to get their cases to a jury.

title: Review/Rock; Faith, Love And Death: It's Weighty
description: Johnette Napolitano, Concrete Blonde's bassist and singer, writes about weighty matters: faith, love, death, resurrection. She addresses them in a big voice, a mezzo-soprano that can be a bluesy growl or a clarion; like Ann Wilson of Heart, she has clearly listened to Grace Slick and Robert Plant. At the Academy on Thursday night, in a College Media Journal Marathon show, Ms. Napolitano's voice and her premeditated but unforced gestures filled her songs with drama.

title: 3 Women Accused of Making Firebomb
description: Three women from 18 to 21 years old were arrested on Monday and charged with helping to make a firebomb that was thrown into a fire engine, injuring three firefighters during a night of unrest in Washington Heights in July.

title: Review/Film: Carlito's Way; The Triumph of Atmosphere Over Detail in Spanish Harlem
description: When Carlito Brigante gets out of prison in 1975, he returns to Spanish Harlem as a street-smart Mr. Big. This has less to do with Carlito (a vaguely written, not-so-clever character) than it does with casting, since "Carlito's Way" brings Al Pacino back to familiar dramatic territory. Playing one more tough, savvy gangster, Mr. Pacino brings vast entertainment value to a film that otherwise would not make great sense. And Brian De Palma finally succeeds in a "Bonfire of the Vanities" vein, delivering a droll portrait of the disco years as seen through a bemused, jaundiced eye.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A promising Broadway moment . . . far off Broadway.

title: Let's Not Extend Morning Darkness in Winter
description: To the Editor:

title: Backtracking on the Baltics
description: Who's in charge of Russian foreign policy, Boris Yeltsin or the military? That question takes on new urgency after Defense Minister Pavel Grachev challenged Mr. Yeltsin's commitment to unconditional withdrawal of all 20,000 Russian troops from Latvia and Estonia.

title: Man and Boy Hurt After Being Hit by Subway
description: Holding his 5-year-old foster brother in his arms, a 27-year-old man jumped in front of a moving subway train yesterday, the police said.

title: A Murdered Writer's Prophecy
description: Three more Muslim extremists were executed in Egypt last week, bringing to 18 the number of militants put to death this year. At the end of October, militants assassinated a high-ranking police official in Qena, a southern town. Thus, as President Hosni Mubarak begins his third six-year term, Egypt continues the cycle of violence that has led to the deaths of more than 200 people in less than two years.

title: Top Black Studies Scholar Is Leaving Princeton for Harvard
description: Cornel West, a leading scholar of African-American studies and religion and a best-selling author, will move next fall from Princeton to Harvard.

title: Which Mayor Created That Big Deficit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Peak Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eating Well
description: WHO says people watching their diets, watching their fat, watching themselves, can't enjoy gifts of food at Christmas? Everything for the holidays is not made with cream and butter and chocolate.

title: A Wireless Upstart Gets Bigger
description: The revolution in wireless communications took a new turn yesterday as an upstart company acquired the capstone for a nationwide network that could give cellular phone companies and giants like A.T.& T. a run for their money.

title: John Boy Calling on the Videophone
description: John Boy Walton in cyberspace?

title: Ambar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Ban on Gun Sales to Minors Passes Senate Easily
description: After Senators told grim tales of gang violence in their states, they passed two measures today expanding Federal authority to prosecute crimes committed by gang members and making it a Federal crime to sell a pistol to a minor.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Society Starts an Annex
description: On Monday night, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center inaugurated its Music of Our Time series in the Walter Reade Theater. This venture seems to have grown out of difficulties encountered with contemporary music in the society's regular concerts at Alice Tully Hall; a smattering of new works will remain at Tully, but most will be taken by the new three-concert offshoot.

title: International Aluminum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,430,000, or 34 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Haggar Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Pro forma year-ago fourth quarter and fiscal share earnings were 71 cents a share and $ 1.69 a share, respectively. The company had its initial public offering in December 1992.Year-ago common share earnings are after preferred dividend requirements of $ 280,000 in the fourth quarter and $ 1,117,000 for the year. There were no preferred dividend requirements in the 1993 periods.

title: The Light That Raged, Then Died, 40 Years Ago
description: YESTERDAY, on the 40th anniversary of Dylan Thomas's death, a retired Welsh clergyman, who had married Miss Piggy and Kermit the Frog in one of the Muppet movies, and a waiter read the dead man's poems at his favorite table at the White Horse Tavern.

title: CHINA MAY ALLOW RED CROSS TO VISIT DISSIDENTS IN JAIL
description: Signaling what would be a major policy shift on human rights, China said today that it would give "positive consideration" to allowing the Red Cross to visit more than 3,000 political prisoners.

title: Accounts
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., New York, to FCB/Leber Katz & Partners, New York, to handle advertising and promotions for Palmolive Ultra, a superconcentrated automatic dishwashing detergent that uses enzymes to remove dried on food and stains from dishes. FCB/Leber Katz, which already handles all Palmolive brands, was awarded the account, with billings estimated at $23 million, without a review. * Nature's Best, Hauppauge, L.I., to Waring & LaRosa, New York, to handle advertising and promotion, previously at Wallack & Wallack, Great Neck, L.I. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE place: Waterbury, Conn. The time: Next to the last banking day before Halloween. The sign, spotted by Jack Manning, is posted in the lobby of the Bank of Boston, Connecticut branch, at Colonial Plaza:

title: CNN Extends Its Audience
description: Larry King threw a party for Al Gore and Ross Perot last night in the form of a free-swinging debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement. And the question is: who showed up?

title: A Southern Journal; Y'all Come Back, Now, Ecoutez, Professeurs?
description: Sure, they deconstructed the plantation world, saw a gala screening of the Southern epic "It's Grits," heard the Swiss Alpine bluesman Walter Liniger and pondered whether Scarlett O'Hara was a feminist.

title: I.B.M. Shows Successor to Mainframes
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a big new computer yesterday to replace its antiquated mainframe line. It also warned that it would not be able to commercially ship the new systems until late next year or 1995.

title: Gordon Ramsey, 63, A Singer and an Actor
description: Gordon Ramsey, an actor and a singer, died on Friday at his home in Grymes Hill, S.I. He was 63.

title: My Father's War
description: I was a kid during World War II and I loved the machinery of it. New cars, if there were any, could not be half as fascinating as bombers, and I tried to spot Junkers and Dorniers as easily as I could tell a Chrysler from a Chevy. If a Stuka dive-bombed Times Square this afternoon, I could still identify it by the outline. Other kids were following their fathers' Army careers, but it was not my father's war. He came here from Germany as a grown man, and when he went to the draft board the morning after Pearl Harbor to enlist, he was turned down because of age. So I drilled him on civil defense and I got all the flashcards of bomber outlines. I even got him to drive me out to Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn one night so I could look over the water and be the first to spot a Nazi air raid. When I think now of the blackout and gas rationing, it must have been a hell of a chore for him, but he did it uncomplainingly.

title: Courting the Israelis; With Barriers Down, Arab Lands Compete To Conclude Deals With an Ancient Enemy
description: The meeting between Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and King Hussein of Jordan last week provided a glimpse into a fascinating new phase of Middle East politics in which different Arab parties are tacitly forging alliances with Israel against one another.

title: Del Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Husband Tells Court of Sexual Mutilation by Wife
description: John Wayne Bobbitt, whose very personal suffering has gained him national notoriety, testified today that he tried to scream but could not when his wife cut off his penis with a kitchen knife on June 23.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY TO BUY DU PONT'S HALF OF VENTURE
description: The DNA Plant Technology Corporation, based in Cinaminson, N.J., said yesterday that it would buy the Du Pont Company's half-interest in the companies' Freshworld premium fruit and vegetable venture for a package valued at more than $30 million. Under the agreement, DNA Plant Technology will pay Du Pont about $1.5 million in cash, two million of its common shares, 2,750 shares of nondividend paying preferred stock convertible to 2.75 million shares of common stock, DNA's 28 percent interest in the Intermountain Canola Company and nonexclusive rights to certain DNA technology. DNA Plant Technology applies advanced breeding techniques and genetic engineering to develop improved fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: GENERAL MILLS TO BUY YOGURT UNIT FROM FRENCH CONCERN
description: General Mills Inc., based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Colombo yogurt unit from Bongrain S.A., based in Paris. The price and other terms were not disclosed. The acquisition of Colombo, a leading producer of soft frozen yogurt and premium hard-pack frozen yogurt, is expected to accelerate General Mills' entry into that business. General Mills' Yoplait division had sales of about $250 million in the 1993 fiscal year, mainly in refrigerated yogurt cups. Although Colombo also offers refrigerated yogurt cups, it is strongest in the Northeast, where Yoplait's business is less developed. Colombo, with annual sales of about $100 million, has plants in Methuen, Mass., and Springfield, Mo.

title: Anthony T. Vaccarello, 67, Dies; Former Sanitation Commissioner
description: Anthony T. Vaccarello, who served as the New York City Commissioner of Sanitation for three years in the 1970's and shocked New Yorkers in 1977 when he called them "a bunch of slobs," died on Monday in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 67.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Oilers End Loss Streak The Edmonton Oilers, overcoming a 2-0 first-period deficit, snapped an 11-game losing streak and 14-game stretch without a victory with a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings last night at Detroit. The Oilers, who opened the season with two victories, tied it with second-period goals by Steve Rice and Craig MacTavish, then won it with third-period goals by Ilva Byakin and Igor Kravchik. (AP) Blues 3, Penguins 3: Brett Hull's second goal of the game tied visiting Pittsburgh, but a last-minute chance turned out to be only a tantalizing tease for St. Louis. Philippe Bozon fired a shot off the right post with 34.2 seconds to go and the goal judge flashed the goal light on, but replay officials overruled the call. (AP) Capitals 2, Nordiques 1: The Washington Capitals stretched their winning streak to five games, rallying behind third-period goals by Peter Bondra and Randy Burridge to defeat Quebec. (AP) Team USA 5, Whalers 1: Mike Dunham stopped 23 shots and Peter Ferraro had a goal and an assist to spark Team USA to victory over the Whalers at Hartford. (AP) TENNIS Fernandez Is Upset Zina Garrison-Jackson upset third-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-4, 6-1, in the first round of the $750,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia yesterday. Later, Tracy Austin, a wild-card entry, lost to Ann Grossman, 6-4, 6-1, 6-4. (AP) Sampras and Becker Win: Pete Sampras and Boris Becker each won their opening matches yesterday at the European Community Championships at Antwerp, Belgium. Sampras coasted past fellow American David Wheaton, 6-3, 6-2. Becker, who needs to reach the final of the $1.11 million event to be able to defend his world championship title, rallied from behind for a 2-6, 6-3, 7-5 victory over Jason Stoltenberg of Australia. (AP) Cherkasov Takes a Bow: Andrei Cherkasov of Russia, playing before an Olympic Sports Complex audience that included President Boris Yeltsin, held off a late rally by Diego Nargiso of Italy for a 7-6, (7-1), 7-5 victory in the Kremlin Cup in Moscow yesterday. (AP) BOXING Hill Wins 14th Defense Virgil Hill stopped Saul Montana of Mexico in the 10th round last night in Fargo, N.D., to retain his World Boxing Association light heavyweight title. (AP)

title: Russia and China Sign a Military Agreement
description: Russia and China signed a five-year military cooperation agreement today that is expected to broaden the transfer of military technology to China. But the Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel Grachev, said the expanded cooperation would not be used "against any third country."

title: Atchison Casting Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mashburn Content as a Builder
description: Whether it was Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx or the University of Kentucky in Lexington, Ky., Jamal Mashburn has made a strong impact on any program he has been a part of. So why should it be any different with the Dallas Mavericks, the National Basketball Association's worst team last season with only 11 victories in 82 games?

title: COURT, 9-0, MAKES SEX HARASSMENT EASIER TO PROVE
description: Ruling with surprising speed and unanimity, the Supreme Court today announced a broad definition of sexual harassment in the workplace that will enable workers to win suits without having to prove that the offensive behavior left them psychologically damaged or unable to do their jobs.

title: Bank Data, On Screen, Via Phone
description: In partnership with Citicorp, the nation's largest bank, Ameritech said yesterday that it planned to offer banking and other information services through advanced telephones with large calculator-like screens. The service will be offered to 200,000 Chicago customers in one of the largest test markets to date.

title: Access Health Marketing (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holiday Tomorrow
description: Veterans Day will be observed on tomorrow. Here are holiday schedules.

title: Nature Food Centres (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 200,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 251,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 92,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 256,000, or 6 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respctively.Nature Food Centres said that on a pro forma basis, assuming that the company's merger with the Revere Fund and acquisition of Nutrition World had both occurred at the beginning of the year. net income would have been $ 595,000 or 12 cents a share, for the latest third quarter, $ 2,230,000, or 44 cents a share, for the latest 9 months, and $ 2,181,000, or 44 cents a share, for the 9 months ended Sept. 27, 1992.Pro forma sales for the year-earlier third quarter were $ 18,683,000, and the latest 9 months pro forma sales were $ 66,301,000, compared with $ 56,648,000, in year-ago period.

title: Electrocom Automation
description: Shares in Electrocom Automation Inc., which manufactures high-speed document processing systems, dropped sharply yesterday in active trading after the company said its 1994 earnings would be flat because the United States Postal Service had delayed awarding its contracts. The stock has sagged since late September.

title: Rebounding From Crises, New York Hospital Changes Its Ways
description: At a time when New York Hospital, like nearly all others in the city, was facing an acute financial crisis, the mysterious death of Andy Warhol after a routine operation in 1987 added yet another jolt. But in the end, the tragedy helped shock the entire staff of the institution into accepting the need for a sharp change in direction.

title: Lintas Appoints 3 Department Heads
description: Battered by the loss of three large accounts, Lintas New York said on Monday that as expected it had revamped management by appointing three new department heads.

title: Treasury Refunding Wavers a Bit
description: The Treasury struggled a bit in the first leg of its quarterly refunding auctions yesterday, even though the latest report on inflation was unexpectedly good.

title: Comcast Says It's Not for Sale
description: Responding to persistent speculation, the Comcast Corporation said today that it was not for sale but would be interested in an alliance with a telephone company.

title: AST Research Will Eliminate 1,050 Jobs
description: AST Research Inc. said today that it would eliminate 1,050 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, as it consolidated its acquisition of the Tandy Corporation's personal computer manufacturing business.

title: Review/Theater: A Quarrel of Sparrows; Lo, It's Armageddon in an Old-Fashioned Comedy
description: It has gotten to the point where specters of the apocalypse should probably form their own theatrical union. Over the past year, they have tirelessly stalked the stages of New York in works as different as "Angels in America," "Marisol," "Pterodactyls" and "The Twilight of the Golds," reflecting and enhancing millenarian jitters in their audiences.

title: House Fire in Jamaica Kills Two Boys, Ages 3 and 4
description: Two boys were killed yesterday afternoon when fire swept through their home in Jamaica, Queens, trapping the children in an upstairs bedroom, fire officials said.

title: L.I. Nanny, A Newlywed, Is Arrested
description: A nanny left two children, 1 1/2 and 3 1/2 years old, in her employer's home here today while she went to Brooklyn to get married, the police said. The woman returned to find the police waiting.

title: Market Place; Wall Street Savors Boston Chicken
description: In the most successful initial public offering of stock in years, Boston Chicken, a fast-food chain that has yet to earn its first annual profit, went public and promptly more than doubled in price.

title: Johnson: He Runs, Catches And Starts
description: Jets running back Johnny Johnson had an excellent training camp. Some people said he earned the starting job. He didn't.

title: Personalities and Pictures: A Made-for-TV Debate
description: Sometimes there is a political event so transcendentally weird, so Silly Putty, to use one of tonight's Perot-isms, that it almost defies description.

title: Wallace M. Cohen, 85, Regulatory Law Expert
description: Wallace M. Cohen, a retired Washington lawyer who was an expert in regulatory and administrative law, died on Saturday at Sibley Memorial Hospital. He was 85 and lived in Washington.

title: California State Women Win Promise on Sports
description: In the most comprehensive resolution of a sex discrimination lawsuit to date, the California State University system has agreed to offer women attending its 20 member campuses substantially the same opportunities to play varsity sports as men by the 1998-99 academic year.

title: Corrections
description: A holiday schedule yesterday, for tomorrow -- Veterans Day -- referred incorrectly to plans for the financial markets. They will be open. The schedule also misstated the day and time for the Transportation Alternatives Street Fair to be held on St. Marks Place between First Avenue and Avenue A in Manhattan. It is on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., not on Thursday from 11 to 1.

title: Giuliani Chooses 19 for Transition Council
description: Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani named 19 people to his transition council yesterday, assembling a group largely from prominent campaign supporters and donors, but one that also sent a signal that he is consulting women and minority groups as he puts together his government.

title: Review/Television; Eisenhower: The Warts Are Receding
description: Military genius or bland bumbler? A hero of our time or Old Bubblehead? When he left the White House in 1961, his "crusade for peace" in tatters, Dwight D. Eisenhower was ranked by a survey of historians as being in the bottom third of American Presidents, below Chester A. Arthur. During the 1980's, the same survey ranked him near the top. "Eisenhower," continuing a series of in-depth political portraits ("The Kennedys," "L. B. J.," "Nixon"), finds its subject more complex and more interesting, though not always more admirable, than the public image.

title: Thalia to Showcase Fine Line Films
description: The Thalia Theater, the venerable revival house on 95th Street west of Broadway, which reopened in July after six dark years, will show first-run art films distributed by Fine Line Features beginning on Friday.

title: Libya Expels Thais in Chemical Weapons Dispute
description: Libya has ordered thousands of Thai workers out of the country in retaliation for Thailand's efforts to investigate American allegations that Thai companies were involved in the construction of chemical weapons plants in Libya, Thai officials and foreign diplomats said today.

title: Lynch Honored by N.C.A.A.
description: NNENNA LYNCH, Villanova's cross-country runner and Rhodes Scholar, won the N.C.A.A.'s Woman of the Year award. She was one of 10 finalists chosen for athletic, academic and community achievement from a group of 51 national semifinalists.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;
description: Corporations sold about $1.95 billion of new debt yesterday, according to MCM/Corporate Watch, a new issue research firm.

The company also said earnings in the latest quarter and year were reduced by 1 cent a share and 11 cents a share, respectively, by net incremental costs associated with accounting changes.The company also said that sales of medical supplies and devices totaled $ 374 million in the latest quarter, a decrease of 1 percent from a year ago, and totaled $ 1.36 billion in the latest year, an increase of 3 percent from the previous year.

description: The continuing plunge in the value of shares in a huge railroad the Japanese Government recently sold to the public and gloomy economic news put the stock market into a tailspin today, turning the steady slide of the last two weeks into a rout.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Clinton's lobbying for the North American Free Trade Agreement referred incorrectly to the involvement of Representative Karan English of Arizona with a White House dinner on Monday night for undecided Congressional Democrats. Although her name was on a White House list of those who would attend, Representative English said yesterday that she declined the invitation last week and did not attend.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Katie and Anne Roiphe; One Daughter's Rebellion Or Her Mother's Imprint?
description: ANNE ROIPHE wanted to make just one statement about her daughter Katie, the social critic-slash-prodigy who is at the center of the most intense feminist controversy since Betty Friedan pitched a fit about lesbians two decades ago.

title: Heileman Makes Choices for 5 Brands
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company has named the Richards Group in Dallas and Eisaman, Johns & Laws in Chicago, to share its beer and malt liquor brands account. Combined billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Florida State Wants To Avoid a Runaway
description: The concept seems simple enough: stop the run. That has been the formula, it seems, since Dinosaurs versus Mammals, the original meeting between No. 1 and No. 2. If Florida State intends to pass through Notre Dame Stadium this Saturday and continue on a path toward a national championship, the Seminoles must limit the Irish running game enough to create the kind of uncomfortable passing situations that can lead to mistakes.

THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Overview; Gore and Perot Dual on TV Over the Trade Pact
description: Vice President Al Gore suggested tonight that Ross Perot opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement to win political and financial advantage for himself.

title: Food Notes
description: Organic California Raisins

title: Gorky Stars as Auctions Resume
description: The market for contemporary art at auction is facing its own sort of Catch-22. The audience is there and eager to buy; the only problem is finding good material to sell. At a tepid auction at Christie's last night, art sold at every price level, even relatively insignificant art. Of the 62 works offered, 50 found buyers. The evening's sale totaled $15.9 million, just above Christie's low estimate of $15.3 million.

title: Indians Question Americans' Motivation
description: The hosts are ready and willing, but will anybody represent the visitors when the United States, a 1993 Davis Cup first-round loser because of apathy among its top players, and India, 1993's sleeper semifinalist, clash in the first round of Davis Cup next March in Bombay or Madras? India's Davis Cup veteran RAMESH KRISHNAN said yesterday from his training headquarters in Tampa, Fla., that he hopes the unassembled United States squad includes PETE SAMPRAS and JIM COURIER, the world's top two players. But the 296th-ranked Krishnan, who along with LEANDER PAES this year upstaged Switzerland, the 1992 runner-up, and France, the 1991 champion, has spotted a disturbing trend among United States players: "For some reson, Americans don't take Davis Cup that seriously, maybe because there's such an abundance of good players that it's easier for them to pass the buck and not go," said Krishnan. As for India's interest in the March 25-27 match, said the 32-year-old player, "The whole country will be aware of it."

title: In Schools
description: Early on, the pediatrician noted Jonathan Estrada's attention span. "At six months he liked watching 'Wheel of Fortune,' " says his mother, Mary. "He'd get all excited when they turned over the letters."

description: b-Net lossc-Included a cumulative gain of $ 3,352,000, or 43 cents a share, on change in accounting for income taxes, a loss from discontinued operations of $ 7,214,000, and after a gain on disposal of $ 4,265,000, or 54 cents a share.

title: Cuomo Wants High-Speed New York City-Albany Rail Link
description: Hoping to tap into the Clinton Administration's interest in high-speed rail transportation, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday proposed building a high-speed rail link between New York City and Albany that would eventually connect to Boston in only two hours.

title: First Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the effect of adopting SFAS 109, accounting for income taxes, on a retroactive basis in the second quarter of fiscal 1993.First Brands said that its first quarter of fiscal 1994 included additional expenses from higher tax rates resulting from the recently enacted U.S. tax legislation, and also from the adoption of SFAS 106, accounting for postretirement benefits.Excluding these additional charges, the company said net income in the current first quarter would have been 80 cents a share.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MONEY TO MINISTERS IN CAMPAIGN CITED The campaign manager for Christine Todd Whitman's successful race for Governor in New Jersey said the campaign paid money to black ministers who agreed not to rally their flock to vote for Gov. Jim Florio. A1. NO AREA VOTES FOR TRADE ACCORD As evidence of the hill President Clinton must climb if he is to win Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, no Democrat in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations in the House of Representatives is committed to voting for it. A1. NEW YORK CITY HIGHER COST SEEN TO REMOVE ASBESTOS The projected cost of the cleanup of asbestos at schools has more than tripled to at least $119 million, making it likely that other urgent maintenance and construction projects will have to be delayed, school officials said. B3. TWO BOYS KILLED IN QUEENS FIRE Two little boys were killed when fire swept through their home in Jamaica, Queens, trapping the children in an upstairs bedroom, fire officials said. B3. BOMB-MAKING BOOKS SHOWN AT TRIAL Six large-format books with blue-green covers containing writing in both Arabic and English and, most importantly, diagrams on bomb-making, were at the center of testimony in the World Trade Center trial. B4. GIULIANI APPOINTS ADVISERS Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani named 19 people to his transition council, assembling a group largely from prominent campaign supporters and donors, but one that also sent a signal that he is consulting women and minority groups as he puts together his government. B6. A group of New York State legislators and members of the City Council have been wined and dined in Puerto Rico at a conference. B9. Three women were charged with helping to make a firebomb that was thrown into a fire engine, injuring three firefighters in Washington Heights in July. B11. Holding his 5-year-old foster brother in his arms, a 27-year-old man jumped in front of a moving subway train, the police said. B11. REGION WHITMAN AND FLORIO MEET For the first time since Election Day, Gov. Jim Florio and Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman met. Mrs. Whitman talked privately with Mr. Florio at the gubernatorial mansion. B8. FIRST CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR George E. Pataki, a little-known State Senator from Peekskill, said he will run for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in 1994, and he apparently will have the support of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and the state party chairman, William D. Powers. B8. A Rye, N.Y., couple testified that they thought their baby had been abused by a nanny. B8. A nanny in Jericho, L.I., was charged with leaving two young children alone while she went off to get married. B8. About New York by Michael T. Kaufman B3 Holiday Box B3 Chronicle B12

title: Tripled Estimates for Asbestos Cleanup Could Delay Other Work
description: The projected cost of the emergency cleanup of asbestos at New York City public schools has more than tripled since September to at least $119 million, making it likely that other urgent school maintenance and construction projects will have to be delayed, school officials said yesterday.

title: Female Crew II in Whitbread Race
description: A new group of women has taken over the U.S. Women's Challenge, the 60-foot yacht that NANCE FRANK had entered in the Whitbread Round the World Race. The women's original Whitbread team withdrew from the race last month after the team arrived at its first port-of-call, Punta del Este, Uruguay. The 32,000-mile competition started Sept. 25 from England. Although a lack of finances was given as the team's reason for quitting, an internal rift that tore apart crew solidarity also contributed to the campaign's demise.

title: Peekskill Legislator to Seek Governor Nomination
description: George E. Pataki, a little-known State Senator from Peekskill, said today that he will run for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in 1994, and he apparently will have the support of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and the state party chairman, William D. Powers.

description: The Complete Lyrics of Ira Gershwin Edited by Robert Kimball. 414 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $45.

description: Women hold only 6.2 percent of the board seats in the 1,000 companies that make up the Fortune 500 and Fortune 500 Service companies lists, according to a study released yesterday.

Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $10 million to $15 million.

Harper, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Company told its cigarette distributors Monday night that the company was raising prices for most brands, including Camel and Winston, by 4 cents a pack, a cost virtually certain to be passed on to consumers.

description: For a week now, a group of New York State legislators and members of the New York City Council have been wined and dined by lobbyists as they hold a conference here that they say will help them better serve their Puerto Rican constituents back home.

title: In America; Nafta And the Elite
description: The intellectual and political elite have lined up in support of the North American Free Trade Agreement, but it's the grunts, the ordinary working men and women of America, who will face the consequences in the form of wage contraction, lost jobs and reduced standards of health and safety.
