description: A recent scrimmage had just ended at St. Raymond High School in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx when Gary DeCesare, head coach of the basketball team, walked over to Kareem Reid and the rest of the losing squad and said simply, "Pull out the chairs."

title: Review/Critic's Notebook; Celebrating Segovia As Master and Mentor, Even as Imperfect Man
description: The daylong celebration of Andres Segovia's centenary at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday must have seemed at least slightly peculiar to any nonguitarists in the audience. What the museum offered, in the form of lectures on Segovia's life, working methods, achievements and instruments, ending with a recital by Manuel Barrueco, was the kind of examination regularly lavished on composers and hardly ever on performers.

title: A Seeker of Mystery Takes Stock of Suburbs
description: IT was a dark and stormy night. As the wind whistled through the trees, the lights in the spacious Victorian and colonial homes beckoned with the promise of warmth and shelter.

title: Yeshiva U. Is Bequeathed $40 Million
description: Yeshiva University has received a $40 million gift, the largest in its 107-year history, from the estate of Rachel Golding, who died last year at the age of 81.

title: O'Neal Receives Fine
description: Orlando's SHAQUILLE O'NEAL was fined $5,000 yesterday by the National Basketball Association for making derogatory comments about the officiating in the Magic's game against Detroit last Wednesday. (AP)

title: SOCCER
description: The Final Draw

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Harold E. Varmus; Out of the Lab and Into the Bureaucracy
description: HAROLD E. VARMUS, the new director of the National Institutes of Health and therefore one of the most powerful figures in science, is a man with many weighty matters over which he can mull.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Review/Theater; The Backstage View of TV's Golden Age
description: So it wasn't Paris in the 20's. But midtown Manhattan in the 50's produced its own cockamamie earthquake in American letters. Creating sketches for "Your Show of Shows" and then "Caesar's Hour," a band of young, mostly Jewish writers forged a comic style that dominated the new medium of television, as well as Broadway and the movies, for decades. If you want to find the ur-texts of "The Producers" and "Blazing Saddles," of "Sleeper" and "Annie Hall," of "All in the Family" and "M*A*S*H" and "Saturday Night Live," check out the old kinescopes of Sid Caesar cavorting with Imogene Coca, Carl Reiner and Howard Morris on those Saturday nights 40 years ago.

title: Agriculture Department, in Shift, Will Punish Corrupt Contractors
description: After flouting a Presidential directive for seven years, the Agriculture Department will stop giving hundreds of millions of dollars in Government contracts to large dairies and other agricultural companies that have been caught defrauding Federal programs.

title: Fuel-Short Ukraine Is Caught in Wintry Vise
description: This is the coldest autumn here in 50 years, and Ukrainians are beginning to feel it indoors as well as out. Throughout the country, apartments and offices are getting colder, hot water is running out and brownouts are more common.

title: Chess
description: It's hard to be a rebel in chess, at least for any length of time. If you avoid mainline theory and are successful, you become swallowed up in the new, inclusive main line. If you are not successful, you remain on the fringe, losing a lot of games.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about "Never Stop Running: Allard Lowenstein and the Struggle to Save American Liberalism," by William H. Chafe, misstated the date of Mr. Lowenstein's assassination. It was March 14, 1980, not 1981.

title: 30-Year Commemoration In Dallas and Arlington
description: On the 30th anniversary of John F. Kennedy's death, thousands of tourists filed past his grave at Arlington National Cemetery today, and the plaza in Dallas where he was shot to death was declared a National Historic Landmark.

title: Foyt Names Jones
description: A. J. FOYT announced yesterday that DAVY JONES , a 29-year-old racer from Lake Tahoe, Nev., who made his name in sports car racing, will be the driver on his Indy-car team starting in 1994. Jones replaces ROBBY GORDON , a promising but crash-prone driver who left Foyt's team after his rookie season in 1993 to go to DERRICK WALKER's team. This is not Jones's first time with Foyt, who gave Jones his first ride at Indianapolis in 1987. Jones responded then by posting the fastest qualifying time for a rookie.

title: Dinkins Accepts Faculty Post In Urban Affairs at Columbia
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins will join the faculty of Columbia University to teach urban affairs and other subjects at the School of International and Public Affairs after he leaves office at the end of the year, the chairman of the university's Board of Trustees said yesterday.

title: Burlington Resources
description: Shares of Burlington Resources Inc., an oil and gas developer, rose yesterday. Burlington will replace Paramount Communications Inc. today as a component stock of the Standard & Poor's 500 index. Paramount was replaced because of merger speculation.

title: Trade Pact Raises Threat of TB From Cattle
description: To the Editor:

title: Her Study Shattered The Myth That Fraud In Science Is a Rarity
description: AS a premedical student at Wellesley College in the 1960's, Judith P. Swazey was puzzled by the disappearance of slides of tissues her research team had prepared.

title: Apple Lawsuit Ends in Accord
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that Albert A. Eisenstat, who quit its board and sued the company, had reached an agreement to settle the suit.

title: After Elections, Italy Is Still a Muddle
description: In nationwide municipal elections depicted as an oracle of things to come, Italian voters registered their disappointment with the tainted parties of the mainstream by turning to the neo-Fascist and ex-Communist candidates in record numbers.

title: An Author Who Lets Women Be Bad Guys
description: Margaret Atwood is tired of seeing only nice girls in fiction, so in her latest novel, "The Robber Bride," she has created a formidable alternative. She is an anti-heroine named Zenia, a brilliantly scheming temptress who betrays other women, steals and discards men like so many secondhand clothes, constantly reinvents herself for her own dark purposes and generally conducts herself with flamboyant malevolence.

title: Congressional Roundup: House Fends Off Effort To Trim Budget Further; Brady Bill Faces More Resistance
description: Facing continuing Republican resistance to the Brady bill, Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic majority leader from Maine, said he would call Senators back to Washington from their holiday recess to give final passage to the measure if he needed to.

title: Chinese End Austerity Drive In Favor of Yet More Growth
description: For months experts have been debating whether China's soaring economy could be brought in for a landing, a "hard" one or a "soft" one depending on the austerity measures the Government used last summer to apply the brakes. But it now appears the Chinese economy is not going to land at all.

title: So Long, Farewell, A Happy Goodbye
description: The women's tennis game, though its administrators are loathe to admit it, fell into a strange limbo the instant the curtain closed on the $3.5 million Virginia Slims Championships late Sunday afternoon after the event played to a non-record total of 100,784 fans at Madison Square Garden last week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Tuesday about Iraqi Government moves against opposition Shiite Muslims in southern Iraq misspelled the name of the Geneva representative of the Supreme Council of Islamic Revolution in Iraq, an opposition group. He is Ali Ali al-Adhadh.

title: Stanley Rich, Entrepreneur, 76; Invented Submarine Sonar Device
description: Stanley Robert Rich, an entrepreneur and inventor who devised a scanning sonar for submarines in World War II, died on Sunday at Youville Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 76 and lived in Grantham, N.H., and Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Smokers Can't All Quit the Same Way
description: To the Editor:

title: End to Strike Is Only a Lull in Industrywide Upheaval, Airline Experts Say
description: The walkout by flight attendants at American Airlines has ended for now, but industry experts say that further labor turmoil in the airline industry is likely in the coming year and many people could find their travel plans disrupted.

title: Aikman on Mend, Smith on Table
description: The Dallas Cowboys, who lost one on the field Sunday, won one and lost one yesterday in the trainer's room. Coach Jimmy Johnson announced that Troy Aikman would probably play Thursday against the Miami Dolphins but that Emmitt Smith would probably not.

title: Trade Pact Raises Threat of TB From Cattle; Threat to Cows
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. May Dilute Earlier Threats To North Korea
description: A day before President Clinton meets South Korea's President to discuss the standoff on nuclear inspections in North Korea, South Korean officials said they feared the Administration may be pursuing too conciliatory a policy.

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall 3.1%; Anxiety Grips Market
description: Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's failure over the weekend to issue a clear commitment to reinvigorate the deteriorating Japanese economy sent the stock market here into a fearful dive today, with the closely watched Nikkei index of 225 issues plummeting more than 3 percent.

title: Software Maker Accused of Using Virus to Compel Client to Pay Bill
description: When a custom-designed computer program failed to meet William Haberman's expectations, the furniture builder used the leverage of dissatisfied customers everywhere: he held back on payment.

title:
DIALOGUE: TV Violence: Survival Vs. Censorship;
Save Free Speech
description: As the Senate Commerce Committee's hearings on television violence drew to a close, two Senators argued about a movie.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
First Chicago Agrees To Acquire Lake Shore
description: Making its first bank acquisition in almost five years, the First Chicago Corporation agreed today to buy Lake Shore Bancorp Inc. in a stock deal valued at $323 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Short but Sweet; Seattle Stores Promote Candy With Itty-Bitty Ad
description: A chocolate candy that is an obsession in the Pacific Northwest and elsewhere will star this month in what a retailer is trumpeting as the shortest and the most expensive television commercial ever made.

title: XEROX TALKING WITH FUND AMERICAN ON TELEGEN SALE
description: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy all or part of the Xerox Corporation's insurance unit and thus re-enter the United States insurance business. Fund American said it had had preliminary talks with Xerox over the sale of Xerox's Telegen unit, formerly Crum & Forster Inc., one of the nation's largest property and casualty insurers. Fund American said it could pay between $100 million and $2 billion for all or part of the unit, which Xerox has been trying to sell since January.

title: Scanning The Future Of Books On Disks
description: BOOKS go back to the early centuries of the first millennium. By the fourth century A.D., "the rectangular codex (Latin, 'book')," had replaced "the inconvenient scroll," in the words of Microsoft Encarta, that lively CD-ROM encyclopedia. Undoubtedly there were old fogies in the early fifth century still scanning scrolls while their children, clucking in pity, flipped to Chapter Five of the latest Elmorus Leonardus.

title: New York Urged to Shift Cost of Fighting Shore Erosion
description: People who live near the shore would pay more in taxes and fees to help protect New York's coastline from storm damage under a plan released today by a state task force.

title: Amoco Loses Oilfield Suit
description: A jury has ordered the Amoco Production Company, a unit of the Amoco Corporation, to pay $417 million to the Rubicon Petroleum Corporation for breach of contract and fraud.

title: 2 Beach-Erosion Control Projects Planned for L.I.
description: Two emergency beach-erosion control projects, the first for the North Shore of Long Island since last winter's destructive northeaster, were announced today by Federal officials.

title: Moore's Position Redefined
description: As the Jets' offense has evolved, so has Rob Moore's role. During the early part of the season, Moore was a big-play receiver, using his height and athletic ability to stretch defenses deep and strike fear into cornerbacks.

title: TREDEGAR IS EXPLORING SALE OF COAL SUBSIDIARY
description: Tredegar Industries of Richmond said yesterday that it had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to look into selling its coal subsidiary. The unit, the Elk Horn Coal Corporation, owns the mineral rights to 133,000 acres in Kentucky and has about 400 million tons of low-sulfur coal reserves. In 1992, Elk Horn, which mostly leases its mining rights, posted an operating profit of $9.2 million on sales of $30.9 million, or about 7 percent of Tredegar's $479 million in revenues. Tredegar manufactures plastic and metal products and also develops computer software.

title: Bruno Rossi, 88, Pioneer in Cosmic Ray Research
description: Dr. Bruno Rossi, an authority on cosmic rays and a retired professor of physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died on Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

title: Workplace Bias Tied to Obesity Is Ruled Illegal
description: In the first Federal appeals decision of its kind, a three-judge panel in Boston ruled unanimously on Monday that job discrimination against severely obese people violated a Federal disabilities law.

title: Review/Film; Of Children And Dinos, With Feeling
description: "We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story" is a brief, witty children's book about dinosaurs who pay a visit to New York City, a place that is described amusingly from the dinosaurs' point of view. But tiny admirers of Hudson Talbott's illustrated volume will be surprised to find the dinosaurs in the animated screen version, "We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story," play second fiddle to a cast of people. The people are brash, rude and occasionally scary. This was somebody's idea of how to enhance the authentic New York City atmosphere.

title: Driver's Shot From the Point Earns a Point for the Devils
description: Devils 1, Nordiques 1

title: Skating By -- at 72 M.P.H.; Some Lovers of Rollerblading Are Speeding Up the Sport by Latching Onto Autos
description: Tom Rooney, an investment banker for Prudential Securities, was riding in a limousine uptown on Third Avenue for cocktails at Mortimer's the other night.

title: When Grass Roots Lead to Ivy Halls
description: If he had studied politics at Columbia before becoming Mayor, David N. Dinkins was asked yesterday, what lesson would he have liked to learn?

title: New York Police Ban Use of Choke Holds
description: The New York City Police Department has banned the use of choke holds, the restraining maneuvers that cut off the flow of blood and oxygen to the brain and have been blamed in the deaths of suspects in New York and other cities.

title: Personal Health; Turning your anger into a constructive force
description: THREE New Yorkers were recently overheard venting their spleen:

title: The City's Budget: Better and Worse
description: Mayor David Dinkins's final report on the New York City budget shows him leaving office with a perfect score -- four balances in four years. Expected post-election spending cuts will not be needed to balance this year's books, he says. But in the same report he warns of looming deficit problems much larger than he estimated last summer.

title: Bridge
description: Two major titles were decided here Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Markets to Shut For Holiday
description: All banks and financial markets in the United States will be closed tomorrow in observance of Thanksgiving. But markets in other countries will be open.

title: G.O.P. Governors Weigh Protecting 'Own' Issues
description: Vowing to regain control of a majority of the nation's statehouses next year after almost 25 years of Democratic dominance, Republican governors concluding a conference here today agreed that the best course was to emphasize issues that have been staples of their party platform: fighting crime, cutting taxes and controlling spending.

title: Sour End to Strong Year
description: The 103d Congress more or less ended a productive first session today, but on a note of ill will that made it clear that the legislative paralysis of recent years had been diminished but not vanquished.

title: Books of The Times; Experts in the Comedy of Self-Love
description: Private Parts By Howard Stern Illustrated. 446 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23. Confessions of a Raving, Unconfined Nut Misadventures in the Counterculture By Paul Krassner Illustrated. 352 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: C. Clark Zantzinger Jr. Architect, 89
description: C. Clark Zantzinger Jr., a founder of the Philadelphia architectural firm Kneedler, Mirick & Zantzinger died on Sunday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 89.

title: Food Notes
description: T-Day and Counting

title: Blair Having Treatment on Injured Calf
description: BONNIE BLAIR, the top American female in the sport, is receiving treatment this week in Rocky River, Ohio, for a calf muscle injury she sustained last Friday in Germany, the United States speed skating federation said yesterday.

title: A Perfect World; Where Destiny Is Sad and Scars Never Heal
description: In a perfect world, says one rueful character in Clint Eastwood's quietly devastating new film, the events that shape the story of Butch Haynes and Philip Perry wouldn't have to happen. But the world in which "A Perfect World" unfolds is a place of sad, ineradicable scars that shape their characters' destinies. Many of those scars have to do with the burdens and misapprehensions of manhood, as illustrated beautifully during the course of this eloquent road film and understood by Mr. Eastwood in subtle, profoundly moving ways. The time and place -- Texas, just before the Kennedy assassination -- tacitly heighten the film's sense of needless tragedy.

title: U.N. FINDS BAGHDAD IS GAINING IN SOUTH
description: President Saddam Hussein has now succeeded in draining about 40 percent of the fresh water marshlands of southern Iraq so his military forces can press their campaign against dissident Shiite Muslims there, a United Nations human rights inspector reported today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Swedes Fear a Russian Invasion: Crime Gangs
description: After weeks of conflicting testimony, a Swedish court has delivered a mixed verdict in a bizarre kidnapping plot that has raised fears in Sweden about crime spilling over from Russia.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on Sunday in the "Where to Complain" listing in The City (section 13) misstated the telephone number of the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Its number is (718) 722-2877.

title: Reform: Now for the Hard Part
description: Nobody said it would be easy. And Democratic leaders suffered a few scary moments before winning House approval for an overhaul of Congressional campaign financing. The reforms will, at last, give challengers of modest means a competitive shot at well-financed incumbents.

title: Holiday Tales of Turkey And Its Discontents
description: LEFTOVER turkey is a ghoulish reminder on the morning after Thanksgiving. Roasted, dismembered and carved, remnants of big bird tweak the guilt of all who dare crack the refrigerator door. Therein lies evidence of abundance, testimony to overindulgence.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Argue With the Computer
description: NOTRE DAME fans, enraged, continue to call the office.

title: The Great Expanding Holiday
description: New Yorkers live and breathe the rattle and hum of their city. How could they not, with eight million people streaming along the sidewalks, jamming the subways or circling the block in a vain search for parking spaces?

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column last Wednesday about a genetically engineered hormone, bovine somatotropin, or BST, that increases milk production in cows misstated the view of the American Academy of Pediatrics on its safety and desirability. An editorial in Pediatrics, the organization's journal, endorsed the use of the hormone, but the academy has not taken a position.

title: Board Reports Played Down School Crime, Cortines Says
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday that Board of Education officials have in recent years minimized the extent of violence in the New York City schools by restricting information about school-based crimes, and he vowed to change the practice.

title: Cusk, Spanish Style, Adds a Twist To Traditional Holiday Meals
description: BECAUSE of my wife's Spanish origin, fish is a traditional choice for our family at holiday time. The spicy Spanish-style fish featured in this menu is typical of the dishes reflecting her heritage that appear on our Thanksgiving and Christmas tables along with the more familiar turkey and trimmings.

title: Starks Willing to Pay Price for Success
description: It is no coincidence that John Starks has suffered two broken noses since March.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Guerlain's lengthy review works to a small agency's advantage.
description: GUERLAIN INC., ending one of the longest recent account reviews, has selected a small, creatively focused New York agency to help raise the profile of its premium-priced products.

title: James Stern, 88, a Prolific Writer Of Short Stories and a Translator
description: James Stern, an Anglo-Irish critic and prolific writer of short stories that traced his wanderings through the British Isles, Africa, the Pacific and America, died on Monday at his home in Tisbury, England. He was 88.

title: While We Lock Up More People, Street Violence Only Grows
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Review/Film: Mrs. Doubtfire; A Wig, a Dress and Voila! Dad Becomes the Nanny
description: "Mrs. Doubtfire" is about a man who dresses as a dowager to invade the household of his estranged wife, who has thrown him out. The movie's biggest challenge, one that it does not exactly meet, is to persuade the audience that this husband and father's escapade is somehow an act of love.

title: Viacom Appears to Top QVC In Paramount Tender Offer
description: Viacom Inc. appears to have taken an early lead over QVC Network Inc. in the tender offer race for Paramount Communications Inc., as the combatants in the takeover battle await a crucial court decision that could come today.

title: OLYMPICS: 80 Days to Lillehammer <HEADLINEAfter Hard-Luck Year, U.S. Skaters Cutting New Groove
description: As the last figure-skating season ended last spring, American women were suffering through more crashes than the average Indy car race. Nancy Kerrigan, a bronze medalist at the 1992 Winter Olympics, stumbled to fifth place at the 1993 world championships. Tonya Harding, overweight and perhaps over the hill, finished fourth in a weak field at the United States championships and didn't even qualify for the world title event.

title: Safety 1st
description: Shares of Safety 1st Inc., a maker of child safety products, gained slightly yesterday, recovering from a round of profit taking last week. The shares had run up to a peak on Nov. 15 after the company announced at the end of October that its earnings per share for the third quarter were more than twice those in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Merry-Go-Round's Credit Challenged
description: A shiver of concern swept through New York's garment industry yesterday as some factoring companies and credit-rating agencies advised clients against shipping goods to Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc., the operator of trendy specialty stores.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY CROSSROADS FOR COLISEUM?

title: Eating Well
description: THE announcement this week that the Federal Government's information on nutrients in food is flawed and unreliable will probably cause even greater angst among those who are already confused about healthful eating. It shouldn't.

title: Mexico City Journal; South of the Border, the Trade Deal Was a Breeze
description: As the Mexican Senate prepared to cast its decisive vote on the free trade agreement that will join this country with the United States and Canada in the largest trading bloc in the world, a wall of dark suits rose on Monday night by the telephones in the Senate cloakroom.

title: Now, Back to Health Care: the White House Is Mobilizing Again
description: With the distraction of the North American Free Trade Agreement behind them, the Administration and its allies are hoping to use the two-month Congressional recess to revive their campaign for overhauling the health care system. They have planned a relentless exercise in retail politics: town meeting by town meeting, hospital by hospital, videotape by videotape.

title: Youngsters on the Run From Painful Realities
description: Twelve-year-old Josh Whitney (Jacob Tierney) is a computer whiz and a fast-talking liar who can worm his way out of any scrape by inventing an ingenious story. He is also acutely sensitive to his divorced father's disappointment in him because he can't catch a football.

title: Alexander Langmuir Dies at 83; Helped Start U.S. Disease Centers
description: Dr. Alexander D. Langmuir, a leader in public health who is credited with saving hundreds of thousands of lives through his innovations in controlling epidemics, died on Monday in Baltimore, where he lived. He was 83.

title: Market Place; A Squeeze Play by Big Aluminum
description: Few companies would pass up a chance to wish away a big competitor. And apparently, the American aluminum industry is willing to do just that -- even if it means losing a big customer while they are at it.

title: Review/Film; Youngsters on the Run From Painful Realities
description: Twelve-year-old Josh Whitney (Jacob Tierney) is a computer whiz and a fast-talking liar who can worm his way out of any scrape by inventing an ingenious story. He is also acutely sensitive to his divorced father's disappointment in him because he can't catch a football.

title: AT DINNER WITH: Ricki Lake; Half the Weight and on the Rise
description: AMERICA'S most pleasingly plump, cheerfully chubby young actress is no longer living with euphemisms.

title: Up for Auction: The Cooking Tips Of a Duchess
description: JUST when we thought they'd been totally forgotten, they're back.

title: Palestinian Says Israel Agrees to Release Captives
description: The chief Palestinian negotiator at talks on carrying out the Israel-P.L.O. peace accord said today that Israel had agreed to include the release of Palestinian prisoners in any final agreement.

title: Clash Between 2 Senate Leaders Stalls Brady Bill
description: A measure mandating a five-day waiting period for the purchase of a handgun stalled again today as Senate leaders failed to agree on a few remaining details.

title: Rights in the Baltics
description: To the Editor:

title: E.D.S. Signs On for Britain's Tax Agency
description: Electronic Data Systems, the information technology subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it had won a 10-year, $1.5 billion contract from Britain's national tax agency.

title: Diminutive Runner, Big Numbers And a Dream of Playing in the N.F.L.
description: Archie Griffin, the only player to win the Heisman Trophy twice, sat in his office at Ohio State recently and talked about one of the top running backs in college football this season.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MACANDREWS & FORBES HOLDINGS INC., New York, a company controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, the financier, said it had formed Meridian Sports Inc. as an active recreation company that will consist of four water sport units: Boston Whaler, Mastercraft, O'Brien and Skeeter. TRIMAS CORP., Ann Arbor, Mich., has agreed to acquire the Lamons Metal Gasket Co., Houston, a subsidiary of Mascotech, for $60 million in cash.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHELSEA CLINTON will take to the stage next month to perform in the Washington Ballet's production of "The Nutcracker," The Associated Press reported yesterday. She is one of four students from the Washington School of Ballet who will alternate in the role of Favorite Aunt in the classic Christmas production at the Warner Theater in Washington.

title: Ruling on Demjanjuk Errs in Assumptions
description: To the Editor:

title: To Help Girls Keep Up: Math Class Without Boys
description: In Laura Gamb's high school mathematics and science classes last year, the boys would make fun of her if she said million when she meant billion, and she learned to deflect their ridicule by saying, "Just kidding," or "Never mind."

title: Lockheed Gets Contract
description: The Lockheed Corporation has received a $398.8 million contract from the Air Force for computer-aided engineering software, the Defense Department said today. Lockheed's Missile and Space division, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will provide Integrated Computer-Aided Software Engineering -- known as I-CASE -- technology, a combination of off-the-shelf hardware and software and specially developed software that the Pentagon will use to modify or maintain existing information systems. The company's contract extends through November 1995.

title: BIG U.S. HOSIERY MAKER TO BE SOLD FOR $233 MILLION
description: Grupo Synkro S.A. of Mexico City, the largest Latin American hosiery company, plans to purchase the Kayser-Roth Corporation, a unit of Collins & Aikman Group Inc., for $233 million. Members of the Ballesteros family, Synkro's main shareholders, will also take part in the venture. The transaction will make Grupo Synkro the second-largest producer and distributor of hosiery worldwide, with total sales of about $600 million. Synkro plans to keep Kayser-Roth as an independent unit. The acquisition will give Synkro the opportunity to introduce some of Kayser's well-known hosiery brands, including No Nonsense and Burlington, in Mexico.

title: Bleak Romanian Economy Growing Ever Bleaker
description: Bundled up against the icy cold of an unseasonably early winter, Victoria Uleia shopped at Bucharest's thinly supplied outdoor market, splurging on cheese but not meat.

title: Molson Picks Shop For Media Buying
description: Molson Breweries U.S.A., which imports 25 brands including Molson Golden, Molson Ice and Foster's Lager, named Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. of New York to handle its media-buying responsibilities, previously handled by Lintas New York.

title: Book Notes
description: Snowballing to Success With a laughably minuscule promotion budget and no publisher to speak of, "The Celestine Prophecy," a first novel by James Redfield, a resident of Saginaw, Ala., might have been expected to die a quick and anonymous death. But Mr. Redfield published the book himself, calling his one-book company "Satori," and when he brought it to distributors, a curious thing began to happen.

title: Backer Spielvogel's Canadian Venture
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with five advertising and marketing executives in Montreal to open an agency that will take over the Montreal office of Backer Spielvogel's Canadian unit, BSB Canada. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Republic Breaks With Tradition
description: When the Republic New York Corporation sheepishly announced late last Friday that it was withdrawing its hostile bid to acquire the Green Point Savings Bank, it put to an end -- at least for now -- one of the most curious episodes in the recent history of banking.

title: Time to Pull Up Your Socks, Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Garners Praise In Handling Rollins Furor
description: There have been longer honeymoons. After eking out a victory in a raucous New Jersey gubernatorial race, Christine Todd Whitman might have expected a respite, a sweet and relaxed recess between the rigors of campaigning and the difficulties of governing.

title: Reviews/Film: A Perfect World; Where Destiny Is Sad and Scars Never Heal
description: In a perfect world, says one rueful character in Clint Eastwood's quietly devastating new film, the events that shape the story of Butch Haynes and Philip Perry wouldn't have to happen. But the world in which "A Perfect World" unfolds is a place of sad, ineradicable scars that shape their characters' destinies. Many of those scars have to do with the burdens and misapprehensions of manhood, as illustrated beautifully during the course of this eloquent road film and understood by Mr. Eastwood in subtle, profoundly moving ways. The time and place -- Texas, just before the Kennedy assassination -- tacitly heighten the film's sense of needless tragedy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ORIBE CANALES, the hairdresser to stars and supermodels who is known simply as Oribe, has entered a drug rehabilitation center, his spokeswoman, Chen Sam said yesterday.

title: Norway in Missile Deal
description: The Norwegian Government signed a contract today to purchase antitank missiles from the French aerospace and military concern Aerospatiale for 650 million francs, about $110 million. Aerospatiale said in a statement that it was the most important military contract signed between France and Norway. The order is for 424 Eryx antitank systems and 7,200 missiles and associated material.

title: No Headline
description: Patricia Drylie, a dancer and an actress best known for her performance as a dancing waitress in the 1979 Michael Bennett musical "Ballroom," died on Nov. 11 at a nursing home in Brooklyn. She was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mr. Rollins Stirs the Pot Anew
description: The plot twists in the New Jersey election fracas get stranger and stranger. Ed Rollins, campaign manager in the final stretch of Christine Todd Whitman's successful run for the governorship, spent nearly seven hours last Friday denying under oath his earlier boast about suppressing the black vote -- but also indicated there might be some truth to it. That tantalizing tidbit was then denied by another key player.

title: Giants' Defensive Line: Surprising Strong Point
description: It's not as if the origins were even humble. No, the point of departure for the 1993 defensive line for the Giants was more like a tumultuous ground zero.

title: Food Notes
description: T-Day and Counting

title: Clinton Seeking To Consolidate Bank Agencies
description: The Clinton Administration today outlined a plan to create a single agency to regulate the entire banking industry, saying that dividing the job among four agencies no longer made sense.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the temporary reinstatement of Dr. Edmond L. Volpe as president of the College of Staten Island misstated his scheduled role at commencement ceremonies next May. He is to participate in the exercises; he will not preside.

title: Review/Pop; Singing Dirty but Staying Wholesome
description: Gloria Trevi, the young Mexican soap opera star turned pop singer, jams a microphone into her crotch when she performs. She shakes a can of Coca-Cola (her sponsor), places it at groin level and pops the top. She pours Coke over her breasts. She licks her fingers, mimicking rote sexuality. She talks dirty and sings even dirtier. And her audience, which ranges from pre-teen girls to grandparents, loves it all.

title: W.W.F. Boss Enters Not Guilty Plea
description: The boss of the World Wrestling Federation, VINCENT McMAHON JR., pleaded not guilty yesterday in Uniondale, L.I., to federal charges accusing him of peddling muscle-building steroids to wrestlers between 1985 and 1991.

title: Review/Film; Irish, Unwed, Pregnant: Why Is She Glowing?
description: "The Snapper" was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 8. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, 63d Street and Broadway.

title: State Suspends Doctor
description: The New York State Health Commissioner yesterday suspended the medical license of a Long Island physician accused of causing the death of a 14-year-old girl in his office on July 29. The physician, Dr. Maximo C. Chua, who has a practice in Smithtown, was charged with gross negligence and incompetence. The board said he "inappropriately" gave the girl vitamins intravenously.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: KEMPER INSURANCE UNIT TO BE SOLD FOR $100 MILLION
description: Associated Group said its Anthem P & C Holdings insurance unit had agreed to purchase the Federal Kemper Insurance Company, a unit of the Kemper Corporation, for $100 million. The acquisition will expand Anthem's insurance business to 20 states, mostly in the East, from 13. Anthem also owns the Shelby Insurance Group. Associated Group, a privately held company, generates some $3.3 billion in annual revenues from insurance and financial services businesses. Federal Kemper will change its name and become the leading company of a new subsidiary called the Anthem Personal Insurance Companies. Its headquarters will remain in Decatur, Ill.

title: Strike Is Called Victory For Women, Not Unions
description: President Clinton's intervention Monday in the strike by flight attendants at American Airlines represented a breakthrough for working women, rather than a victory for organized labor, union leaders said today.

title: Executive Changes
description: GENESEE CORP., Rochester, appointed John Wehle Jr., its president and chief executive, to the additional post of chairman. METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER INC., Santa Monica, Calif., named Francis Ford Coppola, the film director, writer and producer, and Thomas M. Lewyn, a lawyer specializing in corporate and entertainment law, as members of the board.

title: Stocks Recover Slightly As Dow Climbs by 3.92
description: Stocks yesterday recovered some of the losses suffered in Monday's sharp selloff, as investors were buoyed by a rally in the Treasury bond market and Britain cut its base lending rate.

title: Runaway Rubles
description: In opinion polls, Russians consistently name inflation and crime as their chief concerns. However different, both are results of the most crucial problem most former Communist countries face: the state is too weak, while the old Communist elites are too strong.

title: Israeli Arabs Say P.L.O. Pact Is a Path to First-Class Status
description: Diab Mahroum, a pastry maker in this ancient city, could see for himself how much the world had suddenly changed when he put his baklava on display at a food fair in October in Cologne, Germany.

title: No Headline
description: "Their taste is very today. They're not stuffy and pretentious and neither is their home." -- KAKI HOCKERSMITH, the Clintons' decorator. [ A22:5. ]

title: L.I. Business Group Says Federally Required Auto Inspections Will Be Disruptive
description: A Long Island business group, backed by gas station operators, is forecasting "delay, confusion, and a disruption of daily life" if New York proceeds with a federally required program for centralized auto inspections in 1996.

title: A Redecorated White House, the Way the Clintons Like It
description: It was farewell to the free trade agreement and the Pacific Rim conference. At the White House today, it was time to concentrate on domestic issues -- like whether the country is ready for blood-red fabrics and neo-Victorian decor ornamented with gold Napoleonic laurel wreaths.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Thanksgiving is tomorrow. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: In School
description: The Department of Education recently invited 200 great teachers, including most of the state teachers of the year, to the Capitol to get their points of view on education reform.

title: Elementary Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Ralph Berton Is Dead; Jazz Teacher Was 82
description: Ralph Berton, a teacher and writer on jazz, died last Wednesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 82 and lived in North Bergen, N.J.

title: Tarkanian Loses Another Round in Court
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday against former Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach, JERRY TARKANIAN, and declared unconstitutional a Nevada law that was intended to protect him and others facing National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions.

title: GOODYEAR UNIT TO SELL WHEEL REFURBISHING BUSINESS
description: Air Treads Inc., a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday that it would sell its aircraft wheel and brake refurbishing business to the Aircraft Landing Systems unit of Allied Signal Inc. by the end of the year. The companies did not disclose the price. The sale includes the inventory and equipment of Air Treads' wheel refurbishing operations in Dallas; Kingman, Ariz.; Allentown, Pa., and Morfelden, Germany.

title: Scuffle? What Scuffle? Barkley Is Cleared
description: CHARLES BARKLEY of the Phoenix Suns will not be prosecuted for a scuffle during which a patron at a bar said he was punched by the National Basketball Association's most valuable player.

title: New Study Links Increased Hypertension To Greater Anxiety in Middle-Aged Men
description: THERE may be more truth than doctors have long believed to the notion of a relationship between tension (as in stress) and hypertension (as in high blood pressure), at least for middle-aged men.

title: Wine Talk
description: MORE wine and spirits will be bought, and presumably consumed, in the next five weeks than in any other comparable time of the year. The shops will be crowded, and even the friendliest clerks will get a bit edgy when asked what wine goes best with, say, shrimp in black bean sauce.

title: Bratton of Boston Indicates He Is Interested in New York Police Job
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton of Boston, who less than two weeks ago said he was not interested in the job, indicated yesterday that he would consider an offer to become the commissioner of New York City's Police Department.

title: A Hero in the AIDS Battle and a Fun-Loving Boy
description: AT the Javits Center on Saturday night James Matarazzo, who is 12 years old, was hanging around backstage waiting for his friend Joey DiPaolo, who is 14, to go on and address the 10,000 dancers who were raising money to combat AIDS.

title: In America; Battered Girls in School
description: Most of the time the girls just take the beatings. They may think that getting beaten up is normal, or that there are no alternatives. Or they may be afraid they will be beaten worse if they complain, perhaps even killed.

title: Warner-Lambert Will Close 7 Factories and Cut 2,800 Jobs
description: The Warner-Lambert Company announced a restructuring yesterday, including plans to close seven factories and eliminate 2,800 jobs. The cuts would be in addition to a reduction of 2,700 jobs already under way.

title: 2 Clinton Aides Are Leaving on a Winning Streak
description: Two senior White House officials will leave the Government by the end of the year, taking advantage of the relatively good news the Administration has enjoyed of late to make their departures.

title: In California, a Lab for the Brady Bill, The Debate on Guns Has No Winner
description: As looting and violence spread during last year's rioting, there was a near-riot at Art's Guns in suburban Canoga Park as scores of panicked people discovered they could not buy quick self-protection because of California's 15-day waiting period on gun sales.

title: For Gators, Seminole Game Could Be Route to No. 1
description: The last two things Errict Rhett and his University of Florida teammates will see before they step onto the field on Saturday to face Florida State are a very old photograph and a fairly new sign. The photo is of Dale Van Sickle, a defensive end from the 1928 Florida team, which almost went to the Rose Bowl. The sign, painted above the doorway two seasons ago, reads:

title: Bridge
description: Two major titles were decided here Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: EXPANSION AT WALT DISNEY WORLD TO ADD 11,000 ROOMS
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that expansion plans at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., would add 11,000 rooms to the resort in the next five years. The expansion will include nine hotels, a 5,000-seat stadium and sports complex and a third water-theme park. The company did not release cost estimates. Last week, Walt Disney World said it planned to build a multimillion-dollar international amateur sports center, to include a stadium, field house, tennis arena and fitness center, on about 100 acres.

title: Prince Charles, the Royal Cookie Maker
description: His face most certainly does not adorn the packaging, Paul Newman-like, and it would be a stretch to refer to his new products as big sellers. But Prince Charles has plunged into the food business -- more specifically, the cookie business -- and so far no one is laughing.

title: George Balanchine's "The Nutcracker"; An Intimate 'Nutcracker' With a Culkin Star Turn
description: You don't have to believe in Santa Claus to be swept up in the magic of Christmas. By the same token, some of the fairy-tale magic of "George Balanchine's 'The Nutcracker' " has been lost in its translation from a staged ballet into a film, but it doesn't hurt; it is only a fraction. If Rouben Ter-Arutunian's depiction of the Sugarplum Fairy's Palace of Pleasures is obviously a painted stage set, its elegant swirl of domes and pedestals is still gorgeous.

title: Tatyana Nikolayeva, 69, Dead; Pianist and Shostakovich Expert
description: Tatyana Nikolayeva, a Russian pianist widely respected for her interpretations of the music of Bach and Shostakovich, died on Monday in San Francisco. She was 69 and lived in Moscow.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Big East

title: Comptroller Says City's Slump Is Ending
description: H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, said yesterday that New York City was beginning a slow, uneven recovery after a four-year slump that cut far deeper than elsewhere in the nation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: If Donald Trump's former wife, Ivana, is selling her designs on the Home Shopping Network, can the mother of his fourth child, MARLA MAPLES, be far behind?

title: Peter Henderson; Oil Executive, 69
description: Peter Henderson, owner of the Peter Henderson Oil Company of New York and Houston and an avid polo player, died on Saturday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 69.

title: How Africa Understands Female Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Haiti Death Toll Questioned

title: Review/Film: George Balanchine's "The Nutcracker"; An Intimate 'Nutcracker' With a Culkin Star Turn
description: You don't have to believe in Santa Claus to be swept up in the magic of Christmas. By the same token, some of the fairy-tale magic of "George Balanchine's 'The Nutcracker' " has been lost in its translation from a staged ballet into a film, but it doesn't hurt; it is only a fraction. If Rouben Ter-Arutunian's depiction of the Sugarplum Fairy's Palace of Pleasures is obviously a painted stage set, its elegant swirl of domes and pedestals is still gorgeous.

title: With Friends and Readers, Rushdie Pleads His Case
description: Surrounded by security guards and with the author Susan Sontag acting as what he jokingly referred to as "my beard," Salman Rushdie emerged from hiding tonight to receive an honorary post as visiting professor of the humanities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Cuomo Names Stein to Head A Study Panel
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today announced the creation of a commission to study shortcomings in the state's juvenile justice system, and appointed Andrew J. Stein, the departing New York City Council President, to head the panel.

title: 2 in House Want to Free Baby Bells
description: Two Congressional chairmen who have played opposing roles in regulating the telephone industry today proposed the lifting of all major restrictions on local phone companies that were put into practice when the old Bell System was broken up in 1984.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about the film director Emile Ardolino misspelled the name of his companion. It is Luis Miguel Rodriguez-Villa.

title: Book Notes
description: Snowballing to Success With a laughably minuscule promotion budget and no publisher to speak of, "The Celestine Prophecy," a first novel by James Redfield, a resident of Saginaw, Ala., might have been expected to die a quick and anonymous death. But Mr. Redfield published the book himself, calling his one-book company "Satori," and when he brought it to distributors, a curious thing began to happen.

title: Like the U.S., Western Europe Steps Up Its Trade With Asia
description: During a week in which the message from Washington and Seattle was that United States foreign policy has been too Eurocentric and must concentrate more on Asia, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany was quietly touring China and concluding contracts to sell about $4 billion in German goods to Beijing.

title: Investors Hug Vermont Teddy Bears
description: A fondness for teddy bears, generally expressed with hugs, took a new form yesterday as investors warmly embraced the stock of the Vermont Teddy Bear Company on its first day of trading.

title: White House Dinner, but What Kind?
description: To most of the world, the dinner President and Mrs. Clinton gave this evening for President Kim Young Sam of South Korea and his wife looked like the state dinners other Presidents have given for visiting heads of state. But it was not, the White House insisted, a state dinner, merely an official one.

title: Grumman Agrees to Pay U.S. $20 Million
description: The Grumman Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $20 million to the Federal Government to avert criminal charges of defrauding the Navy and to strengthen the way it supervises internal corporate ethics.

title: Of Children And Dinos, With Feeling
description: "We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story" is a brief, witty children's book about dinosaurs who pay a visit to New York City, a place that is described amusingly from the dinosaurs' point of view. But tiny admirers of Hudson Talbott's illustrated volume will be surprised to find the dinosaurs in the animated screen version, "We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story," play second fiddle to a cast of people. The people are brash, rude and occasionally scary. This was somebody's idea of how to enhance the authentic New York City atmosphere.

title: Bittersweet Memory for Minnesota's Haskins
description: Clem Haskins said that, all things considered, he was happy to be back in New York.

title: TANDY PLANS TO SPIN OFF FURNITURE SUBSIDIARY
description: The Tandy Corporation said yesterday that it would sell shares of O'Sullivan Industries, a subsidiary that makes ready-to-assemble furniture, in an initial public offering. The spinoff will substantially complete Tandy's plan to shed manufacturing businesses.

title: Wine Talk
description: MORE wine and spirits will be bought, and presumably consumed, in the next five weeks than in any other comparable time of the year. The shops will be crowded, and even the friendliest clerks will get a bit edgy when asked what wine goes best with, say, shrimp in black bean sauce.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about American policy toward North Korea referred incorrectly in some editions to a meeting between President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea. It was yesterday, not this coming Friday. A report about the meeting appears today on page A16.

title: Review/Theater: Perestroika; Following an Angel For a Healing Vision Of Heaven on Earth
description: If you end the first half of an epic play with an angel crashing through a Manhattan ceiling to visit a young man ravaged by AIDS, what do you do for an encore?

title: U.S.-Europe Trade Talks
description: Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's top trade official, held detailed discussions today to resolve some of the many quarrels that have delayed the completion of a 116-nation free trade pact. They also agreed to hold more talks in Brussels next week.

title: Kelly Bans Choke Holds By Officers
description: The New York City Police Department has issued an order banning the use of choke holds, the restraining maneuvers that cut off the flow of blood and oxygen to the brain and have been blamed in the deaths of suspects here and around the nation.

title: It's 'Showtime' Again for Erving, a k a Dr. J
description: Six years after his retirement, JULIUS ERVING thought the time was now right for a return to pro basketball, so yesterday he became the studio analyst of NBC's "NBA Showtime" pre-game show. He replaces QUINN BUCKNER, who left the studio last season to become coach of the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Blurring Cultural Lines In a Quick Autumn Meal
description: IS this what they mean by cross-cultural eating? An Italian pasta seasoned with Chinese dried mushrooms, sesame oil and soy sauce? And to further blur the lines, a side dish of broccoli rape, the Italian name for the vegetable known in Chinese as choy sum?

title: Pressure for a Decision on Coliseum Site
description: It has been nearly nine years since Mortimer B. Zuckerman won the right to replace the Coliseum, a building much maligned by architecture critics, with a gleaming new mixed-use complex on Columbus Circle. Today the old Coliseum still stands, and the fate of the site, which occupies prime real estate near the southwest corner of Central Park, seems as uncertain as ever.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: From the Ashes, a Plus for a Utility
description: The New England Power Company burns a lot of coal at its waterfront power plant here: 2,400 tons a day, day in, day out, year round.

title: U.S. and Seoul Differ on Appeal To North Korea on Nuclear Sites
description: The United States and South Korea agreed today to hold out to North Korea a package of inducements if it allows some inspections of its nuclear sites and resumes discussions with South Korea. But the two longtime allies could not agree on exactly what the offer should contain.

title: God Saves Queen, but Not England Coach
description: GRAHAM TAYLOR quit as manager of England's national team yesterday, six days after his team was eliminated from the World Cup. The announcement was made by GRAHAM KELLY, chief executive of the English Football Association. The F.A. said LAWRIE McMENEMY, Taylor's assistant, had also resigned.

title: Tariff Fought On Tobacco
description: With the North American Free Trade Agreement clear of Congress, Senator Hank Brown, a Colorado Republican, introduced legislation this week that would delay a protectionist measure on tobacco that was included in the budget package approved by Congress last summer.

title: U.S. RESTRICTIONS ON ADULT TV FARE ARE STRUCK DOWN
description: A Federal appeals court today struck down as unconstitutional a Government regulation prohibiting indecent television programs broadcast between the hours of 6 A.M. and midnight.

title: Those Gaudy Billboards Still Give a Thrill
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Doubtfire; A Wig, a Dress and Voila! Dad Becomes the Nanny
description: "Mrs. Doubtfire" is about a man who dresses as a dowager to invade the household of his estranged wife, who has thrown him out. The movie's biggest challenge, one that it does not exactly meet, is to persuade the audience that this husband and father's escapade is somehow an act of love.

title: Treasury Market Bill Is Passed
description: It took more than two years and came with little fanfare. But around 2 A.M. yesterday, the House of Representatives gave the final approval needed to pass the bond market legislation proposed in the wake of the Salomon Brothers Treasury scandal in August 1991.

title: Rangers Would Love A Parade, Any Parade
description: The frustration of the Montreal Canadiens was personified in Patrick Roy, their star goalie, who fished four pucks out of his net last night when the Rangers won by 5-4 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Airlines Almost Back to Normal, Just When Normal Is the Busiest
description: The nation's flight paths returned to near-normal yesterday, the first full day of operations after the five-day flight attendants' strike against American Airlines.

title: Now Batting and Playing First Base for the Yankees, (the Mets?), It's . . .
description: Although the Yankees are the New York team that has expressed interest in Rafael Palmeiro, whose job the Texas Rangers have given to Will Clark, the Mets could become the New York team that seriously tries to sign him. The possibility is not as farfetched as it might seem now.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 FOR ISRAEL'S ARABS, OPTIMISM Many of the 800,000 Arab citizens of Israel are hopeful that the agreement on Palestinian self-rule will bring sweeping improvements in their lives economically, politically and even culturally. A1 Talks made progress on the issue of Palestinian prisoners. A6

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the House vote on a deficit-reduction proposal overstated the share of freshmen House members who supported the plan. Fifty-five percent of the freshmen backed the proposal, not 75 percent.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FOR several years I have devoted this pre-Thanksgiving space to those who enjoy turkey but do not have enough guests to roast an entire bird. For them I suggest turkey breast, which is widely available in supermarkets.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Wachtler Suffers Minor Injuries in Stabbing in Federal Prison
description: Sol Wachtler, New York State's former chief judge, was stabbed on Sunday in the Federal prison in North Carolina where he is serving a 15-month sentence, his family said yesterday.

title: Referees Agree on Money
description: Don Meehan, the agent for the striking National Hockey League officials, said yesterday that the union had accepted the league's proposed salary scale and has halved its benefits proposal from an increase of $1.5 million a year to $750,000 a year for the 58 members.

title: A Superhighway Through the Wasteland?
description: Telecommunications and cable TV executives, seeking to allay concerns over their proposed megamergers, insist that the coming electronic superhighway will be an educational and informational tool as well as a cornucopia of interactive entertainment. Allow the marriage between entertainment and communications giants, we are told, and they will connect students with learning resources, provide a forum for political discourse, increase economic competitiveness and speed us into the multimedia information age.

title: Behind a Glamorous Image, Flying Working Class
description: The corporate stylebook so strictly decrees the proper image of flight attendants, from head to heels, that they have a wry saying about the requirements of their jobs: "You've got to be willing to go anywhere -- and to cut your hair."

title: G.M. Sets Sale of 3 Parts Plants
description: To streamline its parts-making operations, the General Motors Corporation said today that it planned to sell most of its ownership in three plants that manufacture starting motors, generators and other products.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Burlington Motor Holdings, Daleville, Ind., parent of Burlington Motor Carriers, is selling $100 million of senior subordinated notes due in 2003 priced at 100 to yield 11.5 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. and Bear, Stearns & Co. The issue is redeemable in five years and is rated B-3 by Moody's and CCC+ by S.& P. * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, is selling $100 million of debentures due 2003 priced at 100 to yield 5.99 percent through Lehman Brothers. The 10-year debentures are noncallable.

title: DOCTORS QUESTION HAITI HEALTH DATA
description: A physicians' group that took part in a recent study of the impact of an international embargo on the people of Haiti has challenged the study's projection that the sanctions may be killing as many as 1,000 children each month.

title: Mammograms Before 50? A Hung Jury
description: THE decision was eagerly awaited. A prestigious advisory board to the National Cancer Institute was going to vote on what to do about the mammography question. Should women under 50 have regular mammograms? The answer could help settle one of the most contentious disputes in medicine.

title: Sotheby's Chief Is Leaving As Auction Sales Rebound
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. announced yesterday that Michael L. Ainslie, its president and chief executive, was stepping down and would be replaced by Diana D. Brooks, the president and chief executive of its worldwide auction division.

title: Sports Briefings; Victory in Alaska For St. Raymond's
description: St. Raymond's, the defending New York City and state champion in the Catholic High School Athletic Association, opened its basketball season in Alaska Monday night by thrashing West Anchorage, 105-51, in the opening round of the Great Alaska High School Shootout.

title: A Flying Dutchman May Miss World Cup
description: MARCO van BASTEN, the top striker of Italian League champion A.C. Milan and the Netherlands national team, may miss the rest of the season and the World Cup finals because his right ankle has been slow to heal.

title: Real Estate; With hopes that casino gambling will soon follow, Philadelphia developers plan retail centers.
description: A 42-ACRE retail center is under construction on the Delaware River waterfront here, amid signs that future development on adjacent properties may include casino gambling in shoreline buildings, on piers and aboard ships.

title: Review/Film; Kafka's Sinister World by Way of Pinter
description: Harold Pinter can be Kafkaesque even when presenting a love story, as he did in letting the finely calibrated events of "Betrayal" unfold in reverse chronological order. So the combination of Mr. Pinter and Franz Kafka would appear to be made in heaven, or at least in the kind of hell that both parties might understand.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FOR several years I have devoted this pre-Thanksgiving space to those who enjoy turkey but do not have enough guests to roast an entire bird. For them I suggest turkey breast, which is widely available in supermarkets.

title: K-III Acquires A Publisher
description: The K-III Communications Corporation said on Monday that it had bought, for an undisclosed price, Nelson Publications, best known for its directory of securities analysts.

title: Contract for Police Holsters Prompts Query on Bidding
description: What initially looked like a routine contract to supply the New York City Police Department with holsters and gun belts for its new 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistols has resulted in an internal investigation and the discovery that the president of a company that has received departmental business was convicted of a felony.

title: Looking for La Bomba: Is Tomba on the Wane?
description: Can that really be the fiery Italian ski racer, Alberto Tomba, over there in the dimly lit corner of the Vintage restaurant, his shoulders hunched and his eyelids at half mast?

title: A Lucky Ending for Rangers as Streak Reaches 13
description: The game ended in controversy, a final-seconds Montreal goal disallowed on a debatable offside call by one of the National Hockey League's substitute linesman, who was clearly out of position on the play. It ended with a late-game surge by the Canadiens, some soft play from the Rangers and a lot of reasons for different people to complain.

title: Economic Scene; A four-day workweek plan is optimistic, not realistic.
description: READY for the 4-day, 33-hour workweek?

title: A SALVADOR DENIAL ON DEATH SQUADS
description: Vice President Francisco Merino of El Salvador today denied allegations that he was involved in plotting and financing death-squad activities in 1990, as reported in recently declassified United States intelligence documents.

title: Barnes & Noble
description: Shares of Barnes & Noble, which went public in September, rose sharply yesterday after Morgan Stanley recommend purchases of the stock. Earlier this week, the bookstore operator reported a 22 percent increase in third-quarter revenues. And revenues and profits are expected to peak during the fourth-quarter holiday season.

title: NCR Says Its Intention Is to Be 'Competitive'
description: Struggling with brutal price competition at home and sluggish markets overseas, A.T. & T.'s NCR Corporation stepped up its effort yesterday to reduce costs by trying to cut its work force by 7,500 people.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Lakshmi Shankar Hindustani Singer Rousseau Room Barbizon Hotel

title: Compuadd's Chief Resigns
description: The Compuadd Computer Corporation said today that its founder, Bill H. Hayden, had stepped down as chief executive.

title: Clemson Coach Quits
description: Clemson Coach KEN HATFIELD, whose team posted an 8-3 season and was looking toward a probable trip to the Peach Bowl, resigned yesterday. He chastised fans and university officials for their lack of support.

title: U.S. Now Turns to Soothing the Europeans
description: After weeks of declaring that the United States would increase its attention to the fast-growing markets of Asia and Latin America, the Clinton Administration is trying to mend fences with Europe.

title: John Butler Memorial
description: A memorial service for the choreographer John Butler is to be held on Monday at 7 P.M. at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street. The two-hour program is to include filmed excerpts from Mr. Butler's ballets and reminiscences by colleagues, including Glen Tetley, Mary Hinkson, Carmen de Lavallade and Judith Jamison. Mr. Butler died on Sept. 11 at the age of 74.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Thanksgiving Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mubarak and King Hussein End a Chilly Standoff
description: President Hosni Mubarak met officially with King Hussein of Jordan today, formally ending a three-year rift that began when the King refused to support the coalition effort to drive Iraqi occupiers out of Kuwait.

title: Fossil Dealers in Tyrannosaur Seizure Are Indicted
description: A group of South Dakota fossil dealers whose tyrannosaur skeleton was seized by Federal agents in 1992 has been indicted on 39 charges of trafficking in fossils illegally taken from Federal land.

title: Clinton and Aides Meet Rushdie At White House in Rebuke to Iran
description: President Clinton met today with Salman Rushdie in a gesture that the White House said was intended to convey America's abhorrence of Iran's refusal to lift the death threat against the novelist.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the resignation of an editor at The Burlington County Times in New Jersey referred incompletely to the background of an article published there. The theme of the article was Democrats' criticisms of Assemblywoman Priscilla B. Anderson, a Republican, because of her attendance record at her job as a high school guidance counselor. The Democrats based their criticism on an article published by The Times of Trenton in June about the attendance records of Assemblywoman Anderson and other legislators who are also educators.

title: Review/Pop; Baby Boomers' Exorcism and Picnic
description: In American pop culture, these are the days of regression. As baby boomers cling to the sitcoms and artifacts of their adolescence, alternative rockers in their 20's hurl themselves back to the traumas of childhood. With Smashing Pumpkins (who opened a sold-out two-night stand at Roseland on Tuesday night), Pearl Jam and Nirvana, the Top 10 has been populated by rockers trying to exorcise troubled childhoods for themselves and their fans. "What's a boy supposed to do?" Billy Corgan sang in an anguished wail on Tuesday night. As the crowd sang along, he continued: "The killer in me is the killer in you."

title: Airlines Ask Clinton To Intervene in Fight On Los Angeles Fees
description: In a showdown pitting the struggling airline industry against a cash-starved city, the nation's major airlines asked the Clinton Administration today to prevent Los Angeles officials from banning their aircraft from the city's international airport.

title: KNOLL UNIT OF BASF TO CUT 430 PHARMACEUTICALS JOBS
description: Knoll A.G., the pharmaceuticals unit of the the BASF Group, the German chemicals giant, said yesterday that it would cut 430 jobs from its domestic work force of more than 3,700 next year. Of the jobs to be eliminated, 280 would be at the company's main site in Ludwigshafen. Knoll attributed the move to a slump in domestic sales resulting from changes in Germany's health care system, which were introduced at the beginning of the year. The changes limit the amount of drugs doctors can prescribe.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Vincent Herring Alto Saxophonist Village Vanguard

title: Amid Holiday Hubbub, American's Pace Is Slow
description: The day before Thanksgiving always means one thing at O'Hare International Airport: controlled chaos.

title: NBC Names New Host For 'Later'
description: NBC has selected Greg Kinnear, a 30-year-old cable-channel performer, as the new host of "Later," the latest of the network's late-night programs. "Later" is broadcast Tuesdays through Fridays at 1:35 A.M.

title:
Currents;
Bright Murals for a Grim Subway Station
description: SOME New Yorkers may notice that the squalid underground world depicted in the film "Demolition Man" looks a lot like the city's subway system. Over the last 10 years the New York City Transit Authority has been trying to do something about its natural grunge look.

title: Events: Shows, a Sale, An Auction and a Talk
description: Design Exhibitions Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 860-6862.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it had distributed about $123 million to more than 91,000 employees worldwide under a profit-sharing plan. Employees of the 54-year-old company are eligible for profit-sharing after six consecutive months of service. The company issues two checks to these employees annually, one in November and the other in May. Combined, the checks represent about two to four weeks' extra pay, the company said. The plan was established in 1962.

title: Tunnel Likened to Brooklyn Bridge in Complexity and Scale
description: It has been likened to the Brooklyn Bridge and other monumental public works in its scale and complexity of construction.

title: GOODRICH BEGINS SELLING ITS REMAINING STAKE IN GEON
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company began yesterday to sell its remaining interest in the Geon Company in a public offering that would generate pretax proceeds of $248 million. The sale of 12.9 million shares at $20 a share represents just less than half of Geon's 26.3 million shares outstanding. Money from the sale is intended to be used for expansion of Goodrich's aerospace and specialty-chemicals business, the company said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about President Clinton's intervention in the American Airlines strike misidentified James J. Reynolds, a Johnson Administration official who intervened in a strike in 1966. He was an Assistant Secretary of Labor and then Under Secretary of Labor; he was not the Labor Secretary.

title: A New York Thanksgiving
description: My mother's birthday, Nov. 25, has always got lost in the commotion of Thanksgiving. She was too busy to care much, though, trying to please the 10 of us, especially her mother-in-law -- my formidable Irish grandmother -- from whose house in Queens the feast moved to ours, in the suburbs, during the 1960's.

title: Chester Santon; Radio Announcer, 78
description: Chester Santon, a radio announcer for 44 years, 38 of them at WQXR in New York, died last Thursday at Dobbs Ferry Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Excerpts From Ruling in Paramount Case
description: Following are excerpts from an opinion yesterday in Delaware Chancery Court by Vice Chancellor Jack B. Jacobs in the Paramount Communications case:

title: This Season, Retail Experts Can't Seem to Agree
description: Never mind that holly boughs, tinsel and blinking lights have festooned store windows and shopping malls since Halloween. Tomorrow, the annual holiday shopping season officially begins, the most profitable time of year for retailers. But there is little consensus about just how strong sales will be this year.

title: EMI to Pay Michael Jackson $70 Million to Manage Music
description: The pop singer Michael Jackson said through his lawyer yesterday that EMI Music Publishing would begin managing his 6,000-title music catalogue, which includes most early Beatles hits, in a deal being described as the most lucrative in music publishing.

title: QVC Network Wins Court Round In Its Bid to Take Over Paramount
description: A Delaware Chancery Court yesterday swept away many of the obstacles that Paramount Communications had put in place to stop QVC Network Inc. in its hostile takeover of the giant entertainment company.

title: Peru's Peasant Victims Still Need Help
description: To the Editor:

title: A Teacher Who Lives His Lessons of Design
description: A BARE table -- or wall, or floor -- makes Stanley Barrows very nervous.

title: Hide It Well, Kiss It Goodbye
description: DONALD SMITH sometimes wakes up in the morning and thinks, "This is going to be the day." The day for what? Not much. Not a sweepstakes win or a rendezvous with fame. What Mr. Smith thinks, and hopes, on such mornings is that this will be the day he finds his gold ring, which has been missing for some months. It wasn't stolen, and it's not exactly lost. In fact, he knows its approximate location. But none of this has done him a lot of good.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Scouting the Top Teams Here are the scouting reports for the top high school football games today and tomorrow in Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: Rap Star and 2 Friends Indicted in Sexual Attack
description: Amid a throng of curious hip-hop fans jostling for space with television cameras, the whirl of accusations surrounding the rapper Tupac Shakur spiraled yesterday into a Manhattan courtroom, where Mr. Shakur and two friends learned that they had been indicted on charges of sexually attacking a fan.

title:
Currents;
Deluxe Hollywood, Restored
description: WILL the Polo Lounge (above) in the Beverly Hills Hotel in Los Angeles keep its sinuous, soigne look? Will the deep green, banana-leaf wallpaper remain in the Fountain Coffee Shop and corridors of the famed landmark? These and other questions were first asked last year when the hotel was closed for renovation by its new owners, Sajahtera Inc.

title: For Movie Industry, Thanksgiving Means A Box-Office Feast
description: With concerns about those inevitable turkeys, movie-style, Hollywood is bracing for the most crowded Thanksgiving season in film history. No fewer than seven films opened today in New York, including "Mrs. Doubtfire," starring Robin Williams; "A Perfect World," starring Kevin Costner and Clint Eastwood, and "George Balanchine's 'The Nutcracker,' " with Macaulay Culkin.

title: Review/Dance; Reveling in the Power of Clarity, Simplicity and Silence
description: The five dances presented by Benedette Palazzola on Sunday night at the Eden's Expressway studio in SoHo were modest. But they were also impressively authoritative, given the relative inexperience of the choreographer and her performers, all recent graduates of the University of Michigan who trained with Peter Sparling, a former Martha Graham dancer. There wasn't an inexpert moment in the program. Ms. Palazzola is clearly a very promising artist.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL Wolverines-Wolfpack The bowl picture crystallized yesterday for Michigan, but not for Ohio State. Michigan and North Carolina State, which have never met on the football field, accepted invitations to play in the Hall of Fame Bowl on New Year's Day in Tampa, Fla. Both teams have 7-4 records. The Wolverines will be making their 19th consecutive bowl appearance. The Buckeyes' bowl options were narrowed to two during a conference call involving the Big Ten athletic directors, who reaffirmed the agreement to preclude consecutive appearances in the Florida Citrus Bowl. Ohio State appeared in the Citrus Bowl last Jan. 1, so if Wisconsin goes to the Rose Bowl, Ohio State will play in the Holiday Bowl on Dec. 20 in San Diego. The Buckeyes (9-1-1) will go to the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on New Year's Day if Wisconsin (8-1-1) loses to Michigan State next weekend at Tokyo. (AP)

title: Sales of Domestic Vehicles Rose 20.5% in Mid-November
description: Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 20.5 percent in mid-November, a sharp increase from the corresponding period a year ago and a robust rate that presaged even stronger sales through the early part of next year.

title: East German Spy Spews Anger as Trial Ends
description: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

title: Merry-Go-Round to Take a Charge
description: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc., the beleaguered operator of specialty stores, said yesterday that it would take a noncash charge against its third-quarter earnings, mostly to account for markdowns on poorly selling merchandise, but also to cover the costs of closing 30 stores.

title: Click, Click. Gobble, Gobble.
description: Steak is too expensive. Pizza doesn't feel right. Hot dogs, hamburgers, fried chicken and baked ham all have their moment at center plate, but not today.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Continuum Alice Tully Hall

title: Classical Music in Review
description: ''Correction Appended''

title: Cool, Astute Leader Takes Flight Union to Victory
