description: As Denise C. Hedges steered into the parking lot of a hotel where the press anxiously awaited her, the engine of her corroded 1985 Renault died. As president of the 21,000-member union of American Airlines flight attendants, she had a news conference beginning in minutes.

title: Four Years Later, Pinstripes May Finally Suit Langston's Taste
description: The Yankees' quest for a quality starting pitcher might not be as bleak as it appeared in recent weeks. There's one out there the Yankees may actually be able to acquire.

title: Sonics' Gill Is Sidelined
description: Seattle SuperSonics guard KENDALL GILL, who suffers from recurring cluster headaches and who collapsed at practice on Tuesday, did not play at Sacramento last night.

title: Councilman's Mayoral Victory in Atlanta Is a Break With the Past
description: City Councilman Bill Campbell won the runoff election for Atlanta mayor on Tuesday, swamping his opponent and becoming the first black mayor in 20 years with neither deep roots in the city's civil rights community nor celebrity status drawn from it.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Vivaldi Orchestra of Moscow Alice Tully Hall

title: Green Point Reprimanded for Vote Action
description: The planned initial public offering by the Green Point Savings Bank ran into more difficulty yesterday when the New York State Banking Department ordered the bank to stop asking depositors who voted against its plan to change their votes.

title: Durable Goods Orders Surge 2% to Record
description: The economy's manufacturing sector gained fresh momentum in October as orders for durable goods surged 2 percent, to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: European Trade Official Hints at Mollifying French
description: The European trade commissioner raised the possibility here today that some aspects of a negotiated agreement on world trade liberalization might be modified to satisfy French objections, particularly to allow a continuation of subsidies for French farmers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Anchor Glass Container Corp., Tampa, Fla., a unit of Vitro Sociedad Anonima, is offering $200 million of senior subordinated notes due in 2008, at 100 to yield 9.875 percent, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Noncallable for seven years, the issue is rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B by Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: FERROFLUIDICS TO RESTATE THREE YEARS OF RESULTS
description: The Ferrofluidics Corporation of Nashua, N.H., whose previous chief executive was forced to step down in September amid allegations of securities violations, said yesterday that it would restate results for the last three fiscal years. The adjustments in the 1993 fiscal year come on top of $11.6 million of previously reported earnings restatements and balance sheet write-downs, Richard S. Groberg, executive assistant to the chief executive, said. The new changes will have the effect of making the 1993 net loss worse than the previously reported $10.4 million and raising sales to more than $33 million from the previously reported $29.6 million, he said.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Grow by 1.2% on Nasdaq
description: The bets that Nasdaq stocks will tumble continue to grow larger.

title: AROUND TOWN WITH: Breyten Breytenbach; Writing in English, Crying in Afrikaans
description: IN the easy iconography of politics and fame, Breyten Breytenbach, the long-exiled South African writer, is captured in a recent Richard Avedon photograph. His face is serene; his gaze is beatific; his hands, one layered gracefully over the other, seem to float in front of him; all that's missing is a halo. Mr. Avedon's ordinarily savage eye has taken the former political prisoner -- who served seven years in a South African jail for anti-apartheid activities -- and turned him into a saint.

title: CHINESE FACTORIES GREET CAPITALISM
description: Next year China's Communist leaders will select 100 big state-owned factories, take their managers aside and tell them that they will now answer to "owners" in the Western sense of the word.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIA LAURINO, the chief speechwriter for Mayor David N. Dinkins, and ANTHONY SHORRIS, the first deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, were planning to marry in June -- with the Mayor officiating.

title: Sears Faces Bias Suit on Buyout Offer
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company illegally required employees who accepted early retirement offers in the last two years to waive all age-discrimination claims against the company, according to a complaint filed here in Federal court by the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Speculum Musicae Merkin Concert Hall

title: Whitman's Brother Gives Answers in 2 Inquiries
description: Gov.-elect Christine Todd Whitman's brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., gave sworn testimony today in separate appearances before a Federal grand jury and lawyers for the Democratic Party, both of which are looking into allegations that Republicans paid to suppress the urban black vote in the Governor's race.

title: Math Teacher Hurt In Classroom Attack
description: A teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School was assaulted yesterday by three masked intruders who entered his classroom and repeatedly punched and kicked him, the police said.

title: 2 British Boys, Both 11, Guilty of Murdering Toddler
description: Two chubby-cheeked 11-year-old boys were convicted today of abduction and murder in the beating death last February of a Liverpool toddler, James Bulger, and sentenced to serve a term of indefinite custody for what the trial judge later called "an act of unparalleled evil and barbarity."

title: Officer Quits Post at Novell
description: Novell Inc., the leading maker of software for local area networks, said yesterday that Darrell L. Miller was retiring as executive vice president for corporate marketing and strategy effective on Dec. 9. Mr. Miller, who is 47, is leaving after six years at Novell, based in Provo, Utah, to provide consulting to the venture capital community.

title: No. 2 Man at F.B.I. to Quit For Job With Financier
description: Floyd I. Clarke, the No. 2 official at the Federal Bureau of Investigation who operated for most of this year as the agency's de facto director, said today that he would retire in January to join a New York company led by the financier Ronald O. Perelman

title: Parcells Aims at Jets Again
description: It was New England's fourth game of the season. Bill Parcells didn't know very much about his team, but he expected it to be competitive against the Jets. He was returning to Giants Stadium for the first time since retiring as Giants coach in 1990 and it was a homecoming for the Oradell, N.J., native.

title: 16-Ton Hoist Falls on Workers in a Queens Shaft
description: A 16-ton winch tumbled into a shaft in Queens yesterday, killing one construction worker and injuring seven others as it ricocheted off the walls of the dank 503-foot hole that is to tap into a new city water tunnel.

title: Morceli Athlete of Year
description: NOUREDDINE MORCELI, who set the world mile record and was unbeaten at that distance and 1,500 meters in 14 races, has been selected Track and Field News's male athlete of the year for 1993.

title: Moynihan and Kennedy Tangle on Health Bill
description: Months before they are to start scrutinizing any fine print in the Clinton Administration's plan to overhaul health care, some of the Senate's leading figures have fallen into a nasty squabble over who should hold the magnifying glass.

title: Horse Carriages Don't Obstruct Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: When Security Becomes a Struggle; Demand Is Acute as Neediest Cases Fund Begins 82d Appeal
description: A year ago, Anthony G. Brown and his son, Charles, shared a spacious two-bedroom apartment with a terrace on the top floor of a brownstone in the North Bronx. The $700-a-month rent was comfortably within Mr. Brown's reach as a presentations specialist, a clerical job at the brokerage firm of Shearson Lehman Brothers, where he had worked for two years.

title: Why Make Fellini the Scapegoat for New Cultural Intolerance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Collins, Guitarist, Dies; Influential Blues Stylist Was 61
description: Albert Collins, a Grammy-award winning blues guitarist, died Wednesday after a three-month fight against cancer. Mr. Collins died at his Las Vegas home, according to a statement from Alligator Records, a label he had recorded for. He was 61.

title: After the Subtraction, Finally a Mets Addition
description: Howard Johnson left, and New York yawned. Sid Fernandez exited, and the city, well, maybe burped. Charlie O'Brien won't be back. Eddie Murray is perhaps headed to Baltimore, and yesterday the Mets traded Dave Gallagher to the Braves for Pete Smith.

title: Stocks Rise, With Dow Up by 13.41
description: Stocks closed higher yesterday in modest trading, propelled by favorable economic news and a bond market that kept a lid on interest rates.

title: Essay; The Porn Is Green
description: Legal scholars are breaking their heads over a clash of rights: the right of children to be sheltered from pornography and violence vs. the right of adults to choose to watch what they want when they want it.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Tiffany & Company unveils its Christmas windows on Dec. 3, it will be a milestone for GENE MOORE, the store's display director: he will have produced 5,000 windows for the famed jewelry and silver emporium.

title: Giants' Walking Wounded Are Glad to Be Walking
description: Jumbo Elliott's back. The throwing shoulder of Phil Simms. And David Meggett's broken rib. Potentially, these could be damaging injuries to the Giants since they involve three of their best players. Of the three, Elliott and his back could be the biggest problem.

title:
Currents;
Child's Space With Touches Of Matisse
description: SPACES where art is made and displayed should look arty. So say the Manhattan architects Peter Stamberg and Paul Aferiat, whose axiom guided their design for the temporary quarters of the Long Island Children's Museum, which opened in Garden City last Sunday.

title: F.B.I. Shaken by Inquiry Into Idaho Siege
description: The bloody standoff between the F.B.I.'s elite paramilitary force and a white separatist in Idaho has produced one of the largest and most wrenching internal inquiries ever conducted by the Justice Department, threatening some of the country's top law-enforcement officials with criminal prosecution.

title: High Hopes for Low Interest Rates
description: Despite a recent upturn in interest rates, many economists and market analysts believe that the United States has entered an era of rates far lower than in the 1980's that is likely to last for many years -- thanks to a host of forces ranging from an inflation-fighting Federal Reserve to a slow-growing world economy.

title: Nebraska Has Point To Prove To Polls
description: They have a wealth of football history and tradition going back to 1912, but when Nebraska takes on Oklahoma for the 74th time tomorrow, it will be a meaningless game -- freighted with significance.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Claimed Turner Ward, outfielder, off waivers from the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUSANA TORRUELLA LEVAL has been named director of El Museo del Barrio, which she joined in 1990 as chief curator. She has been acting director for six months, since the resignation of Petra Barreras.

title:
Currents;
Meet Me in St. Louis Or Chicago or Paris For Grand Design
description: THE Louisiana Purchase Exposition of 1904 is best known for the song "Meet Me in St. Louis, Louis," which later became the title of a musical film (minus a "Louis"). But the bombastic Beaux Arts-style architecture of the fair's pavilions has been all but forgotten.

title: Eurotunnel Fee Settlement
description: Eurotunnel P.L.C., the British-French company that will operate the rail-tunnel link between Britain and France, said today that it was settling a dispute with ESC Wagons, the company supplying trains for the tunnel.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Bougainvillea in Winter

title: On This Subject, Bishops Speak for the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: The Leonard Bernstein Revue A Helluva Town! Rainbow and Stars 30 Rockefeller Plaza Through Jan. 1

title: Lights! Lights! For Every Room, Lights!
description: NOT everyone is lucky enough to live in a house brimming with natural light. But despite lighting problems caused by things like small windows, low ceilings or shadows cast by tall buildings across the street, it's still possible to use fixtures to light a home in a way that's both pleasing to the eye and functional.The Living Room

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST UNITED CORP., Oakland, Md., said its acquisition of the Myersville Bank unit of Hometown Bancorp Inc. had been approved by the shareholders of both institutions.

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: All banks and financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. But markets in other countries are open.

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: WHEN the television set goes dead, the audio-cassette player eats tape or the camcorder fails to work, the next step is usually to buy a replacement. But sometimes it pays to have an item repaired.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section last Thursday misstated the address of T, an emporium and cafe expected to open in SoHo. It is at 142 Mercer Street.

title: 'Red Shoes' Opening Postponed Until Dec. 16
description: The Dec. 2 opening of "The Red Shoes," the musical based on the 1947 movie about the ballet, at the Gershwin Theater, has been postponed until Dec. 16, the show's producer, Martin Starger, announced yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: 11-Year-Old British Boys Convicted in Toddler Slaying

title: Tobacco's Role in Philip Morris Plan
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it would cut 14,000 jobs, or 8 percent of its total work force, and close or scale back 40 facilities.

title: Review/Dance; A Very Mixed Bag, Choreographically
description: How resourceful dancers can be! That was demonstrated on Friday night by Ballet Inc., an organization directed by Charles David Anderson that encourages new choreographers. The program offered premieres by Mr. Anderson, a former member of the New York City Ballet, and Carld Jorel Jonassaint, a member of American Ballet Theater. The cast was to include Mr. Anderson and young dancers from City Ballet, Ballet Theater, Dance Theater of Harlem and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: United Airlines Unions Resume Bid to Gain Control
description: Pilots' and machinists' unions at United Airlines are resuming their effort to gain control of the carrier.

title: UNITED ASSET MANAGEMENT PLANS ANOTHER ACQUISITION
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire GSB Investment Management Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition would be the seventh this year for United Asset Management, a Boston-based holding company for 36 investment management firms. GSB, a Fort Worth investment company with $2.4 billion in assets, will continue to operate under its own name. The purchase is expected to be completed next month. Affiliates of United Asset Management manage more than $96 billion for more than 5,000 clients worldwide.

title: LORD OWEN WARNS RIVALS IN BOSNIA
description: In a speech prepared for delivery on Thursday in London, the European Community's mediator on the Balkans warns that unless a peace accord on Bosnia and Herzegovina is reached soon, the United Nations may impose new sanctions and Britain and France may withdraw their troops from the peacekeeping force in the former Yugoslavia.

title: DISTRIBUTION TO COMPLETE A RYDER SPINOFF
description: Ryder System Inc. said yesterday that its board had declared a special tax-free dividend of one share of its aircraft engine services unit for every four shares of Ryder common stock. The dividend of Aviall Inc. stock is payable on Dec. 7 to shareholders of record on that date. The distribution will complete Ryder's spinoff of the aviation business as the company focuses on its trucking business.

title: Man Who Killed 2 Is Indicted on 2 Gun Charges
description: A Brooklyn man who used an unlicensed gun to kill two teen-agers who he said were robbing him at gunpoint was indicted yesterday on gun-possession charges by a grand jury that rejected possible charges of murder, manslaughter and assault.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section last Thursday misstated the address of T, an emporium and cafe expected to open in SoHo. It is at 142 Mercer Street.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet Honors Broadway and Hollywood
description: George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins and Peter Martins all choreographed Broadway musicals, and Mr. Robbins and Balanchine even toiled briefly in Hollywood. At other times, these past or present artistic directors of the New York City Ballet created works for the company with show business themes that used classical technique.

title: Corrections
description: A profile in The Home Section last Thursday about a 1960's leader of the Weather Underground movement misspelled her first name and omitted the surname of a child being reared by her and her husband. The former leader is Bernardine Dohrn; she and her husband, William Ayers, are the legal guardians of Chesa Jackson Boudin.

title: Among Amish, Suspect In Arson Is Well Known
description: State prosecutors last week charged the grandson of a local Amish bishop with setting fires that burned $1 million worth of barns and livestock last year on six Amish dairy farms here in the lush Kishacoquillas Valley, 70 miles northwest of Harrisburg.

title: The Turkey Farmer
description: The boys wondered about this one farmer down the road who did nothing on his little farm but raise turkeys. He said if you really cared about one thing, that should be enough for anybody. He said he knew more about turkeys than any other person in the world.

title: Lima Journal; Dictator? President? Or General Manager of Peru?
description: Pen and paper at the ready, Peru's mathematician-turned-President likes to make quick calculations. For an American visitor Tuesday night, he calculated that Peru's toll of 22,000 dead in 13 years of civil strife equals 250,000 dead in the United States.

title: Nassau Residents Offer Ideas for New Legislature
description: Nassau County residents are presenting a long wish list to the commission that a Federal judge assigned to reinvent the county's government to comply with the Constitutional requirement of one person, one vote.

title: 'Six or Seven Seconds,' Then Clinging to Hope
description: It was just another work day. And like all the others before, Charles T. Berberich and his co-workers gathered in the morning chill, climbed into a small cage and were lowered into the darkness of a construction shaft below.

title: Mary Luke Is Dead; Author, 74, Wrote On Elizabethan Era
description: Mary Luke, a biographer who wrote about Tudor and Elizabethan figures, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. She was 74 and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY WORKER KILLED IN TUNNEL ACCIDENT

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Afghan Whigs Irving Plaza

title: Knick $26 Million Man Ready to Earn His Keep
description: He has been the $26 million invisible man. While Patrick Ewing and John Starks have grabbed the headlines, Charles Smith's name has been relegated to injury updates. No one much asked where he was or when he would be back. No one much missed him, either.

title: Not the First Park Inspired by History
description: To the Editor:

title: An Unsung Caravaggio Finds Glory in Dublin
description: Sergio Benedetti stood behind the almost reverent crowd in the National Gallery of Ireland as it murmured admiration for the painting he expects will give the museum new status in the art world: a wide canvas of somber shadow and sparkling light showing Judas kissing Christ as a soldier grips Jesus's neck, ready to drag Him away for crucifixion.

title: Arab Students, Foes of P.L.O. Pact, Win Key Vote
description: In the first significant electoral test for the P.L.O. since it signed a peace accord with Israel, backers of Yasir Arafat were defeated today in voting for the student council at Bir Zeit University, the West Bank's leading academic institution.

title: Justice Delayed: Caseload Cripples an Appeals Court
description: In 1987 an 8-year-old girl was run over by a school bus in Queens and suffered what doctors said would be permanent damage to her reproductive system.

title: Art of Glass Blowing Finds a Home in Brooklyn
description: In the reaches of an old vaudeville theater in Brooklyn, where the balcony once hung, stands a three-story-high maze of girders and cables, intake pipes and exhaust ducts that nurse an incessant roar from four white-hot furnaces.

title: U.S. to Finance Project to Study Breast Cancer On Long Island
description: On the day she learned she had breast cancer, Lorraine Pace began to gather evidence.

title: Keenan Switches Gears, but the Rangers Roll On
description: Certain rules are supposed to be followed when a sports team is on a streak. Don't talk too much about it. Don't make any predictions. And, most important, don't tinker with what's working.

title: Richter and Terri Lead Devils Past the Sabres
description: The Devils, led by Chris Terreri's stellar goaltending, extended their unbeaten streak on the road to six games by defeating the Buffalo Sabres, 5-3, tonight at the Auditorium.

title: Adoptions That Lack Papers, Not Purpose
description: NATHAN AND JANET RILEY married three years ago and immediately took a little boy named Charles Johnson 3d into their home in Philadelphia. The Rileys are now learning about P.T.A.'s, French-horn lessons and temper tantrums -- the realities of raising a son. They fret over private concerns when the child, Mr. Riley's great-nephew, is out of earshot: are they hugging him enough? Should they say "I love you" more?

title: Bridge
description: A star German player made a strong bid for a second major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today. Sabine Zenkel, who lives in Chicago but won a silver medal for her native Germany in the World Championships in Chile in September, won the Life Master Women's Pairs here Saturday. Today she was leading into the semifinal stage of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championships, playing with Tom Sanders of Nashville, long one of America's top-ranked players.

title: Public & Private; Death at an Early Age
description: Today is Thanksgiving and I won't be writing my column. Norma Perkins-Murray, who runs a home day-care center in Aurora, Ill., wrote it for me.

title: The Airline Settlement: Not a Solution
description: The families who gather around a dining room table eating turkey this Thanksgiving, instead of rushing through airports desperately seeking a flight, owe thanks to President Clinton for artfully ending the strike against American Airlines by its flight attendants.

title: THOMSON-CSF TO BUY A HUGHES SUBSIDIARY
description: The French military electronics company Thomson-CSF reached an agreement yesterday to buy Hughes Rediffusion Simulation Ltd. of Britain. The price was not disclosed. The acquisition would put Thomson in position to challenge CAE Inc. of Canada as the world's No. 1 producer of flight simulation equipment.

title: S. C. Tsiang, an Economist, 75; Helped Guide Taiwan's Economy
description: S. C. Tsiang, an emeritus professor of economics at Cornell University and a principal architect of Taiwan's economic miracle died on Oct. 21 in Chicago. He was 75

title: UMass Jolts Tar Heels in Overtime; Kansas Wins
description: What a great run for the state of Massachusetts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 CLINTON MEETS WITH RUSHDIE

title: 2 Companies Plan Sharp Payroll Cuts
description: Two corporations announced plans to cut thousands of workers -- 14,000 at Philip Morris and 7,500 at NCR. Both are trying to streamline to stay competitive, doing their work with fewer employees.

title: William C. Brinkley, 76, Writer Known for His Novels of the Sea
description: William Clark Brinkley, a novelist known for his books about the Navy and the sea, died on Monday at his home in McAllen, Tex., near the Gulf of Mexico. He was 76.

title: A Speed Burner From Saratoga
description: On a dark and rainy afternoon, the quiet of Saratoga Spa State Park is broken by a dozen teen-age girls, who run amiably on the snake-like trails. Their shoes squish in the mud, their ponytails bounce behind them and their gloves are inscribed with "No. 1 in the Country."

title: Regional Bank Rates
description: Following are average annual percentage yields, in percent, on money-market accounts and C.D.'s offered on November 24, 1993 by the 10 largest banks and savings institutions in each of the 10 largest metropolitan areas.

title: No Headline
description: "Our message to the international community is that it should not say or do anything to give hope to this regime. It is a regime of infamy and it should be isolated. " -- WOLE SOYINKA, referring to the Government of Nigeria. [ A10:1. ]

title: Assignment: Bring Asia To the Amex
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that Lisa S. Y. Sun, a lawyer, had been appointed managing director of the exchange's newly created Asia division.

title: FIELDCREST SHAREHOLDER ASKS FOR COMPANY'S SALE
description: Wyser-Pratte & Company, a minority shareholder in Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., asked the Fieldcrest board yesterday to sell the company to Springs Industries or to the highest bidder. Wyser-Pratte, a management firm that owns about 3 percent of Fieldcrest stock, has said it opposes Fieldcrest's plan to buy the Amoskeag Company, its controlling shareholder. Wyser-Pratte contends Fieldcrest is paying an inflated price for Amoskeag. Shares of Fieldcrest closed up 75 cents yesterday, to $25.75.

title: A Jewel-Box Library Dream
description: "IN Russia, it's an old saying," said Vicky Nicholas. "If you really hate someone, you tell them, 'May you renovate your apartment every hour.' "

title: GUN-CONTROL ACT WINS FINAL BATTLE AS G.O.P. RETREATS
description: The Senate today passed a mandatory waiting period for the purchase of handguns after Republican opposition to the measure collapsed. It was an anti-climactic finish to seven years of Congressional battle.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra Avery Fisher Hall

title: First Signs of Resistance To Nigeria Coup Appear
description: Almost a week after Nigeria's new military leader seized power in a bloodless coup, the first significant signs of resistance to his takeover have begun to emerge.

title: At Last, the Brady Law
description: Congress has finally stood up to the intimidating lobby of weapons peddlers and passed the simple, fair Brady handgun control bill. Public pleas to tone down society's violence, and the moral claim for slowing down the domestic small arms race, have overwhelmed a potent gun lobby that in the end went down with a whimper.

title: Sports of The Times; Some '93 Holiday Thoughts
description: IN the Phillies' dugout before one of the World Series games, John Kruk learned that the man he was talking to had purchased him in a rotisserie league last season.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Arthur Blythe Alto Saxophonist Bradley's 70 University Place, Through Saturday

title: 2 Large Companies Make Cuts
description: Two blue-chip American corporations -- Philip Morris, the tobacco and food company, and NCR, the computer unit of A.T.& T. -- announced yesterday that they planned to cut their payrolls by a total of as many as 21,500 workers, or as much as 8 percent at Philip Morris and 15 percent at NCR.

title: Caution SIgnal for Corporate Boards
description: Shareholders won an important victory yesterday when Delaware's Chancery Court ruled that Paramount Communications had unfairly snubbed QVC Network Inc.'s hostile bid in favor of one from Viacom Inc.

title: Parent & Child
description: WHEN Dr. Jeanne Brooks-Gunn came home from a hospital stay a year ago, she expected her 3-year-old son to be upset but to quickly get over his concerns once he realized she had returned. She was wrong.

title: U.N. to Expand Street Patrols in Mogadishu
description: With bandit attacks on civilians becoming more frequent, United Nations military officials have agreed to put more soldiers on the streets to protect their workers despite misgivings that their presence might provoke confrontations with Somali militiamen.

title: Review/Dance; Repression, Romanticism and Rebirth
description: Henning Rubsam united his company, Sensedance, with other dancers in "Dancegiving," a program presented on Monday night at St. Mark's Church.

title: Witnesses in Trade Center Trial Tell of Inquiries for Hydrogen Gas
description: The prosecution in the World Trade Center case presented evidence yesterday indicating that one of the four men on trial used bogus company names in an effort to have hydrogen gas cylinders delivered to the storage rental locker where the material for a bomb was assembled.

title: Books of The Times; Second Chances: Madison County Goes to India
description: Slow Waltz in Cedar Bend By Robert James Waller 197 pages. Warner Books. $16.95.

title: Young Divers Wish Kimball Well as He Starts New Life
description: In an emotional parting Tuesday night at the Swimming Hall of Fame pool before about 100 well-wishers, the United States' Olympic diving coach, Ron O'Brien, told Bruce Kimball that he has a full-time job waiting for him with the Fort Lauderdale Diving Club.

title: Executive Changes
description: BOCA RATON CAPITAL CORP., Boca Raton, Fla., a business development company whose principal asset is an investment in Railamerica Inc., named Alan L. Jacobs president and chief executive. CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC., Los Angeles, appointed Robert J. Lambert executive vice president of human resources.

title: On This Subject, Bishops Speak for the Church; Not a Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 9, about a study showing that being cautious and somewhat dour is a key to longevity, misidentified the issue of The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology in which it appeared. It was the issue of August, not October.

title: Eisenreich Re-Signs With Philadelphia
description: Outfielder JIM EISENREICH, who batted .318 in 153 games this past season, re-signed with the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday, agreeing to a one-year contract worth $1.4 million. Eisenreich is 34 and made $675,000 in 1993. He will earn $1.2 million next season and the Phillies have an option for 1995 at $1.2 million with a $200,000 buyout.

title: On This Subject, Bishops Speak for the Church; Approval for Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Continue a Climb Back
description: The bond market continued its small rally yesterday, with prices bouncing back for the second consecutive day after more than a week of steep losses.

title: DISCLOSURE URGED FOR SECRET BUDGET
description: The White House should disclose the multibillion-dollar budget for secret intelligence spending, senior members of Congress have urged President Clinton.

title: Slipshod Play: Cowboys Give Game to Dolphins
description: On a 32-degree afternoon of drizzle, sleet, snow and rain, and on a field covered with enough snow that the hash marks could barely be seen, the Miami Dolphins and the Dallas Cowboys played a Thanksgiving Day game here today. The table could not have been set with more unusual drama.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; In creating a spot, many say there's nothing like the real thing.
description: IS reality in advertising like Samuel Goldwyn's definition of sincerity, in that once you can fake it, you've got it made?

title: After Tourists' Deaths, Florida Works to Recover
description: The homicide statistics seemed to spell disaster for the $31 billion tourist industry in Florida: since the beginning of last winter's tourist season, nine visitors, all of them foreigners, have been killed near some of the state's most popular resorts.

title: Body of Man Is Recovered From Tunnel
description: The body of a worker killed by a huge winch that plunged into a deep shaft at a water-tunnel construction site in Queens was recovered yesterday as New York City and Federal officials planned an extensive joint investigation to determine the cause of the accident.

title: Review/Photography; The Mapplethorpes: Gallery, Artist and Model
description: It's both fitting and not surprising that the Guggenheim Museum's first exhibition in its new photography gallery is devoted to the work of Robert Mapplethorpe. When the museum announced that it would begin collecting photographs, it did so on the strength of a 1992 gift, including both artworks and cash valued by the museum at $5 million, from the foundation the photographer set up a year before he died in 1989. The new gallery, on the fourth floor of the addition to the Guggenheim's familiar spiral building, is also named after Mapplethorpe.

title: LUTHERANS BALK ON A SEX POLICY
description: A four-year effort by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America to write a statement on human sexuality has nearly foundered since reports of a first draft alarmed members of the 5.2 million-member denomination.

title: Anthony Burgess, 76, Dies; Man of Letters and Music
description: Anthony Burgess, the prolific British novelist, composer, librettist, essayist, semanticist, translator and critic, whose best-known novel, "A Clockwork Orange," offered a bleak vision of a violence-ridden future, died yesterday in London Hospital. He was 76 and lived in Monaco and Lugano, Switzerland.

title: Mediterranean Fruit Flies Return to California
description: The Mediterranean fruit fly has returned to Southern California, threatening many crops and rekindling a debate over how best to eradicate the stubborn pest.

title: After Murder, Britain Asks Why? Why?
description: A day after a jury found two 11-year-old boys guilty of the abduction and murder of a Liverpool toddler, the police, politicians and psychiatrists across Britain were pondering questions the trial did not answer: how is it that two otherwise normal children could commit such a barbaric crime?

title: Market Place; Baxter hints it may sell stock in some intriguing but risky lines.
description: BURIED in last week's seemingly routine announcement of a restructuring at Baxter International were hints that Baxter might sell stakes to the public in some of its most exciting -- and riskiest -- new-product projects.

title: Struggling Oilers Drop Their Coach
description: TED GREEN, who made a National Hockey League career out of bashing opponents into the boards, was discharged yesterday as head coach of Edmonton. The Oilers are 3-18-3, the worst start in the team's history.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Food in the Genes

title: New Churchill Papers, but No Pearl Harbor News
description: The Government has begun releasing documents from Winston Churchill's secret wartime intelligence archive, but so far they do not shed light on one of the war's greatest mysteries -- whether Churchill knew in advance of the impending Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941.

title: People
description: * Bruce Campbell has rejoined Ketchum Advertising San Francisco, as executive vice president and chief creative officer, assuming some responsibilities from Millie Olson, who continues as executive vice president and executive creative director and assumes a more active role in new business. Mr. Campbell was previously a senior vice president, creative director and partner at Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, which he joined in 1979 from Ketchum.

title: Ferrari Shows the Way From Racer to Road Car
description: The connection between racing car and passenger car has evolved over the last 30 years into more of a fantasy -- well sustained by auto manufacturers' advertising agencies -- than a nuts-and-bolts reality.

title: Review/Theater; A Political Morality Tale On the McCarthy Era
description: Few calumnies have had a more lasting effect on the national psyche than the witch hunt for Communists instigated and pursued in Congress by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the 1950's. Its smoldering residue gives off varying degrees of heat and light in such diverse works as Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" and Neil Simon's "Laughter on the 23d Floor" on Broadway, and Laurence Holder attempts to stoke it into a full blaze downtown in his new play, "Red Channels," at Theater for a New City.

title: Keenan Magic Makes Doubt Vanish
description: It was after a Ranger loss against the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena late last season when the veteran Mike Gartner and General Manager Neil Smith admitted what every outsider had already seen. The Rangers didn't believe in themselves. They didn't have any confidence. And, because of it, they were playing erratic, hesitant and ineffective hockey.

title: Art in Review
description: Claire A. Khalil Nancy Hoffman Gallery 429 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through Wednesday

title:
Empty New Buildings;
Tribeca Tower Will Become a Rental
description: Tribeca Tower's days as a luxury condominium were over before they began. But soon, the 52-story building, empty since it was completed a year and half ago, will spring to life under new ownership and as New York City's newest mixed-income rental.

title: Art in Review
description: '25 Years, Part I' Paula Cooper Gallery 155 Wooster Street (at Houston Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: Colombia Court Says Ransom Can Be Paid
description: A high court's decision to overrule a series of laws designed to curb kidnappings in Colombia, which has one of the highest abduction rates in the world, has generated controversy among officials and proponents of the legislation.

title: The Spoken Word
description: TALKS AT THE WHITNEY, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street. "Vija Celmins," tomorrow at 2 P.M.; "In a Classical Vein," tomorrow and Sunday at 3:30 P.M.; "Mike Kelley," Sunday at 2 P.M. The lectures, by Margaret Sundell, are free with museum admission: $6; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 570-3611.

title: Ailing UMass Seeks Another N.I.T. Upset
description: Amid all the pre-game speculation that top-ranked North Carolina would crush the undersized Massachusetts Minutemen in a semifinal matchup of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament, Roy Williams issued a warning that went unheeded.

title: That Indelible Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: Clifton and Passaic played a 0-0 game today in the meeting between the longtime Passaic County high school football rivals. It will go down as a tie in the standing, but this was clearly an effort for Clifton to brag about.

title: Millions Without a Home
description: According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the number of people seeking asylum worldwide has now swelled to 19.7 million. That staggering figure does not include an estimated 24 million people dislocated in their own homelands because of war and persecution.

title: Israelis Wound 37 in Violent Gaza Street Protests
description: In the most serious eruption of unrest in the Gaza Strip since the signing of the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord, Israeli soldiers shot and wounded 37 Palestinians today in violent street protests set off by the killing on Wednesday of a militant Muslim commander.

title: Inside Art
description: Modern Buys Collection

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Serbs and Croats Try to Build Bridge to Peace
description: Under heavy security, Serbian and Croatian scholars, artists and political figures have gathered here to seek reconciliation between their republics, which have been at war since April 1991.

title: Jane G. Judge, 91, an Educator And Noted Expert on Childhood
description: Jane G. Judge, who spent five decades as a social worker, educator and child advocate, died on Wednesday at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 91.

title: Critic's Notebook; Sampling Art In Sound Bites
description: FOR many people who listen to Acoustiguides, going to an art museum is like plunging into the ocean without knowing how to swim. The Acoustiguides are their cruise ships and Philippe de Montebello, the voice that launched a thousand exhibitions, is their captain.

title: Kafr al-Ilw Journal; Industrious Egypt Is Choking Its People to Death
description: When the students at the Kafr al-Ilw primary school begin to cough uncontrollably they are sent home.

title: TV Weekend; On Point in a War Zone Called Urban America
description: "There Are No Children Here," a book by Alex Kotlowitz, formerly a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, chronicles the lives of two boys growing up in a Chicago housing project. The children are black. They live in what has come to be known as the other America, one often bearing a terrifying resemblance to a war zone.

title: Hard Times Dilute Enthusiasm for Clean-Air Laws
description: One of the few things about life in Southern California that has improved in recent years is the air. The air is indisputably cleaner and clearer and the region's notorious alerts for lung-searing smog are all but history.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the early hours of Thanksgiving Day, viewers of television's "Late Night With Conan O'Brien" saw New York City Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS put in a telephone call to Gov. MARIO M. CUOMO.

title: VW Plan For 4-Day Workweek Is Adopted
description: Volkswagen A. G. reached agreement today with the metal workers union on a radical plan to reduce costs by putting production workers at its six German plants on a four-day workweek and cutting their pay by nearly 10 percent.

title: Kohl's Candidate for President Pulls Out
description: In a sharp blow to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political standing, his candidate for the German presidency withdrew today and said another man from eastern Germany should get the job instead.

title: Passing Blame at Paramount Over a Meeting a Court Assailed
description: There was finger-pointing yesterday within Paramount Communications about whether the company's board should have held a crucial meeting during which, according to a Delaware court ruling, it did not give proper consideration to a takeover bid from QVC Network, several people with knowledge of the situation said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: "Most people here are still afraid to be independent, to start out on a risky project like this. Risk is not something they understand very well." -- ALBRECHT WENDT, a West German who has moved east. [ A12:1. ]

title: It Should Be Called the Grossman Health Care Bill
description: When Bill and Hillary Clinton said they had "no pride of authorship" in their legislative proposal to overhaul the nation's health care system, there was good reason: neither they nor anyone else in the White House wrote it.

title: French Coach Resigns
description: France's soccer coach, GERARD HOULLIER, resigned yesterday, eight days after the national team was eliminated from the 1994 World Cup.

title: Plans for an Irish Cultural Center Divide a Village; Opposition by a Residents' Group Brings Claims of Bias From the Project's Proponents
description: When Edward Sheeran proposed creating the largest Irish cultural center outside Dublin on a college campus in this Westchester village, the reaction of many residents was swift and negative.

title: Boston Globe Cuts Agency Search to 3
description: The Boston Globe has narrowed the review on its estimated $4 million account to three agencies from five. The account had been at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston for 15 years. The newspaper and the agency decided to part ways last month.

title: Art in Review
description: Sean Landers Andrea Rosen Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: RUSSIA WARNS NATO ON EXPANDING EAST
description: Russia's foreign intelligence service warned NATO today that any move to incorporate Eastern European countries would force Moscow into "fundamental" military countermeasures and heighten anti-Western sentiments.

title: Paris Opera Reduces Its President's Role
description: Pierre Berge, the Yves Saint Laurent executive whom President Francois Mitterrand appointed president of the Paris Opera, will lose control of the opera after February. The announcement was made by Jacques Toubon, the French Minister of Culture, at a news conference this morning.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASKETBALL Reid Leads St. Raymond's

title: Bears Take Black-and-Blue Bowl
description: The Chicago Bears, playing tough, mean and inspired defense, upset the Detroit Lions today, 10-6. As Coach Wayne Fontes of the Lions put it, "Their defense strangled our offense."

title: Sara Lee's European Strategy Proves a Success
description: The chairman of the Sara Lee Corporation, John H. Bryan, had a difficult time in the late 1970's selling the company's directors on his idea of expanding into Europe.

title: Article 238393 -- No Title
description: Here's a secret, a theater district secret, which makes it especially nice. Walk over to 46th Street between Eighth Avenue and Broadway, a block east of Restaurant Row. Look for the entrance, under a marquee, to the Edison Hotel. Between the marquee and an Italian restaurant is a white door that looks more like a closet than an entrance. Go through that door and walk one flight down to a reception desk in front of a glass-block wall. You are now entering Indigo Blues, a nightclub that is also the home of Mama's Kitchen, which calls itself the "Rolls-Royce of Southern Cuisine."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19 GO EAST, SOME SAY IN GERMANY About 250,000 pioneers have abandoned the security of western Germany to seek their fortune in what they call "the wild east." A1 Chancellor Helmut Kohl's candidate for the presidency withdrew. A12

title: Pursuing Facts After Rollins Debacle
description: In the two weeks since Edward J. Rollins the astute campaign strategist became Edward J. Rollins the notorious liar, New Jersey's political landscape has been littered with contradiction and uncertainty, but nothing approaching verifiable fact.

title: Universities Biased Against Religion, Scholar Says
description: A leading historian of American religion has accused the nation's major universities of excluding scholarship that reflects religious viewpoints, especially traditional Christian ones.

title: After Flood, Giving Thanks Simply
description: For Ken and Sandi Crim, this was Thanksgiving without the harvest, or home.

title: Square Rooting
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Cabaret; Susceptible To Romantic Infections
description: Nobody knows better than the cabaret singer Andrea Marcovicci how a seemingly harmless popular song can infect your life by instilling romantic expectations that can never be met. That is a running theme of Ms. Marcovicci's popular cabaret act. And on Wednesday evening, it dominated her debut concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Bozell Promotes 3 Detroit Executives
description: Bozell Worldwide has revamped its Bozell Detroit office in Southfield, Mich., promoting three top executives to additional posts.

title: Alabama Governor Plans Educational Overhaul to Address Ruling
description: Gov. Jim Folsom Jr. has proposed a sweeping set of overhauls to address a state judge's ruling that Alabama's schools violate the State Constitution by failing to provide an adequate education.

title: Cardinals and Their Coach Losing the Numbers Game
description: Before taking a head-coaching job with the Phoenix Cardinals, be sure to have plenty of food in the refrigerator and some unemployment insurance. The Cardinals have provided a coaches graveyard over the years. In fact, some coaches jokingly call the team's owner, Bill Bidwell, "the nutty professor" because of his horn-rim glasses and what they say are some of the zany things he puts his coaches through.

title: Zulu Leads Unlikely Alliance In Facing Post-Apartheid Era
description: By uncanny coincidence the Friday night movie on television last week, after South Africa's political rivals had signed a new constitution, was "Zulu," a 1964 film about the Zulu struggle against British colonialists in the last century.

title: Review/Film; A Home That Was Far From Sweet
description: To judge from "El Pisito" ("The Little Apartment"), an excessively noisy, dark comedy directed by the Spanish film maker Marco Ferreri, New York City's real estate squeeze in the 1980's was nothing compared with Madrid's in the 1950's. In the movie's vision of real estate hell, middle-class people who can't afford modern housing -- and that seems to be almost everyone -- often live eight to an apartment in a space that is more appropriate for two. Because of overcrowding, thin ceilings and frequently raised voices, apartment living often borders on bedlam.

title: Tajik Civil War Fades, but the Brutality Goes On
description: It was just after dusk when a car with five men drove into this small village on a collective farm in southern Tajikistan. The men were armed and drunk, and they were looking for women, villagers recalled the following morning.

title: Oil Companies Tread Warily Into Russia's Decrepit Fields
description: There's a fish in the hole at well 7551 in the vast Siberian oilfield here. To hook that fish -- an oilmen's term for stray tubing or other gear blocking the flow of oil -- a team of American and Canadian rig hands and engineers led by Texaco Inc. is braving below-zero temperatures and stiff winds to feed drill pipe 8,000 feet down to the blockage, hoping to hoist it to the surface or ram it out of the way.

title: New York Shop Gets New Name in Merger
description: The agency being created by the merger of the New York office of Hal Riney & Partners and the New York agency Angotti, Thomas, Hedge will no longer carry the Riney name.

title: Ruling on QVC Bid Faces an Expert Review
description: Whether a Delaware court ruling for QVC Network Inc. in its bid to gain control of Paramount Communications survives a review by the Delaware Supreme Court next month depends on how the higher court interprets previous cases pitting the discretion of corporate boards against the rights of shareholders.

title: EDUCATION PANEL STATES ITS MISSION
description: To ease fears about Federal intrusion into local school systems, the National Education Goals Panel said last week that the educational standards being adopted in various subjects were not intended to become a national curriculum.

title: Review/Art; Amid Depression Sorrow, a Celebratory Message
description: Six decades ago, with America in the grip of the Depression, Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal Administration began to pay artists to illuminate the walls of schools, hospitals and government waiting rooms. The artists weren't always top of the line, though some, like Stuart Davis, were among the best of their time. The work was often didactic, with a positive, even celebratory, spirit. Most important, it was showing up in the overcrowded institutional spaces where many Americans spent a chunk of their lives being educated, getting well and learning to wait their turn.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey National Hockey League

title: Accounts
description: Shaw Industries, Dalton, Ga., to Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Co., Atlanta, as the first agency to handle the carpet manufacturer's Trustmark Carpet Selection System account. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $30 million. * CIT Group Holdings, Livingston, N.J., to Bloom FCA, New York, as the first agency to handle the account of the financial-services company's consumer finance division. Billings were estimated at $6.5 million.

title: Jailed by Hanoi, Shut Out by Washington
description: More than 20 years after the last American troops left Vietnam, a sullen shadow war still rages. Psyches on both sides remain haunted by extravagant suspicions, diplomats barely communicate, and unfortunate people trapped in the middle can pay a heavy price.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The man known as Captain Kangaroo thinks television has gotten too commercial, MEL ALLEN thinks sportscasters talk endless gibberish, and VIRGINIA GRAHAM thinks talk shows are not substantive.

title: Albert Collins, 61, Blues Guitarist Whose Wild Style Affected Rock
description: Albert Collins, a Grammy-winning guitarist and the foremost exponent of the Texas blues tradition, died on Wednesday at his home in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 61.

title: Home Video
description: The video as gift has proved a bankable concept over the last few holiday seasons, and this year distributors are responding with stacks of releases.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Longo Metro Pictures 150 Greene Street (at Houston Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Knicks' Davis: The Choir Boy With the Killer Shot
description: Hubert Davis learned about physical basketball long before he joined the Knicks. He learned playing one-on-one against his father.

title: Shorter Hours For Markets
description: All financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. But markets in other countries were open.

title: At the Bar; Last year the Government brought a law firm to its knees. Should it have?
description: Peter M. Fishbein was not one of those Wall Street figures led away from work in handcuffs who, quite apart from their guilt or innocence, came to personify the greed and irresponsibility of the 1980's. But as counsel to the most spectacularly irresponsible savings and loan association in the savings and loan crisis, he suffered almost equal ignominy.

title: From Political Rivals to Marital Partners
description: Leading a dancing, swaying jazz parade of guests in evening dress through the French Quarter, James Carville and Mary Matalin consummated their improbable union on Thanksgiving evening in the noisy style of New Orleans.

title: Rescuing County From Road Name Mix-Ups
description: There are eight School House Roads, five Church Roads and a Singing Bridge in Columbia County. In the summer, one town alone swells from a population of 3,000 to 12,000, and a lot of those people are not quite sure where they are.

title: Tomato Gene That Resists Disease Is Cloned
description: Using a technology developed for the Human Genome Project, scientists at Cornell University have for the first time isolated and cloned a gene responsible for disease resistance in a major crop: tomatoes.

title: Mexico Planning to Loosen Foreign Investment Rules
description: Mexico announced a long-awaited loosening of its restrictions on foreign investment today, extending to the rest of the world many of the rights that will be accorded to American and Canadian concerns under the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Review/Art; Turning Back to the World
description: Throughout his nearly 40-year career, Alex Katz has played a friendly game of one-upmanship with Abstract Expressionism, the style that held sway when he was coming of age as an artist in New York in the 1950's. In his often enormous close-ups of heads and in his more complex paintings of groups of people indoors or out, he has specialized in turning the scale, austere composition and all-over unity of Abstract Expressionism back toward reality, suffusing its formal advances with the facts of life and light and the actual experience of looking at the world.

title: Day of the Shoppers
description: Some people think the Christmas season in New York City begins the moment somebody pushes the button that lights up Rockefeller Center's Christmas tree. Those people are wrong. The season starts today.

title: Hatfield's Clarifications
description: Clemson's former football coach, KEN HATFIELD,issued a statement yesterday about his departure from the school.

title: On My Mind; 3 Israeli Warnings
description: One Israeli Jew killed by an Arab car-bomber, a couple of Jewish hikers murdered, a Jew here, a Jew there -- nine dead, many others left bleeding since Yasir Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin arrived in Washington to shake hands.

title: How Japan Got Mugged in Hollywood
description: Amid the hoopla about "multimedia," about Bell Atlantic's plan to merge with Tele-Communications Inc. and about the QVC-Viacom bidding battle for the Paramount movies-to-books conglomerate, an important lesson is being missed. Like most management lessons these days, it comes from Japan. But this is different from all other Japanese management lessons. This one is about how not to do it.

title: For Children
description: 'International Children's Television Festival' Museum of Television and Radio 25 West 52d Street Manhattan (212) 621-6800 Recommended ages: 4 and up Through May 29

title: Abroad at Home; An American Story
description: Fifteen years ago this Thanksgiving weekend a 10-year-old Vietnamese boy named Viet Dinh arrived in this country as a refugee. He was with his mother, four sisters and a brother. They had $200, which they spent on used winter coats.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Gogo Guitarist

title: Balloons, Floats, Bands And (Rip!) Lots of Wind
description: A clown, his cheeks smeared crimson with greasepaint and his belled jester's cap tinkling faintly, turned his back on the line of giant balloons bobbing down Broadway, hurled one last wad of confetti into the winter breeze, and paused, for a moment, to confront the curbside crowd.

title: Aggies Make Big Plays And Land in Cotton Bowl
description: Texas A&M 18, Texas 9

title: 11 Firefighters Hurt Battling Queens Factory Fire
description: Eleven firefighters were injured yesterday while battling a roaring fire at a Queens metal-processsing factory, the Fire Department said.

title: Hunter to Return
description: His 21-game suspension over, DALE HUNTER returns to the ice tonight when the Washington Capitals play the visiting Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Prayer Won't Balance the Budget
description: Senator Robert Byrd calls the proposed balanced-budget amendment "a precatory expression of pious hope" -- a prayer that something nice will come of a fantasy. The Senator from West Virginia may be concerned that the amendment would curb his authority over spending as chairman of the Appropriations Committee. But, as the meticulous guardian of proper procedure, he is more certainly alarmed by the threat to the Constitution: In the specious name of balancing the books, this amendment would unbalance government.

title: A New Course for Russian Aerospace
description: Four years ago, the Ilyushin Design Bureau, one of Russia's largest aerospace companies, received a proposal from a group that included Armand Hammer and Robert Maxwell for a project to combine Western and Russian aviation technology in a new commercial jetliner.

title: Gullit Finds His Separate Peace
description: Ruud Gullit lives 200 yards from the Ligurian Sea, where another world traveler named Christopher Columbus began his peregrination five centuries ago. This may or may not be an omen.

title: Art in Review
description: Oleg Vassiliev Phyllis Kind Gallery 136 Greene Street (near Houston Street) SoHo Through Wednesday

title: Ban on Some Ammunition Won't End Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/City Ballet; New Gloss On Motifs Romantic And Gypsy
description: One of the legacies of the New York City Ballet's mammoth Balanchine Celebration of last spring was the superb state to which many of George Balanchine's works were restored to the repertory.

title: Some Western Germans Finding Better Financial Rewards in East
description: When the Berlin wall was breached by crowds of ecstatic East Germans in November 1989, Albrecht Wendt saw his chance. He held a good job managing a farm in the west, but had for years dreamed of being his own boss.

title: Review/Music; Into the Mind and Heart Of Jazz's Chameleon Man
description: In his first set on Wednesday night at the Blue Note, the pianist Herbie Hancock gave a glimpse of how his musical mind works. He announced that his trio -- with Dave Holland on bass and Gene Jackson on drums -- would play Cole Porter's "I Love You," adding, "You'll never recognize it." Beyond the first few melodic phrases, he was right; the tune slipped behind odd harmonies, dissolved into streams of single notes, fanned out into two-handed tremolo chords and dispensed salvos of dissonance. Afterward, a smiling Mr. Hancock played the tune slowly and explained what he had done: a key change here, and here, and again, turning Porter's harmonies into his own.

title: Art in Review
description: Josef Sudek 'Poetic Images' Sander Gallery 19 East 76th Street Manhattan Through Jan. 8

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge On New Investor Fears
description: Stock prices resumed their tumble today, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues falling almost 3 percent and closing below the 17,000 level. Weak half-year earnings results from trust banks combined with earlier disappointing reports from commercial banks to scare investors, traders said.

title: Cuomo Drives the Lane as He Runs the State
description: What may be most remarkable about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's relationship with the game of basketball is not the way the beefy 61-year-old sprints up and down the floor, or even his patented fade-away hook shot.

title: Uncaging the Alter Ego, Briefly
description: THE premise was simple. I would rent some kind of super-whiz-bang sports car and take my 55-year-old alter ego out for a spin and see what happened.

title: In Inwood, It Began With a Slip Of the ZIP
description: ON the outskirts of New York, where city and suburb become one, the border between this small Nassau County town and Far Rockaway, Queens, is almost indistinguishable.

title: In Spain, the Unemployed Are Just Too Busy
description: With around 23 percent of its labor force officially out of work, Spain has the highest unemployment rate in the European Community. But while 2.6 million men and women are collecting benefits, it is hard to find anyone sitting at home with nothing to do.

title: Sports of The Times; Strike News: Hockey Subs Look Goofy
description: I knew it was a bad idea to let Disney into hockey. I knew it, I knew it, I knew it. You start calling a hockey team a cutesy name like the Mighty Ducks, and things start to fall apart.

title: Calvin and Hobbes and John Paul
description: Many people find philosophy boring and theology frightening. They would rather read the comics. And so would I: I can't imagine starting a day without studying "Calvin and Hobbes." But whether we notice it or not, that comic strip is often about the fundamental moral issue of our time. Here is a little boy (implausibly given the name of a stern Protestant theologian) asserting that what he wants -- fame, luxury, diversion, staying out of school, hitting Susie with a snowball -- is all that should matter. I am the center of the universe, he says; values are what I say they are.

title: Homeless Ask Court to Halt City Crackdown
description: A citywide campaign to reduce the number of homeless people on the streets was challenged this week in a lawsuit filed here by civil rights groups on behalf of the homeless.

title: Ambulance Workers Were Forced Into Drug Raid, Union Says
description: In an incident they say compromised the safety and credibility of emergency medical workers in a sometimes dangerous neighborhood, officials of the union for the New York City Emergency Medical Service have charged that two workers were ordered on Tuesday to assist the police in a drug bust.

title: Ban on Some Ammunition Won't End Violence; Voice of Gunmakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Perception Lags Changeover by Company
description: Although half the sales of Sara Lee come from apparel and household and personal-care products, the company is still widely regarded as a food company. That misconception is even more striking in Europe than in the United States.

title: Lawyers Have to Take the Complaints of Clients More Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: A Factory in the Business of Candy Canes
description: Michael Briglia knows why schools, Scout troops and clubs are always asking for tours of his little factory here.

title: Restaurant Worker Who Resists Robbery Is Slain
description: A woman working at a Chinese take-out restaurant in the Bronx was shot in the head Wednesday evening for refusing to surrender $19 from the cash register, the police said. Yesterday, she died.

title: Bowie Admitted to Club
description: The former Kentucky basketball star SAM BOWIE has been voted into the Lexington (Ky.) Country Club, becoming the first black member in the club's 91-year history. The club has nearly 500 members.

title: There's No Shortage Of Math Doctorates
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil May Have 26 Different Foreign Policies
description: Representing a state with an economy twice the size of Argentina's, Governor Luiz Antonio Fleury Filho of Sao Paulo has become accustomed to red-carpet treatment on his foreign tours, to the United States, Europe and Taiwan.

title: Elliott Unlikely for Cardinals
description: The back problems that have plagued Giants offensive tackle Jumbo Elliott will probably keep him from playing on Sunday against Phoenix. Elliott practiced sparingly for the second consecutive day today and Coach Dan Reeves said his chances of playing in the late afternoon game at Giants Stadium were "very slim."

title: Giuliani Hints Backer May Get Post
description: New York City Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested strongly yesterday that he would appoint Ninfa Segarra, a member of the conservative majority on the Board of Education, to a position in his administration even as she remained on the board.

title: Now There's No Doubting West Virginia's Coach
description: Vindication. That is a word that might suit Dan Simrell these days. Yet the quarterbacks coach at West Virginia prefers to take success in the same low-key manner he took rejection.

title: Ban on Some Ammunition Won't End Violence; To Make Streets Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CUOMO: ON THE BALL EVERYWHERE

title: EGYPTIAN PREMIER ESCAPES CAR BOMB
description: The Muslim militant group Holy War set off a powerful car bomb in a northern Cairo suburb today in an attempt to assassinate Prime Minister Atef Sedki, according to Egyptian officials and a communique from the group.

title: Gulf War Veteran's Widow Is Charged in Murder
description: Detroit's grim image got a national battering in March 1991, when a newly returned veteran of the Persian Gulf war was shot to death in front of his in-laws' home in an apparent robbery attempt. Everyone from the Rev. Jesse Jackson to a Senate subcommittee cited the slaying as more proof of a social crisis in the streets of urban America.

title: U.S. TO ENCOURAGE LEGAL IMMIGRANTS TO GET CITIZENSHIP
description: The Clinton Administration says it will actively encourage legal immigrants to become United States citizens, a new policy intended to counter hostility to immigrants.

title: Books of The Times; The Portrait of a British Serial Killer
description: Killing for Company The Story of a Man Addicted to Murder By Brian Masters Illustrated. 324 pages. Random House. $24.

title: Release Pollard and Vanunu Together; Jewish Unanimity
description: To the Editor:

title: About SportsFriday And Business Day
description: To accommodate holiday weekend news and advertising, SportsFriday starts on page D1 today. Business Day begins on page D11.

title: Release Pollard and Vanunu Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Just Plain Folk

title: Review/Music; An Austrian Blend By the Philharmonic
description: THE music of Franz Schmidt reverses, in a way, the 20th century's customary view of itself. History would have us believe that this has been a time of revolution: tonality overthrown, Romantic forms reduced to Classical ones, heart-on-sleeve effusion tempered to accommodate wit and discretion or else sarcasm and despair, even violence.

title: Art in Review
description: Tobi Kahn Mary Ryan Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: Restaurants
description: The women at the next table are examining the plates. One by one they pick them up, turn them over, scrutinize the labels. "I wonder if they sell them at Bloomingdale's," says one, tossing her tangled red mane past her pale, powdered face and looking in the direction of the store, a block down the street.

title: Bridge
description: Two little-known players from Berkeley, Calif., Michel Schneider and John Fout, led into the two final sessions of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship here this afternoon, but several famous players are in hot pursuit. Fout is a junior player who represented the United States in the World Junior Team Championship in Denmark in August.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Gauguin in the Plaza

title: Whenever Opportunity Knocks, Jets' Rookie Murrell Comes Out Running
description: In the fourth quarter of the Jets-Bengals game last Sunday, Johnny Johnson was sitting on the sideline nursing bruised ribs, Richie Anderson was out with a severely sprained ankle, Brad Baxter was trying to get his broken chinstrap reattached to his helmet and Jets Coach Bruce Coslet was about to flip his wig.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The singer STEVIE WONDER brought the spirit of the holidays to Public School 189 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Wednesday, and he spoke in support of Charge Against Hunger, a food aid campaign sponsored by American Express and Share Our Strength, a nonprofit relief organization.

title: Deciphering State's Takeover of Jersey City Schools
description: Four years ago, convinced that the Jersey City schools were hopelessly mismanaged, the State of New Jersey seized control of the city's school system, the second largest in the state. Since then, high-ranking school officials have been dismissed, curriculums rewritten, schools painted and repaired. In one instance, a high school swimming pool, once filled with furniture and debris, was returned to use.

title: Mum's the Word on Deals, Michael Says
description: Because he has done more talking than trading, the Yankees' general manager said yesterday that he would stop talking until he began trading or signing.

title: Art in Review
description: David Humphrey McKee Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue (at 58th Street) Through Dec. 4

title: In a Sea of Troubles, Their Gratitude Thrives
description: This land of gutted brownstones and constant sirens is home for Carole Shuler and her three children. Although the glass in the front door of their building is missing, it is better than the homeless shelter where they lived for a spell, and for now the police have shooed away the crack dealers. Yesterday a turkey roasted in the oven. For those and other reasons, Ms. Shuler felt blessed this Thanksgiving.

title: Russia Court Calls 'Protocols' Anti-Semitic Forgery
description: A Russian court ruled today that the "Protocols of the Elders of Zion," a document commonly used as a pretext in this century for anti-Semitic attacks, is a forgery and that to publish it is an anti-Semitic act.

title: Films About the African Diaspora
description: Work by film makers from Cuba, Brazil, Britain, Curacao, Portugal, France and the United States (among other places) is featured in the first Festival of Contemporary Films of the African Diaspora, which began yesterday and will run through Thursday at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street.

title: Growth in China and Asia Draws Investors
description: Investor interest in China and Southeast Asia is strong because of the economic growth prospects there. One way to invest is through the new Ivy China Region Fund, which buys stocks of companies in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries. Investments in this part of the world should be long term because of the risks in emerging markets.

title: Volvo Merger Is Opposed
description: Two shareholders with a total of 3.5 percent of the votes of Volvo A.B. said today that they would vote against Volvo's merger of its car and truck units with Renault.

title: Not Again? Yes, Again. Nets Blow Late Lead
description: After losing three of their last four games in the final minutes of play, the Nets weren't exactly sure what to expect against the Utah Jazz tonight.

title: Critics See False Promises and Higher Taxes in Nassau Budget
description: Less than a month after Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, newly re-elected, said he was proposing a "tax freeze" budget that would eliminate a deficit of at least $39 million, opponents say the plan is full of false promises and raises taxes.

title: How They Do It; Moving Up and Out of a Home Office
description: For 10 years, Douglas Baldwin gave guitar lessons at his home. The business suplemented his income from guitar repair and professional club dates. Having moved three times in the last five years, he found that address changes disrupted his teaching business. Furthermore, students were coming to his home at all hours, and parking was becoming a problem.

title: No Headline
description: "When you look at state-to-state migration, you see that people are moving to the South, because that's where all the jobs are." -- MARK VITNER, a banker in Charlotte. [ A1:4. ]

title: A Solution to a Life Insurance Riddle
description: Among the most perplexing financial decisions are whether to buy life insurance, how much, what type and from whom.

title: Dallas Deal For Alltel And GTE
description: The Alltel Corporation said today that its mobile communications unit had agreed to buy a 10 percent limited partnership stake in the GTE Corporation's Dallas cellular telephone system for $120 million in cash.

title: First Belgian General Strike In Decades Forces Shutdown
description: Belgium's first general strike in almost half a century brought industry and transport to a standstill today, forcing the Government to agree to talks next week with the trade unions on its austerity measures.

title: No End of Paper
description: Here are two simple mathematics problems for the New York City Board of Education.

title: Battle Is Fierce on the Phone Front
description: A.T.& T. wants Ed Sassi back. Ever since the 57-year-old aerospace engineer in Sunnyvale, Calif., switched his long-distance telephone calls to MCI three years ago, A.T.& T. has besieged him with entreaties to return, even offering a $75 bonus to switch back.

title: Trade Debate Brought Out Best in the House
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Hitch Faster Train Service to Fantasies; How About Airports?
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Miller, Hobby Executive, 78
description: Charles D. Miller, a retired executive of the hobby and modeling industry, died on Thursday at his home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 78.

title: Tragedyland
description: In Poland, the Wolf's Lair, the Nazis' Eastern Front command post in World War II, is being converted into a theme resort. According to Travel & Leisure magazine, staff members are to dress in replica uniforms of the Luftwaffe and Wehrmacht, and there will be dancing nightly at "Hitler's Bunker Disco."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Hunter Returns With Bang Dale Hunter got two assists last night in his return from a record 21-game suspension, helping the Washington Capitals gain a 4-4 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins at Landover, Md. Hunter, playing in his first game since April 28, missed a chance to do further damage when he got into a scuffle with Rick Tocchet with 8 minutes 43 seconds remaining in regulation and was given a 10-minute misconduct. He did not return. Hunter, 33, was fined and suspended for a late hit he delivered against the Islanders' Pierre Turgeon in last season's playoffs. It was the longest suspension for a non-stick-related incident in National Hockey League history. (AP)

title: Don't Hitch Faster Train Service to Fantasies
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Woolf, Her Inner Circle And Inner Self
description: Pity the future literary historian who has to rely on the promised new wizardry of vast computer networks for facts. Instead of discovering self-revealing handwritten letters, casual notes, first drafts and intimate diary entries, a biographer may be left with little more original material than lists of cellular phone calls, impersonal second-sight faxes and E-mail: all useful only as electronic confetti for a shredding machine.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO RECEIVES ACQUISITION PROPOSAL
description: Esquire Radio and Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited offer from Steel Partners 2 to acquire Esquire Radio for $50 a share in cash. Steel Partners 2, based in Delaware, is a limited partnership controlled by Warren Lichtenstein and Lawrence Butler. Esquire, based in Brooklyn, develops and imports telecommunications equipment including phones, answering machines and fax machines, primarily for Southwestern Bell. Esquire's shares closed up $2.875 yesterday on the American Stock Exchange at a 52-week high of $50.75. As of Sept. 30, Esquire had about 483,000 shares outstanding, so the Steel Partners offer has an indicated value of about $24 million. Esquire did not have an immediate response to the Steel Partners offer.

title: An American Diplomat Is Abducted in Yemen
description: An American diplomat on assignment in Yemen was abducted on Thursday, State Department officials said today.

title: The Boys of Watergate
description: When my enemy and friend, H. R. (Bob) Haldeman, President Richard Nixon's chief of staff, died on Nov. 12, U.C.L.A. lost a notorious alumnus and one of the last living links between the Westwood campus and the Watergate conspiracy of the 1970's.

title: This Much Is Certain: Nebraska Will Play for Title
description: If you go only by winning and losing, Nebraska finished its regular season today with an 11-0 record and a sound claim as the nation's No. 1 college football team. If you consider artistic impression, the way they do in figure skating, the Cornhuskers played a dull, largely inefficient game, and their 21-7 victory over Oklahoma was made possible by the Sooners' generosity, especially in the fourth quarter.

title: Mountaineers Say: Bring On Cornhuskers
description: West Virginia scored two touchdowns in the fourth quarter today, beat Boston College, 17-14, and then immediately called for a showdown with Nebraska, the only other undefeated and untied bowl team in the nation, to decide just who really is No. 1.

title: Leader's New Image Saps Shining Path's Strength
